story:
Theatre and Me, LLC

Hi. My name is Marcus Siler and I am the owner/founder of Theatre and Me, LLC. I am a graduate of East Stroudsburg University with a BA in Theatre (acting/directing). I am a professional actor and singer. I have been performing professionally since I was young. Besides being a performer I am a teacher (preschool/toddler), mentor, and child advocate. I have also taught high school programs, elderly programs, the Upward Bound Program, served as a child care director and several other positions that concentrate in helping a child and teen grow and develop. I have dedicated my life to helping children. I also have a strong background in creating shows, writing, and developing programs.

My company's mission is to promote a fun, relaxed, respectful and positive learning environment that encourages our students to interact with one another and build self-confidence, self-respect and self-love. Through the art form of "Theatre" our students will be given the opportunity to discover their own inner voice. Some of the creative/performing activities they learn about are acting, voice, dance, stage, film and design techniques to help them better understand more about this ever growing art form of "Theatre". This company is led by our guiding principle: "When you understand more of whom you are then life with all of its complications will be much simpler." 

I am running this campaign because last year, 2013, with a very limited to no budget at all, my volunteers and I were able to help several students understand more about themselves. We were able, with our students, to write, direct, and film a short PSA film about anti-bullying, four commercial shorts, teach students about performing, drawing, music, directing, production, and several other creative and performing art elements. We worked out of a shared studio and we had a great first year.

In 2014, we have big plans. We would love to have our own studio home where we can continue to help students express and grow their creativity and self-confidence. We have two production projects that we will be working on with our students to create and to film. One of the short films is about coping with a relative that is ill, and the other one is about loving who you are and being true to yourself. 

If you contribute and help make this campaign a success we will be able to, produce better quality products, reach more students, offer more free classes to those who cannot afford to learn this craft, and to have a space that is more conducive to a creative/performing arts class. You will  help us own, instead of always renting, the equipment needed to give our students the opportunity to practice in front of the camera as well as learn behind the camera techniques. 

With your help in 2014 we will be able to create and film two strong films. You will also assist us to help students who have a passion for this art form of "Theatre", and who do not have the finances to be able to enroll in performing/creative arts programs. Helping children means the world to me and with the right funding Theatre and Me will be able to do more to benefit their lives.

Thank you all, in advance, for your support! 

What We Need

Our Goal: $63,899.94

This budget will cover the essentials that we need in order to fully teach our clientele for the year of 2014, rent a studio space that is spacious enough for our students needs, buy essential supplies needed for our classes, and to be able to do our three student projects (two short films and our end of the year project). This budget will also help us to be able to offer 25 students free classes for the year of 2014. Having sufficient space and equipment for the students to learn and practice their craft is most essential. 

What You Get

Our perks range from a shout out on Facebook to a credit in our short film titled "The Bully" to being brought on stage at our (2014) end of the year showcase, for audience applause, to being placed on our studio wall of sponsors, as well as several other perks.

Everyone who enrolls in our classes will know who they owe their thanks to. When our classes start back up in 2014, we will print the names of everyone who donates in our brochure because we want all who read the brochure to know all the wonderful people who helped to make the program possible, and we want to show how much we appreciate you all. 


The Impact

Theatre and Me gives students the opportunity to develop a stronger self-worth. Through the medium of "Theatre" we give students the opportunity to take on leadership roles, work in teams, develop projects and see them through completion, display and perform their work, learn that they can create works of "art", and develop many other self-improvement skills. We give children the opportunity to truly be themselves and express their own creativity in a warm and nurturing environment. 

By donating, you can help children to be a part of a program that will assist them into becoming strong confident individuals who think outside of the box. You will assist us in helping students find something that they never thought they had inside of them. Children who are allowed to be creative and who are taught that they don't have to settle for just thinking inside of the box will grow up to be  more productive adults. These children will bring more beauty into our world and be inventors and creators of new and wonderful things that will benefit each and everyone of us in the world. Help us to be able to give back to our future. 

I know this works. I have worked with children for many years, and even before I put this company together I have used the concepts of my company to help children of all ages learn more about themselves. Many of my past students are adults now and are doing wonderful things. Some are teachers, programmers, who create new and interesting games and software, performers and many have other careers and are giving back positively to society. So, if you would love to help children learn more about themselves and to develop a strong positive view of self-worth please donate to Theatre and Me and help our program to be able to fully help others. Thank you for reading. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some other ways that you can help us are:

  • Spread the word on your Facebook, Twitter, Youtube channel, Instagram, Myspace and other forms of media about our campaign and our company.
  • Tell your coworkers, family members and friends about this.
  • Like and follow us on Facebook and spread the word.
  • Our email is theatreandmewithmarcus@gmail.com; facebook account is facebook.com/TheatreandMeLLC 
  • You can also use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • If you would like to donate directly to Theatre and Me, LLC you can email us directly for our mailing address. Thank you.

We wish you a very wonderful 2014!!!

story:
Short Summary

Who are you?

The Aeneid Theatre Company is a new student theatre company devoted to independently producing upstanding non-musical plays at USC. Our first adventure is already well underway: We've recently chosen, cast, and established a technical crew for our first-ever production, Six Degrees of Separation by John Guare. 

What's that?

Six Degrees of Separation is a Pulitzer Prize-winning tragicomedy that gracefully maneuvers issues of class conflict, sexual orientation, and race. The play was written twenty-five years ago, but because of recent political events and the ever-connectedness of humans in the digital age, it is now more relevant than ever. 

So what's the Indiegogo page for?

The next step of this very important process involves an equally important person: You. Because we are a brand-new student organization, we don't have the funding and support that other, long-standing production companies possess. We need a little more assistance to get our company off the ground and onto the stage, and contributors like you can make all the difference in the world.

With your help, ATC can begin making a real impact on the USC theatre community and the students involved.

What We Need & What You Get

Where does the money go?

The Six Degrees production team has set a maximum budget for the production which will not change. The budget is broken down between the costs of scenic design, costuming, venue fees, and other essentials for producing any kind of theatre. Any money raised here will go directly to funding these essential costs of production, even if we do not raise the full $2,000.*

*Indiegogo claims 9% of funds if fundraising does not meet the goal amount.

What do I get out of this?

Well, first, you get the knowledge that you've helped enrich the lives of countless students and theatre-lovers in the USC community by helping produce a work of art.

But if you're looking for something a little more extrinsic, there are a few unique perks involved in contributing to our cause:
  • Every contribution of $10 gets a personal thank you from a member of the ATC board
  • Every contribution of $25 gets two (2) guests free admission and priority seating to one of our six shows.
  • Every contribution of $50 gets two (2) guests free admission tickets and priority seating to one of our six shows and two (2) programs signed by the entire cast as a souvenir.
  • Every contribution of $100 gets two (2) guests free admission tickets and priority seating to one of our six shows and one (1) surprise present from the Six Degrees team!
  • Every contribution of $250 gets the contributor recognition as an executive producer of Six Degrees Team, along with two (2) free admission tickets and priority seating to one of our six shows.
  • Every contribution of $500 gets the contributor recognition as a founding investor in the Aenied Theatre Company on future ATC publications including the website and Facebook page; two (2) free admission tickets and priority seating to one of our six shows; and one (1) surprise present from the Six Degrees Team!

The Impact

How does this help in the big picture?

While USC has amazing student organizations devoted to producing a wide variety of theatre, including musicals, new works, and even sketch comedy. However, USC doesn't have the best track record when it comes to regularly producing great non-musical plays, so we at ATC have taken it upon ourselves to fill that niche. In order for this company to thrive and continue expanding the diversity of the theatrical scene here at USC, we need your help. Every dollar raised helps us reach that goal.

 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    What if I'm totally, 100% broke?

    If you don't have a couple dollars to spare right now, that's okay! You can still help in other ways. Most importantly, you can share this page on all your social media profiles and help spread the word to as many people as possible! And of course, please come to our show!
story_txt:
Short Summary
Who are you?
The Aeneid Theatre Company is a new student theatre company devoted to independently producing upstanding non-musical plays at USC. Our first adventure is already well underway: We've recently chosen, cast, and established a technical crew for our first-ever production, Six Degrees of Separation by John Guare. 
What's that? 
Six Degrees of Separation is a Pulitzer Prize-winning tragicomedy that gracefully maneuvers issues of class conflict, sexual orientation, and race. The play was written twenty-five years ago, but because of recent political events and the ever-connectedness of humans in the digital age, it is now more relevant than ever. 
So what's the Indiegogo page for?
The next step of this very important process involves an equally important person: You. Because we are a brand-new student organization, we don't have the funding and support that other, long-standing production companies possess. We need a little more assistance to get our company off the ground and onto the stage, and contributors like you can make all the difference in the world.
With your help, ATC can begin making a real impact on the USC theatre community and the students involved.

What We Need & What You Get
Where does the money go?
The Six Degrees production team has set a maximum budget for the production which will not change. The budget is broken down between the costs of scenic design, costuming, venue fees, and other essentials for producing any kind of theatre. Any money raised here will go directly to funding these essential costs of production, even if we do not raise the full $2,000.*
*Indiegogo claims 9% of funds if fundraising does not meet the goal amount.
What do I get out of this?Well, first, you get the knowledge that you've helped enrich the lives of countless students and theatre-lovers in the USC community by helping produce a work of art.But if you're looking for something a little more extrinsic, there are a few unique perks involved in contributing to our cause:
Every contribution of $10 gets a personal thank you from a member of the ATC board
Every contribution of $25 gets two (2) guests free admission and priority seating to one of our six shows.
Every contribution of $50 gets two (2) guests free admission tickets and priority seating to one of our six shows and two (2) programs signed by the entire cast as a souvenir.
Every contribution of $100 gets two (2) guests free admission tickets and priority seating to one of our six shows and one (1) surprise present from the Six Degrees team!
Every contribution of $250 gets the contributor recognition as an executive producer of Six Degrees Team, along with two (2) free admission tickets and priority seating to one of our six shows.
Every contribution of $500 gets the contributor recognition as a founding investor in the Aenied Theatre Company on future ATC publications including the website and Facebook page; two (2) free admission tickets and priority seating to one of our six shows; and one (1) surprise present from the Six Degrees Team!


The Impact
How does this help in the big picture?While USC has amazing student organizations devoted to producing a wide variety of theatre, including musicals, new works, and even sketch comedy. However, USC doesn't have the best track record when it comes to regularly producing great non-musical plays, so we at ATC have taken it upon ourselves to fill that niche. In order for this company to thrive and continue expanding the diversity of the theatrical scene here at USC, we need your help. Every dollar raised helps us reach that goal. 


Other Ways You Can Help
What if I'm totally, 100% broke? If you don't have a couple dollars to spare right now, that's okay! You can still help in other ways. Most importantly, you can share this page on all your social media profiles and help spread the word to as many people as possible! And of course, please come to our show!

story:
About A Midsummer Night’s Dream

Synopsis

The course of true love never did run smoothly, but who expected fairies and magic flowers? 

On a midsummer’s night, a quartet of mismatched lovers and a band of inept actors wander into an enchanted forest where they find themselves embroiled in a dispute between the king and queen of the fairies. Romance, confusion, and desire all unite as our characters experience the inexplicable magic of love and the wonder of waking dreams. Some of Shakespeare’s most dazzling, dramatic poetry is found in this glittering and inventive comedic masterpiece, whose seriousness is only fleetingly glimpsed beneath its dreamlike surface.

Our Cast

Heather English as Peaseblossom
Amelia Ross as Fawn
Nina Dosdall as Cobweb
Claire Temple as Moth
Ben Groberman as Mustardseed
Rose McNeil as Titania
Joshua Tompke as Oberon
Boris Bilic as Puck
Carly June Friesen as Hermia
Kyle Wipp as Lysander
Ally Schuurman as Helena
Matt Veenbaas as Demetrius
Kurtis Maguire as Theseus
Tiffany Markwart as Hippolyta
Lori Watt as Egeus
Chris Fofonoff as Starveling
Alex Ross as Flute
Julien Amar as Snout
Julian Legere as Quince
Matthew Simmons as Bottom

About Alchemy Theatre

Alchemy Theatre Ensemble is an exciting, innovative theatre group, and the amalgamation of the talents and dedication of a group of young actors from across the Lower Mainland. Having met while working together on the Vagabond Players’ production of Goodnight Desdemona (Good Morning Juliet), the group created something magical – and it wasn’t just the magic on the stage. This production brought together a pool of talented actors whose chemistry was undeniable, and who were drawn together through their mutual desire to produce alternative theatrical works as well as old classics with a new spin.

After officially forming their own theatre group in the spring of 2014, Alchemy Theatre staged their inaugural summer theatre production of Twelfth Night at The Bernie Legge Theatre, a befitting choice since this is whereGoodnight Desdemona (Good Morning Juliet) was performed. They are bringing summer theatre back to The Bernie Legge Theatre for a second time with this summer’s Shakespeare production, A Midsummer Night’s Dream, which includes both new and existing Alchemy Theatre members, and look forward to a long tradition of summer theatre.

FAQ

So how much does it cost to put on a show anyway?

Our current projected costs break down as follows:

Marketing: $2500
Properties: $500
Setting: $1000
Costumes: $1000
Technical: $1000
Total: $6000

If you need $6000, why is your goal only $2000?

While we would be thrilled to raise more, $2000 covers (most of) our upfront costs for many of the items required for our show. The remaining bills will be due after the show and will be covered by our box office proceeds.

What happens if you don’t raise the $2000?

Well, with your help we will!  In the event that we don’t meet our funding goal through Indiegogo we have secured bridge financing to ensure the production goes forward as planned.

How do I get my selected perk?

We will be contacting our contributors to arrange perks with them, however, the best way will be to pick up your perks at the theatre when you come to see the show!

Is there anything else I can do to help?

We know that sometimes, as much as you'd like to help, it's not financially feasible. We are theatre people.... WE UNDERSTAND. There are some simple things that you can do if you'd like to help us.

  • Make some noise and spread the word about the show to your friends, family, and colleagues.
  • Share our campaign with anyone who you think might be keen on supporting us!
  • Like our Facebook page and follow us on Twitter and Instagram.
  • Become a part of the show by volunteering! From front of house to back stage, we can use your help. Contact alannah.stpierre@alchemytheatre.com to get involved.
  • If you have any other ideas or suggestions of ways to help please reach out and let us know!
Can a Perk be shipped outside of Canada?
Please contact us before donating if you would like your perk shipped outside of Canada.
I have a question you haven't answered yet!
No problem! Simply contact us at the top of this page and we will get back to you as soon as possible with an answer. The FAQ section here on Indiegogo will be updated as well!

story:
Our Mission

to enrich lives through movement and dance

In November 2010, Carisa Armstrong and Christine Bergeron, Texas A&M University dance faculty members, along with other talented performers and choreographers, came together to transform the Armstrong Bergeron Dance Company into Brazos Dance Collective.  The organization remains a non-profit modern dance company and provides an opportunity for creative, skilled and passionate artists to collaborate and share their vision with the community.

Since then, Brazos Dance Collective has produced several stage performances, sponsored master classes, performed regularly at First Friday’s Art Step, continue to produce the Brazos Contemporary Dance Festival and offered a weekend long dance intensive in addition to weekly technique classes.  We have also held several fundraisers and travelled across the state and nation to perform in various festivals.


Brazos Contemporary Dance Festival

 

Carisa Armstrong and Christine Bergeron began the Brazos Contemporary Dance Festival to enrich the arts community in the Brazos Valley. This festival has been very successful over the years and has attracted numerous talented choreographers and dancers to our area. This year in an effort to expand the arts offered in the Brazos Valley we are producing two different concerts - one in May and another in September. The artists featured in these concerts includes established and emerging choreographers and dancers.

 

The Impact of Your Donation

 

Your tax deductible donations will fund the production of these concerts and allow us to continue the growth of contemporary dance in the Brazos Valley. As a non-profit and a member of the Arts Council for the Brazos Valley we have grant funding provided to us but these are matching funds. We must reach our fundraising goal to be able to continue offering quality dance in the Brazos Valley.

story:
Momo Chapela Kurata (Mexican-Japanese, 17 years old)

I have been dancing since I was 4 years old. For the last 2 years I have been studying at the San Francisco Ballet School, one of the best and prestigious schools in the USA.

After my high school graduation this May, I would like to attend classes for the next 2 years at any of the best schools in Europe; Germany, Holland, Norway, Hungary, among others. 

Most of these schools require auditions (live presentation) at different places and dates (march-april). So I need about $5,000.00 USD to afford my travel expenses (flights $1,900 and hotels and so on $3,125 for 25 days).

I would like to pay my own expenses by raising money through ‘crowd-funding’, To those who support me to achieve my dream, I offer photos and  tickets for performances once I am in a ballet company. 

Thank you for visiting my page. Any amount will be greatly appreciated! 

Momo

story:
Hi, everyone!

My name is Collins, and I am a 27-year-old graduate student originally from Murfreesboro, Tennessee, but now making my home in Bowling Green, Kentucky.
My name is Megan.  I am 17 years old, and I am from Palm Harbor, Florida.
We are tap dancers who are wanting to go to Chicago this February and attend the Chicago Human Rhythm Project's Winter Tap JAMboree (follow this link: http://www.chicagotap.org/Performance-Education-Detail-Festival/winter-tap-jamboree-2015.aspx).  Both of us are avid tap dancers who are passionate about the craft, and we want to take master classes from some of the best and most well-known names in tap!  We have been tap dancing for three and fourteen years, respectively, and we have had the privilege of learning from such names as Aaron Tolson, Gloria Esenwein, Tristan Bruns, and Kandee Thacker-Mann.  We love what we do, and we have a tremendous and unquenchable desire to learn and improve our skills so that we may be able to tap with the best!
Unfortunately, finances for the trip are scarce, so we have decided to work together to see to it that we both have the opportunity to participate in this incredible opportunity!  We are wanting to raise $1500 for the trip; this will cover the classes, plane tickets, rental car, hotel, food, and gas (as well as a new pair of tap shoes for Collins!). We could really use your help!

story:
The Show

Power. Kingdoms. Lust. And the Will of one (anti-) hero who wants to do everything he can to conquer the one enemy he cannot beat: Death. Based on the epic from Mesopotamia, one of the oldest pieces of literature known to us today, "Gilgamesh - A Musical Epic" is a story of how Man went from Animal to God, told in the form of an epic musical with a live band. It brings together the rocky deserts of the mythical Middle East and the electrifying energy of Rock to challenge the gods themselves.

Book and Lyrics by Peter Petkovsek

Music by Ian Wehrle

Directed by Peter Petkovsek

Produced by Jenny Ainsworth for Invisible Wall Productions

April 1 – 4

The Connelly Theater


The Journey

Gilgamesh had his quest for immortality.  Peter Petkovsek had his quest to bring the story of Gilgamesh to life as a musical.

Peter’s quest began with his decision to direct a musical for his Columbia University MFA Directing Thesis.  He searched high and low for a musical that lit the fires of his creative soul.  His friend/collaborator/producer Jenny tried to convince him that he wanted to go small when directing a musical for the first time – small cast, small band.  He seriously toyed with the idea of directing Oliver.  She threatened to quit.

Then, much like Gilgamesh, Peter got a crazy idea. But, instead of searching for the oldest man in the world, Peter decided to direct a musical that he wrote himself. But who would be the one to join Peter on this epic journey? Who would find the idea of writing a rock opera based on an ancient Sumerian epic poem for little to no money a creatively sexy one? Enter Ian Wehrle, the man with no fear.

And in just three short months Gilgamesh – A Musical Epic was born and introduced to the world at a staged reading on February 7, in Hell’s Kitchen, New York.

The next phase of the quest is a Showcase production at the Connelly Theater, in the East Village, from April 1 – 4. 

Peter has gathered the shepherds and villagers (creative team and actors), but he needs the help of the People of Uruk (aka YOU!) to defeat the evil Humbaba (aka our budget).

Help us collect the valuable cedar trees guarded by Humbaba so that we can pay the shepherds and villagers for all their hard work!


The Quest for Gold

Musicals are expensive to create.  Epic musicals? We need all the gold in the ground and all the cedar trees in the forest!

Thanks to the team at Columbia Stages, we are able to cover the basics of producing the show – set, lighting, costumes, microphones, and, most importantly, a venue!

We need YOUR help to pay the amazing people that actually make the music! Our actors, our musicians, and our fabulous designers.

No-one is going to get rich from being in this musical.  In fact, with the maximum stipend being $300, no-one’s even going to be able to pay their rent! 

So we humbly ask that you donate to help show the people creating the magic that we appreciate the time, energy and enthusiasm that they have invested in Gilgamesh – A Musical Epic


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C9zTii5jPJA


The Team


Book and Lyrics: Peter Petkovsek
Composer: Ian Wehrle
Producer: Jenny Ainsworth  for Invisible Wall Productions

Musical Director: Ian Wehrle
Scenic Design: Kimie Nishikawa
Costume Design: Brynn Almli
Lighting Design: Yuki Nakase
Sound Design: Ian Wehrle
Graphic Design: Eva Mlinar
Production Stage Manager: Zhenghao "Z" Zhang
Stage Manager: Miranda Swineford
Assistant Stage Manager: Kirk Laing
General Manager: Invisible Wall Productions
Company Manager: Caolan Hunter

Cast:

Matthew Dunivan* - Gilgamesh
Ben Mulgrew - Enkidu
Khadija Sallet - Shamhat
Taryn Tonelli* - Ishtar
Carson Grant* - Narrator/Uta-napishti

Ensemble:
Ambar Aranaga, Elena Glass*, Justy Kosek, Mary Linehan*, Christopher Morriss, Jillian Schiralli, Zach Solomon, Viet Vo*

*Denotes member of Actor's Equity (Equity Showcase)

http://columbiastages.org/season/2015/ppetkovsek.html

story:
Collaboration of Movement, Fashion and Film

My name is Hillary Pearson and I am a dancer and choreographer based out of Philadelphia, PA. I recently received the opportunity to choreograph at my alma mater, Mason Gross School of the Arts, for their 2015 Fall Alumni Dance Concert. My dancers and I have been rehearsing since June, not only for the performance in September, but to take this piece - Exhibits of Numerical Items - beyond the limits of a "stage" and give it additional moveable life through film. Collaborating with New York based Director and Photographer, Casey Brooks and Philadelphia fashion designer, Bela Shehu of NINObrand - we are wanting to unite movement, fashion, and film into a conversation that will extend and develop beyond our creative ability and cause change within the way people process and precieve art.

http://ninobrand.com/  http://www.caseybrooks.com/

What We Need 

Since this project is a collaboration and each collaborator will benefit by means of experience and exposure, the money I am looking to raise is strictly for the amazing dancers who are making this project at all possible. We have 3 weeks until our performance at Rutgers University and a month of rehearsals before we go into production for the film. These amazing dancers: Nicolette Alberti, Shawn Brush, Stacy Collado, Mackenzie Connor, Caitlyn Farrell, Genna Mettana, Molly McGrath, and MariaTeresa Volpe have entrusted me with their time and bodies and deserve to be compensated greatly. Because of the generous stipend I received from MGSA, to be a part of the Alumni Dance Concert, I was able to pay the dancers for rehearsal time and travel expenses during the months of June and July. Now I need YOUR help in paying the dancers for rehearsal, travel, performances, and filming during the months of August and September. 

What Else You Can Do:

If you are unable to donate at this time, but are interested in this project and want to be a part of it in some capacity..........
  • You can spread the word about this project by posting/sharing this campaign on any or all of your social media accounts .
  • Buy a ticket and come to the Alumni Dance Concert at Rutgers University, Friday September 11th and Saturday September 12th at 7:30pm. Located in Loree Gymnasium 70 Lipman Drive Douglass Campus, New Brunswick, NJ. Also featuring choreographers: Robert Burke (Robert Mark Dance) and Kyle Georgina Marsh. 
  • Support the arts in general by going to see dance, art exhibits, fashion shows, concerts, theater, etc. - Congregate, Collaborate, Create.

story:
Our Story

Since its founding in 1999, Clinard Dance Theatre has produced five full works: Quest of Theseus, Shifting Landscapes, Jondo Portraits, Sueño Fuera Del Lugar: An Out of Place Dream, and premiering our newest project, From the Arctic to the Middle East: Broken Narratives by an American Flamenco Dance. Clinard Dance Theatre presents contemporary dance rooted in flamenco, created by collaborators from a diverse range of artistic disciplines and cultural backgrounds. At the center of each work, the company seeks to explore personal and global concerns, connecting the audience to the world through art.

The above video features selections from our most recent project, "From the Arctic to the Middle East: Broken Narratives by an American Flamenco Dancer." For our company’s next piece, which will begin its research phase this May, I have chosen the Chicago River as the principal metaphor for the new story I hope to tell. "The Chicago River is the city's most neglected natural resource. It is overshadowed by Lake Michigan, disdained by environmentalists and outdoorsmen alike, neglected, fouled, and abused by industry and all the rest of us. Nonetheless, it is the second greatest gift that nature has bestowed on this city," says Robert Cassidy. The quote above connects directly to what it is about flamenco that holds great meaning to me: that both flamenco and the river contain an ugly, raw, exasperated beauty; a kind of beauty that beacons the observer to seek the unobvious and welcome discomfort. To me, the Chicago River is not beautiful as an expansive view; It is beautiful by her various subtle sought out pictures that carry a history of man's interactions both commercial and design. Old metal remnants of defunct bridges, heron's nests, the frenetic movement of the city above and the bedrock below capture the mechanical, poetic and dramatic understandings I have taken from my life as a dancer/choreographer. I relate to the twists and folds of water likening them to the contractions and spirals that accompany the way I move. The pressures within my body from above and below are like the water sandwiched between air and rock. Being in a small boat on the river simulates the way breath works under my ribcage while dancing. Watching various vessels on the River is watching choreography between barges, speed boats, tour boats, kayakers and canoes.

During the Summer 2010 we likened our studio location at 18th and Halsted to the hub of a wheel. From this hub we made our way outward; north, south, east and west to share our art in our community parks. After researching the history of area parks I tried to make connections between the community, the natural landscapes and my artistic practices. Performance norms were challenged including: pre-show procession-like parading versus traditional marketing, discovering new technical innovations using light and sound, new interactions with an unexpecting public and translating movement and choreography into large and alive spaces. What I learned through these performances is that I became much more interested in finding the connections between my personal artistic practices versus transplanting a prefabricated performance that I created in the studio. The past 15 years have offered much growth in the traditional studio and theatre alike. At present I am curious about how these years of investigation, discipline and growth glean from outdoor, natural spaces and forces that are much larger, both figuratively and literally. I am not interested in outdoor spectacle as much as the understated dialogue between nature and dance. Also the witnessing public holds the potential to be trusted and active, as opposed to entertained.

Current ideas surrounding the Production Phase include finding an outdoor space (be it on the water or the river's bank) where the various natural occurrences allow an improvisatory component to each
performance. Examples are: Studying how the sun lights the space or how a rainstorm allows for a unique movement dialogue with that space. Each performance will intentionally strive to be different due to the elements while the performance space remains static. We hope that the initial parts collected integrate along the way to create a whole story about the Chicago River for our public and interconnected Midwest for the final Production Phase. It will be a story of renewal, a new path to tread on the river. The metaphor of the River is as much about nature as it is about humanity. And the rediscovery of the manifold way in which our lives can be shaped by the recovery of a sense of reverence for life and what we are part of.

What We Need and What You Get


The research phase of the project will focus on researching, exploring, and documenting the Chicago River, cataloguing various perspectives of the River ranging from architectural, design and stories/interviews from Chicagoans, visiting the River at various times of day and weather conditions. With the funds from this campaign, we propose to work with both an outdoor educator and a photographer/designer as I collect my findings. Later phases may require an architect, composer and corps of dancers. Both proposed colleagues offer critical strengths in setting this proposal into action. Charles Stark, Senior Instructor if the REI Outdoor School, offers a knowledge of the human and natural history of the Chicago River. Additionally, he would serve as principal engineer and boat/foot guide in mapping out routes and access points to scout along the river.


In the research phases photographer Laura Prieto- Velsco would photo journal moments in time and place that create dialogue between movement and the many natural occurrences of the river, such as changing light, weather conditions and seasons, all of which alter perception. An example of this came while I was kayaking on the river this summer—rain and shafts of sunlight penetrated an industrial
bridge; I wanted to join in with the rain as a mover and add to the geometry of the bridge with my body. Additionally Laura is a metal-smith and has a keen sense of design that support the intentions of our initial hunting. Through Phase One observations, my job will be to make connections and find patterns that will be carried into the Development Phase where I will work with translating these findings into proportion and rhythm; increment and spatial volume (both pictures that create harmony and horror). I will then try to participate within these frames as a mover or corps of movers to create choreographic links.

Other Ways You Can Help

Visit www.clinardance.org to find out about our other offerings, including upcoming performances, special events, and flamenco dance classes. You can help spread the word by sharing this fundraiser on your social media pages (facebook, twitter, etc.).

story:
Our Story


The West Village Musical Theatre Festival was created in 2010 as a way for emerging musical theatre artists to work with established professionals on an original musical theatre piece, and for audiences to get a sampling of new theatre that wouldn't cost them a lot in money or time.

 

Its mission is not only to provide emerging artists with a platform to produce their work, but to enrich the NYC West Village community by providing an annual theatre event local to the West Village.

 

What makes our festival so unique compared to other festivals is the “CD Track” format.  We present 18 new works in three separate "series", each series is a 90 minute performance consisting of six 10-15 minute one-act musicals - giving audiences a large variety of performances in one short sitting at the theatre, and taking the cost of producing a full length production off of the creative teams.

 


The Impact


A record number of industry including agents, producers, casting directors, and press attended a previously unknown musical theatre festival in June 2010.  We realized that the "CD track" festival format is very conducive to increasing industry attendance, which gets our festival pieces seen and produced in Off-Broadway and Broadway venues.  Many pieces from last year were picked up by big-time NYC producers and many careers got a huge jump start.

 

The West Village Musical Theatre Festival, in its second year, strives to provide even more career-building opportunities for emerging musical theatre professionals and high-quality work that is entertaining, innovative, and accessible for today's musical theatre audiences.

 


What We Need & What You Get


Every effort was made in 2010 to launch the festival and create a high caliber production on a shoestring budget.  This year, the West Village Musical Theatre Festival cannot happen without outside support.

 

In an effort to expand and provide more for our artists, we need hire more staff and buy more equipment to maintain the professional atmosphere of the festival.  Proper sound equipment, technical staff, musical directors, insurance, and theatre rental costs mean that the tab for producing musical theatre can add up very quickly.  

 

Here are some examples of our production expenses currently being paid out of pocket:

 

$100 pays for our required Fire Marshall training and certificate

$100 buys water and some snacks for the actors for the run

$250 will buy our gaff and spike tape, paint, and tools for the run

$450 allows us to transport equipment and pay our crew

$750 pays for promotional and marketing materials

$1000 purchases our playbills

$4000 pays stipends to all of our musical directors

$4500 pays for the theatre rental, insurance, and other equipment and space rentals

 

In our first year, 150 artists depended on us to provide a space and resources for their work.  Through your generous support, even more will be given a new resume credit, exposure to the press and industry, valuable artistic experience, and the exciting opportunity to bring a fresh and imaginative new work to the NYC stage.

 

Please see our gifts to you on the right for various levels of giving.



Other Ways You Can Help


Get the word out, send our page to your friends and colleagues using the share tools, and most importantly, come out and see us!

 

The 2011 West Village Musical Theatre Festival runs from June 8-12, 2011 at the

 

13th Street Repertory Theatre

50 W. 13th Street (between 5th and 6th Avenues) 

 

Performance schedule is below.  Tickets will be available on www.brownpapertickets.com.  See our website for a complete listing of each series at www.wvmtf.com.

 

Wednesday, June 8, 2011       

SERIES A: 5-6:30 pm

SERIES B: 7-8:30 pm

SERIES C: 9-10:30 pm

 

Thursday, June 9, 2011          

SERIES B: 5-6:30 pm

SERIES C: 7-8:30 pm

SERIES A: 9-10:30 PM

 

Friday, June 10, 2011             

SERIES C: 5-6:30 pm             

SERIES A: 7-8:30 pm

SERIES B: 9-10:30

 

Saturday, June 11, 2011         

SERIES B: 5-6:30 pm

SERIES A: 7-8:30 pm

SERIES C: 9-10:30 pm


Sunday, June 12, 2011           

SERIES A: 12-1:30 pm

SERIES B: 2-3:30 pm

SERIES C: 4-5:30 pm

story:
Help us get to the Fringe (and not starve!)

We are performer/devisers devoted to new works of hybrid, experimental, or otherwise envelope-pushingly awesome performance.  The "stage" is a place where magic happens and we're the magicians. We are Matthew-Bamberg Johnson, Genevieve Gearhart, and Alexis Macnab and boy do we have a show for you:

Gods, the exquisite short story by Vladimir Nabokov, is brought to life with movement and video in a poignant and personal retelling. A picture of grief, resilience, and  tragedy which opens our eyes to unspeakable beauty, the piece explores how we communicate when words are not enough.

We're taking this show to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe - the largest Arts festival on earth! But it ain't cheap to get there.  Support new performance and brave young artists! Be a part of the magic!

What We Need

Okay, theater isn't free. Espeically when it's international, multi-media theater.  We're going to need a lot of help on this one.  Here's what we're up against:

AIRFARE! - In case you haven't noticed, the Olympics are in London this year which means flying to GB this summer is just NUTZ! It's a steep ticket from sunny LA on a good day, and this year there just isn't a good day. Tickets for each of us are about $1400 EACH. No joke. Help!
MATERIALS! - Part of the plan this year is to travel as light as possible, but there are still some serious material costs that go into making theater magic happen. This piece uses TWO PROJECTION SCREENS which run about $100 a piece. Then there are frames to make for them and figuring out some way to get them overseas. Yikes!
POSTCARDS! - There are THOUSANDS of performances presented at the Fringe every year. How can we stand out? Having tons of beautiful POSTCARDS and POSTERS are a big help.  This isn't a huge expense, but it's very important. And the more we can afford, the better.  Full color ostcards run about $100 for the volume we need, and posters are about the same if we only get a few...
LIVING EXPENSES! - This, after airfare, is the big one. The Fringe is basically all of August and while we can probably sublet our LA apartments, we'll still have bills to pay back home, plus eating and houshold costs in Scotland. The US dollar doesn't go as far in GB as it does at home. Even modest items add up. Help!
 

Why YOU Should Give

We believe that live performance is both a powerful and necessary form of expression and we know great shows can change lives. With this piece we are trying something new, and through this challenge we hope to help push our art form into a new era and let its intertia take us along for the ride. This piece is not just theater, it's physical expression, visual storytelling, and imaginative laboratory.  It's a link in the evolution of performance from something presentational to something personal. Supporting this piece means supporting the courage and vision it takes to try new things, and to share those discoveries with the world.

But! If that doesn't float your boat, we can give you stuff too!  We have some lovely perks too offer if you like to keep mementos. :)

Last year, we successfully completed our campaign to support the CalArts shows at the Fringe. Help us go 2 for 2!  ART happens when you give!

Spread the word!

EVERY DOLLAR HELPS!  Really, that's true. But if you can't part with any green-backs these days you can still help us along.
 
STAY TUNED - We have a blog for the show:
http://godsatthefringe2012.blogspot.com
where we'll be posting updates, pictures, and videos along the way. Come along on our adventure and keep us (digitally) company!
 
COME TO THE SHOW!! - If you're going to be in Edinburgh in August - stop by!! We'd LOVE to see you!  If not, we're looking for performance opportunities in the Los Angeles area so keep your ears peeled for that news.

where we'll be posting updates, pictures, and videos along the way. Come along on our adventure and keep us (digitally) company!
 

COME TO THE SHOW!! - If you're going to be in Edinburgh in August - stop by!! We'd LOVE to see you!  If not, we're looking for performance opportunities in the Los Angeles area so keep your ears peeled for that news.

story:
We need your help taking Oddlie to Edinburgh Fringe!

We (Aleshea Harris and Ngaire Young) are taking Aleshea's show, Oddlie, to Fringe in the summer of 2012.  We are very proud that it was selected to represent California Institute of the Arts in Scotland.  Oddlie was conceived in Aleshea's hometown of St. Petersburg, FL.  With this show, Aleshea draws on her background as a songwriter, actor and poet to weave this provocative, gritty tale.  Ngaire supports this tale with expert percussion of drums and found instruments.

That's all well and nice, but what's so great about this show?

We believe Oddlie is an important work because it offers a perspective of a marginalized person not often seen in mainstream theatre.  It does this without relying on "tricks" or stereotypical interpretations.  Nope, Oddlie is honest, challenging work which we believe should be seen by as many people as possible.

Why should I dig into my pockets?

Unfortunately, neither of us is a wealthy heiress.  Or a wealthy anything, for that matter.  This is not a trip that we can afford on our own.  Your donations will keep us afloat and fed.

I suppose I can get behind that.  How much money we talkin'?

$5,000

What the-

We know.  In this economy, right?  Here's a break down of how much we need and where it's going:

Two round trip tickets from the U.S. to Scotland-3,000

Fees for housing/venue/etc for two people-2,000

Even if we don't make our goal, we'll split any monies we make between the two of us evenly and hope for the best. But. We will do so with heavy hearts.  You ever seen a poet or a musician with a heavy heart? Not. Pretty.

*Cough*perks?*cough, cough*

We're sooooo glad you asked. We've got CD's of Aleshea's and Ngaire's music, autographed posters, personalized postcards...all kinds of cool stuff to give to our supporters! 

You artist types are always trying to get money to make projects.  I need you to convince me this is worth investing in.

We have seen how this play affects people and that's what we're about-change via art. We know Oddlie is an important contribution to the global cultural landscape.  This isn't art for art's sake.  It's for people's sake.  And it's quality work.  Here are links to reviews:

http://orlandotheater.wordpress.com/2010/05/27/from-the-fringe-oddlie/

and

http://blogs.orlandosentinel.com/entertainment_stage_theat/2010/05/orlando-fringe-review-oddlie.html

How else can I help?

Whether or not you can make a donation, please spread the word about this campaign.  Post it on facebook, twitter, email it, myspace it-whatever.  Thanks.

story:
milk
apples
bananas
avocados
onions
potatoes
tomatoes
mushrooms
carrots and rabbit food for Peter
mince
bread
juice – you choose

If you can carry any more, get a chicken and two cans of beans. Don’t worry if you can’t, I can try and pick these up tomorrow.

Love,
Mum

Money on the counter. Don’t forget your key!


So begins the story of the relationship between a mother and her teenage daughter. Inspired by Alice Kuiper’s ‘novel in notes’, this first ever stage adaptation explores the themes of adolescence and family in a simple yet beautiful way. A coming of age story that is mundane, ridiculous and poignant. 


We are Director Amy Draper and Designer Ele Slade. We've worked together before on Angel Cake (Camden People's Theatre "More theatre like this please" remotegoat), The Door (The Park) and two workshops - Black Daisies for the Bride and Splinters (Ovalhouse). This, our biggest and boldest project so far, will allow us to collaborate from day 1 on a devised-design approach as we workshop the script alongside our performers and Lighting Designer Oscar Wyatt.

The Yard is a great, unusual space and we're really happy to have been invited to show this piece there as part of their exciting NOW 14 Collection: 

http://theyardtheatre.co.uk/show/n-o-w-14-week-9/

Our fundraising is going very well so far. We have just found out that we will receive our full Arts Council grant. This obviously means a lot to us and shows that the work we are doing is considered worthwhile. However, that's not the full story. This Indiegogo campaign forms an integral part of our fundraise, alongside ticket sales, and the £800 raised here will go directly towards the design budget and make our ideas possible.

We will be casting in late February, and will update here as soon as we have everything confirmed!

The aim is to produce a full length show that tells a great story. We want to make the audience laugh, cry, reminisce and have a memorable night out. We'd love you to be part of this and would be hugely grateful for every penny you can give or person you can share the information with. And we hope to see you at the show!


Thank you so much in advance.


www.amydraper.co.uk

www.elesladedesign.com

www.oscarwyatt.co.uk

story:
Help Bring Vital Theater to America.

The Bricklayers are creating an experience that many people from around the country can be a part of. As we tour this production of Don Juan we are tackling our responsibility as theatre makers to be active in the growth and change of the American theater scene specifically in places outside those theatrical meccas where audiences of all ages are not so easily presented with such fantastic and important opportunities.

Your contribution to our tour does not pay for costumes or sets or props (items which, as dedicated artists, we’ve funded ourselves) but for something far greater: the chance to challenge and inspire the people of the nation to be more artistic and active in their own communities. Your contribution will help us spread an understanding that the everyday can be reinvented and that the ordinary can be extraordinary and the extraordinary can be part of the everyday.

Your donation today is seminal.  Please join our mission to bring something beautiful, hilarious, and new to a community you’ve never dreamed of passing through. Give a child from Grand Portage the chance to sing and dance with a clown nose on. Buy a man from Wyoming his first theatrical experience. Be a part of our mission and help make the kind of grassroots difference that will be seminal in the artistic lives of American communities across the region.

                            

The Process

With Don Juan, we are expanding on our previous work of the French technique L’essential (transmitted to us by Paris based Company Collectif Masque), to include standard Commedia Dell’arte styles, British Pantomime sensibilities, and most importantly an incorporation of Boal’s Theater of The Oppressed. This immense hybridization of form has been another leap for the Bricklayers in their mission to create a mask theatre unique to American audiences.

The Production

Our production is a tantalizing examination of the rift between the haves and have-nots. Our modernization of the Moliere play focuses on Don Juan as a modern day 1% trust-fund baby (much like those on display at Rich Kids of Instigram) living a life of selfish comfort and ease. He’s a character spoiled by privilege and without empathy; who only hopes to spend the rest of his life in frivolous pursuit of the next pleasure. When his father cuts him off, Don Juan is sent into a tailspin, his selfishness, greed, and knack for depravity spiral out of control destroying the stability of those around him, who lack the means to survive such a malignant squall. 

The Bricklayers’ production of Don Juan comically focuses on the trickle down disparity between the American classes and the next generation’s errant disregard for fellow man, by posing the question:

Is the behavior of Don Juan acceptable, and if not, HOW DO WE STOP IT? (a question directly answered by the audience themselves at the end of every performance.)

The Team

The core Creative Team of this project, Kyle Cadotte and Matt Trucano (founding members of The Bricklayer’s Theatre Company), are pleased to work for the first time with Jonathan Greene (independent theater artist) and to once again be working with artistic advisor Barbra Berlovitz (co-founder and co-artistic director of the Tony Award winning Theatre de la Juene Lune (1975-2008) and costume designer Sonya Berlovitz (who designed over 50 productions for the Theatre de la Jeune Lune and has also designed for Berkeley Repertory Theatre, Playmakers Repertory Company, Children’s Theater Company, The New Victory Theatre, The Guthrie Theater, American Repertory Theatre, La Jolla Playhouse and Actors Theatre of Louisville).

 

Donate Today!  Remember to share the link to our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, etc.

 

THANK YOU!

story:
605 Collective - Sharing Dance Abroad
UPDATE: We've hit our goal, and made it to New York, and performed on the City Centre stage to a sold out house of 2700 people each night. A huge thank-you to all who have helped make this possible for us. The goal has been reached, but every dollar raised beyond helps us now make the most of our Canadian touring in 2013/14, affording flights and hotels, (from Prince Edward Island in November to Whitehorse in the Yukon in February), and of course, getting in extra rehearsal time to prep some great shows!  We are so grateful for your support. Thank-You!
__________________________________________________________________
605 Collective (605) is one of Canada's fastest rising dance companies. The artists' premiere performance took place in 2009 at the Dancing On The Edge Festival in Vancouver BC, and just four years later, 605 has grown into a high-caliber and sought-after company, touring extensively throughout Canada and into the US at some of North America's most prominent dance venues and festivals. 

605 has now received an invitation to perform its newest work at the 10th Anniversary edition of Fall For Dance Festival (FFD), hosted by the prestigious New York City Centre in Manhattan. This incredible opportunity marks 605's NYC debut, and its largest venue to date, performing for over 2700 attendees each night. This year, 605 Collective is one of 20 companies invited from around the world, sharing the stage with the likes of Doug Elkins, The Royal Ballet, Sidi Larbi Cherkaoui, Alvin Ailey, and Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo. FFD is a major platform for showcasing both rising choreographers and legends of contemporary dance. 605 stands to gain tremendous exposure from this engagement, opening new doors that may support future creation projects, and launching the company forward with new international touring opportunities.  

Directly following FFD, the company prepares for its next major Canadian tour, continuing to help build dance audiences in remote communities on the Made In BC: Dance on Tour network, as well as performing in larger venues in Eastern Canada (see dates below). As a non-for-profit organization, part of our mandate is to bring dance to anyone and everyone, sharing our work with as broad an audience as possible, and we need your help to keep expanding our reach. 

What We Need & What You Get:

We need to raise over $2500 to assist with the company's Fall 2013 travel expenses, which include costs for flights and ground transport, extra baggage and shipment for costumes, set pieces, and equipment, and hotel accommodation for 8 travelling company members in each of the visited cities:

605 Collective Fall 2013 Touring Dates:
September 27th - 28th, 2013 - Fall For Dance Festival, New York City Center, NYC
October 20th, 2013 - Dance Allsorts, Roundhouse Community Centre, Vancouver, BC
Oct 21st-24th, 2013 - Outreach/Community Engagement Residency in Golden, BC
October 25th, 2013 - Kicking Horse Culture, Golden BC
October 30th, 2013 - Mount Elizabeth Theatre, Kitimat, BC
November 2nd, 2013 - Lester Centre for the Arts, Prince Rupert, BC
November 9th, 2013 - Crimson Coast Dance, The Port Theatre, Nanaimo, BC
November 14th - 16th, 2013 - DanceWorks, Enwave Theatre, Toronto, ON
November 20th - 23rd, 2013 - Shadbolt Centre for the Arts, Burnaby, BC
November 30th, 2013 - Harbourfront Theatre, Summerside, PEI
December 5th - 7th, 2013 - Live Art Dance, Sir James Dunn Theatre, Halifax, NS

Travelling from coast to coast is expensive for our young company, and costs can add up very quickly. Every dollar raised makes a difference, and your support will help us pull it off. 

About the Perks:

  • An 8x10 Print of 605 Collective - Choose from one of three photos taken of the company's dancers in action by dance photographer extraordinaire David Cooper. (Please See Gallery for Options) Photo can be signed, or left unsigned, and delivered by Mail to specified address.
  • Complimentary Tickets to a 605 performance - Claimants can chose from any of the above dates/cities listed, with the tickets (general seating) available at the box office for pick-up under specified name. 

For "The Big Apple" Perk Only:

  • Post-Show "Meet The Artists" - Stick around after the performance and meet 605's dancers and crew for a personal thank-you. Ask questions, and learn about the 605's creation process and "behind-the-scenes" of a dance performance.  
  • Can't make it to a show? Rather than tickets, receive a DVD of Archival Performance Footage from one of 605's live dance productions to watch whenever you'd like.

605 Collective has a proven track record of successfully touring and performing its energetic work, reaching thousands of people in 34 cities across Canada/USA with a countless number of shows. By giving to this cause you are helping these young artists take full advantage of their largest opportunity to date. If we are successful beyond our goal with this campaign, all additional funds will be put towards future touring and dissemination. 

All young dancers and choreographers have a goal of sharing their work on a big and beautiful stage, in front of a large audience, and in a cultural hub like New York - you can help us make this a reality. 

Other Ways To Support 605:

"Start Spreadin' The News....!"  If you're unable to contribute financially, you can still be a part of it:

  • Help get the word out and make some noise about our campaign! You can easily share a link to this page with friends and fellow dance-lovers from your Facebook/Twitter accounts or a with personal email. 
  • Simply "Like" 605's Facebook Page, and invite others to join, so you can stay up-to-date with all of 605's ongoing activity and performances. 
  • Come attend one of our shows and bring your friends. Dance is a powerful, ephemeral experience best taken in live. We'd love to see you in our audience.

Thank-you for helping us achieve our goal!

story:
Doreen Brownstone, Gislina Patterson, Arne MacPherson and Daniel Thau-Eleff are hard at work in the studio, rehearsing Judith Thompson's Such Creatures. Come see us January 2nd - 5th, at the Colin Jackson Studio Theatre at Prairie Theatre Exchange, 3rd floor of Portage Place.

85-year-old Sorele goes back to Auschwitz. 15-year-old Blandy waits in a park for the fight of her life. A story of love, hate, strength and hope, as two women come face to face with monsters.

Winnipeg's senior professional actor, Doreen Brownstone acted in the first show at Manitoba Theatre Centre in 1958 and has received numerous lifetime achievement awards. Gislina Patterson is a young actor who adapted and performed in Fringe-hit The Tracey Fragments. Arne MacPherson has directed with many of Winnipeg's theatre companies, most recently, indy hit The Walworth Farce. Daniel Thau-Eleff is known to Winnipeggers for his playwriting, including Remember the Night. 

We are thrilled to be bringing together this exciting creative team, rounded out by designers Jeremy Rampton and Jaymez to tackle Judith Thompson's intense, captivating play.

Such Creatures is receiving support from the Manitoba Arts Council and we are only $2,000 away from meeting our budget. We hope you will be able to help us make this project a reality and we look forward to seeing you at the show!

story:
Who We Are:

5OneDeuce improv is Producing a comedic "Main Event" that includes some of the biggest names in Los Angeles improv slated for performance. Were looking to provide this series in a timely fashion and to book bigger and better partner groups to give the audience the best show in the area. Participating makes YOU apart of our community for a lifetime and gives plenty of returned perks including shirts, free tickets, updated show information, tickets to future shows, exclusive backstage access to meet the cast, and plenty more to make you apart of our community. 

 

Barriers To Entry:

The challenges to produce an improv showcase are locations. Certain groups are supported by their "main titled" school of training and have no capability to branch to every avenue of improv. Our answer, 5OneDeuce improv varies its venues on a monthly basis to give its audience and supporters the choices between venues and styles through our locations throughout California.

 

Our Packages:

5OneDeuce Improv provides a variety of donation sources to give everyone the chance to participate. From "Donor" packages that offer minimal donations to our many "Producer" packages that offer the ability to support us beyond this Main Event Show to continue to many more Main Event Showcases in a variety of theaters around Los Angeles and California.
story_txt:
Who We Are:
5OneDeuce improv is Producing a comedic "Main Event" that includes some of the biggest names in Los Angeles improv slated for performance. Were looking to provide this series in a timely fashion and to book bigger and better partner groups to give the audience the best show in the area. Participating makes YOU apart of our community for a lifetime and gives plenty of returned perks including shirts, free tickets, updated show information, tickets to future shows, exclusive backstage access to meet the cast, and plenty more to make you apart of our community. 
 
Barriers To Entry:
The challenges to produce an improv showcase are locations. Certain groups are supported by their "main titled" school of training and have no capability to branch to every avenue of improv. Our answer, 5OneDeuce improv varies its venues on a monthly basis to give its audience and supporters the choices between venues and styles through our locations throughout California.
 
Our Packages:
5OneDeuce Improv provides a variety of donation sources to give everyone the chance to participate. From "Donor" packages that offer minimal donations to our many "Producer" packages that offer the ability to support us beyond this Main Event Show to continue to many more Main Event Showcases in a variety of theaters around Los Angeles and California.

story:
Short Summary

Hi, my name is Naomi and I am 12 years old. I have been dancing since I was three, and have attended 2 other dance intensives previous to this upcoming summer. I want to become a professional dancer when I grow up, and take every opportunity I can to improve and enhance my dancing and technique. This year, I auditioned for Joffrey Ballet School's summer intensive, and was accepted with a 75% scholarship to attend for 5 full weeks. I know that this intensive is in fact intense and will give me all of the dance training I am hoping to gain this summer, plus some. Additionally, I am paying only $1,500 or so for something that would cost me upwards of $5,000.  I want to take full advantage of this fortuity, and therefore, have decided to attend. 

What We Need & What You Get

I need $1000 in donations in order to go to Joffrey. My mother is offering to donate $600 towards the total.

  • 900 dollars for fees and tuition
  • 400 for dance uniforms and shoes
  • 300 for miscellaneous: food, field trips
- If you donate $10, you will receive an e-mail
- If you donate $20, you will receive a card
- If you donate $50, you will receive a 3-pack of origamis
- If you donate $100, you will receive a poem


The Impact

I, as you may know, will be dancing all day, Monday-Friday for 5 weeks. This means that I will receive 200 hours worth of training. It is inevitable that I will improve tremendously after JBS. Additionally, I would like to primarily focus on ballet for the remainder of time that I pursue dance. Because this camp is a ballet intensive, and my first ballet intensive, I will get the exact training that I am hoping for. 

There are certain attributes that dancers have to cultivate: persistence being one of them so that you can make a difficult, strenuous task look easy. As a ballerina, It is so important to attempt to perfect your craft, despite always knowing that you you will never be perfect.

Even if you decide not to dance anymore, it makes you a better person. I love to dance, and though it is a major commitment, the end product is so satisfying to me.

Risks & Challenges 

I can not raise the money I need without help from others. I appreciate whatever I can get, whether it be a penny or $500. 

Other Ways You Can Help 

I completely understand if you can not contribute, but please try and spread the word and make some noise about my campaign. Thanks!

story:
The Chasse-Galerie

Our Story:

Many moons ago, the good folks at The Red One Theatre Collective came up with the grand idea of bringing the famous French Canadian folk-tale La Chasse Galerie to life at our sometime home The Storefront Theatre at 955 Bloor St., West.  With no more than a desire to create a holiday show that we might present annually, the idea for the story grew and grew, and now we are about to present the first incarnation of this tale—created by the members of the collective and featuring an original score by the enormously talented composer James Smith. 

The story of The Chasse-Galerie is as old as the province of Quebec.  In our version, four young Coureurs de Bois (Kat Letwin, Dana Puddicombe, Tess Benger and Shaina Silver-Baird) are trapped deep in the woods of Quebec on a very cold and lonesome New Year's Eve.  Wishing they were back in Montreal to celebrate with their loved ones, they strike up a deal with the Devil himself, who promises to fly them back to Montreal in their Canoe for one night only on the condition they refrain from Blasphemy (All the choicest Quebecois swear words are Blasphemous!)  If they break their promise, the Devil will take their souls.  The heroes take the Devil's deal, but the Prince of Darkness is a wily customer.  The winter nights are long and in the Chasse Galerie anything can happen.

Your generous support for this project will help with the cost of renting our venue, providing musical equipment, lights, costumes, and marketing materials. Most importantly however, your dollars will go toward the creation of an original play which we hope to bring back to our audiences in the years to come!

Come check us out Dec 17-31 (no shows Dec 23-27) at 8pm at The Storefront Theatre, 955 Bloor St. W., Toronto! 

For more information please visit  http://thestorefronttheatre.com/

The Red One Theatre Collective has assembled an amazing team of artists to bring this production to life.  

Our Cast:

Our Cast (in Order Left to Right)

Kat Letwin, Dana Puddicombe, Shaina Silver-Baird, Vanessa Salazar, Tess Benger, Jonah Widdifield, Michael Cox, Ryan Field, Sam al-Esai, James Smith, Daniel Briere.

Our Creative Team

Director: Tyrone Savage

Tyrone is an actor, director and founding member of the Red One Theatre Collective. Past directing credits for Red One include: Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? and Shrew. 

Composer and Musical Director: James Smith

James is a multi-talented Composer, Conductor, and Band Leader, he has worked at the Charlottetown Festival, Sheridan College, The Shaw Festival, and with Outside the March. Recent credits include: Brantwood, Mr. Burns: A Post-Electric Play, London Road, and Assassins. 

Puppeteer: Daniel Briere

Daniel Briere is an actor, director, and Puppeteer. Recent Credits include seasons at the Stratford Festival: Romeo and Juliet, King John, and Diary of Anne Frank.  He is also the Associate Director of Dutch Uncle Puppetry 

Dramaturg: Emma Mackenzie Hillier

Emma Mackenzie Hillier is the Resident Dramaturg at the Storefront Theatre and also freelances. Recent credits include: This Is Where We Live (Discord and Din), He Left Quietly (Theatre Heteratae). She recently completed training in new play development at the Stratford Festival under mentor Bob White.

Costumes: Holly Lloyd

Costume Design: Sexy Laundry, Last Chance Romance; Look, No Hans! (Drayton Entertainment); Liver (The Slab Collective); Dangerous Liaisons, Human Furniture, Shrew (Red One Theatre Collective); Retreat,  Punch Up (Theatre Brouhaha); Much Ado About Nothing (Single Thread Theatre Co.); Cockfight (Red One Theatre Collective/Theatre Brouhaha Co-production); Alice in Wonderland (City Youth Players)

Lighting Designer: Melissa Joakim

Melissa has worked extensively with The Storefront Theatre and Red One. Including Shrew, Wait Until Dark, and Edmond

Set Designer: Bronwen Lily


Stage Manager: Lin-Mei Lay


Here's what we need:

The Red One Theatre Collective is asking for $7000 to help mount our production and help cover the costs of putting on this epic production. Our budget breakdown is as follows:

-$4000 Venue rental

-$1000 Rehearsal space rental

-$1500 Budgets for our Musical Director, Costumer, Lighting Designer, and Puppeteer

-$500 Publicity and Marketing, including posters, programs and flyers


Check out our Perks page for all the exciting gifts the folks at Chasse Galerie will send you in exchange for your generous donation.


The Red One Theatre Collective has always been dedicated to creating original and exciting work in the spaces and neighbourhoods around our city that are often neglected by the arts community at large. Our mission is to bring theatre onto our neighbours' front doorstep. We are engaged with our community and dedicated to creating theatre beyond the conventional. Our most important resource is YOU, our supporters. If you've seen our work before, then you know we have only thrived through the constant and loving support of those who believe in what we do. Even if you can't help us today, please spread the word about our show to your friends and family and help make Red One Theatre Collective the best theatre company in the city of Toronto.

story:
My name is Lissette Napoleoni and I've owned the Neon Venus Art Theatre in Las Vegas for four years (2008-2012) and the same venue at 7023 Melrose Ave, Los Angeles, CA, for the past six years, where I have been the sole owner for the past two years and a half. Here's my bio, as well as a statement on the reason why I own a venue: http://www.neonvenusarttheatre.com/new-page-1/

Unfortunately the company who owns the building housing our current performance space  is looking to do other things with it, and we are being forced to move. In order to move and so that we might continue supporting the performers in our community, we need your help.  We thank you in advance for reading about our campaign, further details below! 

  • Due to circumstances beyond our control, we must move our theater to another location, and we're looking to raise funds to assist with the moving expenses.
  • We have been supporting actors, writers and musicians in Las Vegas and Los Angeles helping them improve, and hone their skills by providing them a place to develop and showcase their talents. These men and women are the film and TV artists of the future. Check out our 'gallery' section in this indiegogo page to see pics of current and past shows.
  • Many of the artists we've had the pleasure to collaborate with in the past, have gone on to book commercials and guest appearances in roles on TV.  
  • We also offer classes and sponsor events for local screenwriters and directors, including (click on links for reviews)
Film-making and Screenings in Hollywood
Film Production Workshop Hollywood


What We Need 

We are estimating the total funds we need to raise at $9,900.  This figure includes moving costs and the deposit on the new location, and the cost of our Indiegogo campaign.  The estimate is based on the cost of a few spaces we've investigated in the area, including a space in which we've already expressed an interest.  This place is really close to our current location; if we land it, we would only need to move our current shows and acting classes fewer than five minutes away from our current location.  To take a look at our shows, check out our calendar:  http://www.neonvenusarttheatre.com.  We specialize in comedy events:  stand up, Improv and sketch comedy.  However, from time to time we also do music events, film screenings and screenwriting classes. Take a look at our gallery to see past and present shows/events in action! 


What You Get 

  • Contributions over $300:  Everyone who contributes over $300 to our move will get Producer credit. That mean's their name will be included in a special commemorative plaque or artistic installment on one of the walls in our new location; this commemoration will be entitled 'The Producers'.  What's more, you will get free admission to TWO EVENTS per month for TWO YEARS! (The exception to this is private parties or events put together by producers who rent from us.) You will also be invited to, and celebrated at, our opening gala, and included in a short tribute video that we will share on our website. Speaking of our website, you'll also get an honorable mention there in a special area dedicated to 'Theatre Donors'. 
  • Contributions over $100:   Actors contributing more than a $100 will get deals on daytime rentals for one entire year; deals of up to half off the regular rental price.  What that means is that weekend daytime rates will be $10 per hour (instead of our regular $20/hour),  and weekdays will only cost you $7 per hour (instead of our regular $15/hour).  This special offer will be limited to 2 hours per week, so that we are sure we'll earn enough money to cover our ongoing, monthly rental expenses.
  • Contributions over $50:  Anyone who helps by donating $50 dollars will be thanked on our current website.
  • In the event we don't manage to reach our goal and we are unable to move, the money will be returned to you, less the Indiegogo fee which is nine percent.

The Impact

    Culturally speaking, we have been helping to create a little bit of magic in our community for nearly seven years, and we'd love to continue doing so. You can read a few of the articles that have been written about us below:

    LA's Booming Indie Improv Scene

    At the Neon Venus, Art is Life and Life is a Party

    Neon of a Different Kind

Risks & Challenges

 We realize that  we may not be able to reach our goal, in which case we’re ready to return all the monies to everyone who tried to help us see our vision through.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please, get the word out!  You can help by sharing links to our campaign on your Facebook wall, on Twitter, on Instagram and Pinterest. Anywhere that might attract someone's eye and encourage them to give their support.

story:
Infinity Box Theatre Project: creating a space where shared theatrical experience leads to sustainable conversations about the impact of science and technology in our lives.

At Infinity Box Theatre Project we believe that the fundamental question of this century will be “What does it mean to be human?”

Each year’s Thought Experiments on the Question of Being Human presents an evening of original plays that explores how discoveries and innovations at – and just ahead of – the cutting edge of science and technology may fundamentally affect our lives. 

More importantly, however, each evening of plays is followed by a conversation in which the audience can respond to the issues raised in the plays.  As Cady Stanton, one of our scientists from 2013 Thought Experiments said:

     "What the play gave to the conversation was realism, an emotional component....You can talk about something all you want, but people don’t understand until they also feel and experience it."

This year’s annual Thought Experiments on the Question of Being Human: Genetics and Synthetic Biology will present four plays by local playwrights who have collaborated with four local scientists to ask these fundamental questions about what it means to be human—and we are asking for your help to fund the Experiments.

We need to raise $1,000 for rent and to publish the scripts.  We distributed scripts for the last two years to local libraries (and they are also in the Washington State Time Capsule, to be opened in 2389).  Please help us continue that tradition and sustain the conversations about these important question beyond the run of the plays.  And as our way of thanking you, please accept one of the perks listed on the right.

Thank you for helping us save the world through science and theatre!

Thought Experiments opens on Thursday, October 15th at the Ethnic Cultural Theatre, University of Washington and plays through October 18th. 

Our playwright/scientist pairs are:

“Editors” by Holly Arsenault, teamed with scientist Andrew Scharenberg, directed by Susanna Burney

"Frivolous Natura" by Kelly Mak, teamed with scientist Eric Klavins, directed by Roy Arauz

"Anomie," by Courtney Meaker, teamed with scientist Rob Carlson, directed by Teresa Thuman

"Solace," by Bryan Willis, teamed with scientist Jennifer Nemhauser, directed by Tyrone Brown.
