story:
Short Summary

Angel City is a classic and genius play by Sam Shepard being mounted at USC as an independent student production. Once again, Shepard deals with the landscape of American mythology this time with the greatest American myth of all: Hollywood. A young stuntman is hired by a movie producer to save his $8 million dollar picture from disaster by turning it into a disaster movie. The stuntman tries to maintain his own integrity, but comes to realize that he is more a part of the Great American Dream Machine than he had ever known.

"An evening of surrealist high jinks with serious perceptions underneath.... It is his most playful work, and one of his most accessible." - Village Voice 

"A condemnation of Hollywood and of America's preoccupation with the movies." - Chicago Reader

What We Need & What You Get

  • Sam Shepard plays are extremely lighting heavy. We would like to purchase or rent the best lights we can with our budget and still have enough for building the minimalist set.
  • We have a variety of perks ranging from a "thank you" email from our director to a pair of tickets to the show!
  • If we do not happen to reach our entire goal, the funds raised will still go toward purchasing lights and other elements of the set. 

The Impact

Although USC students have a great love of theatre and the arts, it is difficult for students to mount shows without the proper funding. We are a small group of students wanting to perform one of Sam Shepard's greatest plays as it was meant to be performed.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute right now, that's ok! Come and see the show in the Massman Theater at USC, October 8-11. There is a suggested contribution of $5 at the door.

A young stuntman is hired by a movie producer to save his $8 million dollar picture from disaster by turning it into a disaster movie. The stuntman tries to maintain his own integrity, but comes to realize that he is more a part of the Great American Dream Machine than he had ever known."An evening of surrealist high jinks with serious perceptions underneath.... It is his most playful work, and one of his most accessible." - Village Voice "A condemnation of Hollywood and of America's preoccupation with the movies." - Chicago Reader   What We Need & What You Get  Sam Shepard plays are extremely lighting heavy. We would like to purchase or rent the best lights we can with our budget and still have enough for building the minimalist set. We have a variety of perks ranging from a "thank you" email from our director to a pair of tickets to the show! If we do not happen to reach our entire goal, the funds raised will still go toward purchasing lights and other elements of the set.     The Impact Although USC students have a great love of theatre and the arts, it is difficult for students to mount shows without the proper funding. We are a small group of students wanting to perform one of Sam Shepard's greatest plays as it was meant to be performed.

    Other Ways You Can Help If you can't contribute right now, that's ok! Come and see the show in the Massman Theater at USC, October 8-11. There is a suggested contribution of $5 at the door.

story:
THE SHOW

CAFÉ SARAJEVO is an immersive performance exploring borders that divide and unite us, within the framework of a live podcast. The piece is created and performed by Mariel Marshall, Peter Musante, Lucy Simic and Stephen O’Connell and with stage manager Lisa Humber, creative technologist Jacob Niedzwiecki, and lighting designer Patrick Lavender.

CAFÉ SARAJEVO follows Lucy on a journey of self-discovery, as she travels to her father’s birthplace, Bosnia. Along the way, we explore divided cities and the notion of “human nature”, asking the question: what causes a nation to divide, and begin to hate the very people and culture who, before the dividing lines were drawn, they saw as their own?

 

THE OPPORTUNITY

bluemouth has been confirmed to present CAFE SARAJEVO at both the M1 Singapore Fringe Festival in Singapore this coming January and in Toronto in February.

We need your help raising $4,000usd to help cover the cost of renting mobile devices to provide 360 video content we shot on Sarajevo. We can’t realize this project without your help! All donations over $25 are eligible for a tax receipt (available upon request!)

 

M1 SINGAPORE FRINGE FESTIVAL

The M1 Singapore Fringe Festival (M1 Festival) is an annual festival of theatre, dance, music, visual arts and mixed media created and presented by Singaporeans and international artists. The festival brings the best of contemporary, cutting-edge and socially engaged works to the Singapore audience.

http://www.singaporefringe.com/fringe2020

 

TORONTO

North American premier to be announced soon!!!

 

THE COLLECTIVE

bluemouth collectively creates immersive site-specific performances by marrying choreographed movement, text, immersive sound design, original live music, video, and film to create a cohesive, multi-sensory experience. The various themes of our original performances are multi-layered and strive to be a vital witness to our particular time and place while challenging and exploring new levels of interaction between performers and audiences.

We ask our audience,

“WHAT LEVEL OF EXPERIENCE ARE YOU COMMITTED TO HAVING?”

www.bluemouthinc.com

 

 

The Impact

Your contribution will make a huge difference in ensuring that we realize our vision of this show and that no one personally goes into debt in the process.

  • bluemouth has successfully toured two international shows, DANCE MARATHON and PARTY GAME.
  • This is the first time we are bringing our work to Asia.

 

Challenges

All involved in this show have donated time and made financial sacrifices to help make this show and to ensure that this opportunity happens.

  • We have exhausted every possible granting body and this is our last resort and chance for support.
  • Through the generous support of both festivals, we have met 95% of our fundraising goals.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools to help us spread the word!

story:
The Cello of Mr. O, a stunning multidisciplinary performance for all ages!

Think of all the children whose lives have been destroyed by war. Life under siege. Shops, cars, apartments, parks have been demolished. There is no water or electricity -- and food is scarce. 

“'This is not the first time in history that such a thing has happened’, Mama tells me. No, I say..... but it is the first time it has happened to me.”

The Cello of Mr. O is told from the heartbreaking perspective of a twelve-year-old girl, transported from a normal childhood into one altered by the grist of combat. 

We take the journey she takes, every time we experience this powerful and redemptive multi-media performance produced by suddenlyLISTEN Music

The Cello of Mr. O was originally a performance duet featuring Karen Bassett, as the girl, and Symphony Nova Scotia Principal Cellist Norman Adams playing the spirit of Mr. O. The power and beauty of the storytelling comes from weaving projected images by accomplished sound and media artist Lukas Pearse, a haunting sound score created by groundbreaking composer/sound artist Steven Naylor and the beautiful cello music of the incomparable J.S. Bach. 

Originally produced as a 24-minute work for young audiences, it faithfully represented the timeline and characters of the original book, and although it was very well-received critically and by its young audiences, everyone knew there was the potential to do more with this timeless story. 

Industry experts and theatre presenters told us that a longer work would fill full-evening time slots in dozens of communities, with the potential to attract a broader family and interdisciplinary arts demographic - in other words, to go on tour! 

You can help us do this! We have enlisted Halifax dancer/choreographer Jacinte Armstrong to work with the original team to double the length of the performance, adding movement and more of the stunning sound, music and visual projections that were so loved in the original project. With your help, we will transform The Cello of Mr. O into a full-length performance that can transport and engage young and older people across the country and internationally.

You won't be doing this alone! We have already secured enough project funding from Arts Nova Scotia to start the process (thanks Arts NS!) but we need your help to finish the work ahead. A few of our closest supporters and friends have said they're ready to contribute, and they can't wait to see who else is willing to step up as leaders in supporting this innovative artistic project guaranteed to touch the hearts of everyone who sees it. This can be you!


What We Need & What You Get

The Breakdown: 

All we need is $6,000 to pay professional fees to our award-winning talent for the hundreds of hours of work everyone is putting into this project. Our choreographer Jacinte, our lead actor Karen, our sonic artists Norman and Steven, and our media magician Lukas -- we are all already underway with the creative explosions and distillations needed to weave the new story and sensory elements together in the way we have already shown that audiences will love. THEN we will premiere the completely reworked project, and actually pay the artists for that too!

What you get:

Our eternal thanks, of course. And the delight that comes from supporting the creation of original work. But you can also opt to receive any number of special perks and rewards for participating too. T-shirts, buttons, tickets, and the power of music!

The Impact

At the most fundamental level, The Cello of Mr. O is about the power of music itself. The power to inspire, to unite and to challenge us. It is also about how art itself feeds us, when days are dark, and humanity is at its most desperate. When we witness Mr. O's courageous act and its transformative impact on the young girl (weren't we all just like her once?), we see art not as a luxury, but as a necessity of the human soul.

suddenlyLISTEN Music has presented concerts, tours, and performance projects since 2000. The Cello of Mr. O is our first giant step into the world of theatre and multi-media performance, and we believe in the project and its themes so much that we have committed to getting this done this year, as soon as this funding goal is achieved.

Please help us to spread the message of peace, hope and the power of music that this inspiring story has already given to its readers and its audiences!

Risks & Challenges

The only risk we face is not being able to offer a fair wage to the creative people involved in this project, if we don't meet our goal. There isn't a risk to you. But suddenlyLISTEN doesn't like to take advantage of artists who already work hard to make things happen for everyone in the community.

Even when we reach our goal, no one will get rich from this project. You can imagine how much time goes into a complex creative process like this one -- and how dedicated our artists have already proven to be. But everyone has already (and will continue to) contributed time, in-kind services, practices, ideas, help with fundraising, and in so many ways. If we go over our goal, we will be able to develop promotional materials, benefit from more rehearsal time, maybe even think about recording something.

Other Ways You Can Help

No matter how much you are able to give financially, there is much more you can do, if you want to:

  • Do your friends and colleagues like music and theatre? Share word of this campaign - on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and your own website! It's easy to share the links below with your friends and encourage them to match you in your donation! 
  • Do you believe in the arts? We must cast a wide net to realize success, and YOU are our net, line and sinker. Ask your families to join us in making the story of this -- and every -- twelve-year-old girl, and the courageous musician who helped her, understand the devastating residue of war, and how to move beyond it.

story:
The MTA is a fantastic place to learn all about Musical Theater and hone your skills to become industry ready. I've been given a fantastic opportunity to expand my life and I want nothing more than to do so!

Unfortunately I haven't the means to be able to go. So what the heck, why not give this a go! You hear fantastic stories about these sites so I really hope this will be my golden ticket!

The money I need to raise is around £30,000, I'd like to explain how that money will be used.

- £14,000 a year for tuition.

-£2,000 to help me find a flat and see me through until I can find a job and live for myself

The course it's self is a two year course and unfortunately, because the course is so intense they can not be affiliated with the correct faculties to allow for student loans or DaDA's

This means I have no help with my cost of living and so I have turned here in the hope that, with your aid, I will be able to go and do what I love.

story:
A young man was shot down and killed in front of my church in Edgewater. This is a common experience for many teenage youth. Between 1979 and 2010, more children and teens died from guns (119,079) than U.S. soldiers in the wars in Vietnam, Korea, Iraq and Afghanistan combined.xvi In a study of 23 high-income nations, 87 percent of children under age 15 killed by guns lived in the United States.  The same study found that the gun homicide rate for teens and young adults in the U.S. ages 15-24 was 42.7 higher than in the other high-income countries combined. 

Epworth United Methodist Church has received a grant of $1,500 and we would like to match that so we can offer three free performances of the play Bang Bang You're Dead at Epworth. The play addresses a shooter who kills his friends and family and is confronted by those he killed.

Playwright and Screen Writer William Mastrosimone wrote this play for his son after Columbine Massacre. It has been performed all over the world. Mr. Mastrosimone has heard from many youth who considered being shooters and have sought help as  a result of seeing this play.

After each performance there will be a discussion of violence in our society by the Director, Cast, and Audience members.

I would appreciate your support.

Thanks Jerry Miller

story:
Summary

Kerry is a playwright, lyricist, book writer, and screenwriter living in Los Angeles. He writes character-driven plays that frequently contain the theme of people attempting, and often failing, to communicate and connect with each other. Tanya is a producer and actor, who feels that Wounded is an extremely important piece about identity and fighting for a sense of normalcy in a world where the definition of "normal" is shaky. 

We've received a grant from the theatre company Fierce Backbone to bring Kerry's piece, Wounded, to the Hollywood Fringe Festival in 2018. We're hoping that our friends, our family, and art lovers all over the world can help us make up the difference so that we can put up this wonderful show. 

Here are the dates we currently have for the show:

  • Preview - Sunday, 6/3, 11:45am
  • Friday, 6/8, 7:45pm 
  • Monday, 6/11, 9:45pm
  • Sunday, 6/17, 7:45pm - Kerry's birthday!!
  • Saturday, 6/23, 3:45pm

By contributing to Wounded, you'll help us pay for our venue, pay our actors and director, cover our complex makeup, and bring this piece to life for the audience.

What We Need & What You Get

Here's how it breaks down:

  • Our total budget is $4,500. Fierce Backbone has given us $1,000. We need your help to secure our location: The Lounge Theatre in Hollywood; pay our artists and collaborators; put together a set we can bring in and out of the space quickly, and flesh out the show. We're hoping to hire veteran actors and would very much like to pay them for their time and craft. 
  • We have perks! Some will get you your ticket to the show, some will get you love and affection from the artists, and some will get you one of a kind original art from the show.

Risks & Challenges

The biggest risk we face is not being able to bring this piece to life. The venue, registration fees for the festival, and required stage manager alone are more that the grant from Fierce. In addition, we're hoping to cast veteran actors, and would really like to be able to pay them for their time on this piece. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, don't worry, we still love you! Please:

  • share our campaign on your favorite social media platform
  • use the Indiegogo tools to share
  • let us know if you want to give non-monetarily! We need:
    • help with the front of house during our shows
    • furniture that is easy to transport and store for our set
    • makeup help for our actors

Thank you for reading this far! You're truly awesome and we appreciate you so much!

story:
Gut Buddies is an award winning, absurdist physical comedy about a parasitic worm and a white blood cell that are fighting over their habitat in the intestines. After a three-month national tour of India, and it’s Brighton Fringe debut where it won the Best of Brighton Fringe IYAF award, Gut Buddies set sail for the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. 

 

The Piece and Aesthetic

 

Karl is a parasitic worm. Like all of us he’s been trying to find his own home. He has found it in a shiny corner of the intestines, where he survived undisturbed, until today. 

Brian is a white blood cell and on his first day of work. He is a curious warm-hearted creature with a high sense of duty to the Brain who bosses him around. 

In a world that is threatened by the problems of coexistence is it still possible to be “Gut Buddies”?

The piece blends cartoon imagery, with strong characters saturated in luminous colours and a space-age backdrop. These lovable, eccentric characters may be magnetic in empathy, but are a problematic pair. They are forced together in a highly institutionalized world riddled with a fear for liberty.

 

The tone of the piece is gentle and easily accessible. Amongst the people that appreciated our work are: 

-Groups of friends with a beer in hand who don’t normally go to the theatre

-Molecular biologists

-Glamorous older women,

-Children that have tried eating soil before

-Parents that have tried eating soil before

-Muscular men with sunglasses

-People that love the Mighty Boosh, Chuckle Brothers and Waiting For Godot. 

-Those that weren’t happy with the end of ‘Lost’

-Clown lovers 

 

                                                                                Source

 

We explore the paradox between what it means to be human by looking at non-human things.

Gut Buddies is inspired by Jamie Lorimar’s Environmental Humanities study that looks at humans as multispecies made up of organisms such as cells, bacteria, fungi, archaea, and animals invisible to the naked eye. He looks at the ‘diplomatic dialogue’ between a hookworm and the immune system in order to negotiate the conditions for co-existence. 

Caught by this idea we explore the transposition of this relationship to human actions in communities. 

 

The Company

 

We are interested in creating visceral, thought-provoking and easily accessible productions that combine theatrical territories and conventions from the world of clown, the absurd, and tragic storytelling. 

Influenced by the work of Jaques Lecoq, Odin Theatre, Thom Monckton, Thomas Ostermier, La Re-sentida, Patrice Thibaud and the whole cast of Friends, especially Marcel the monkey.

We met three years ago during our Masters at LISPA (now Arthaus.Berlin) in collaboration with Rose Bruford College London.

 

Why We Are Going To Edinburgh

 

Besides the joys of haggis and scotch for breakfast, we hope the international audiences at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival will give us invaluable connections, and feedback on our work. We look for potential touring opportunities by showcasing to international industry professionals. Moreover we look forward to spending an intense month side-by-side with like-minded artists that will inspire and challenge our growing artistic practice. 

We recently returned from a three-month national tour of India, where we created a festival of short performances including ‘Gut Buddies’ and only one of us got Delhi belly! We covered the expenses of the tour by giving workshops to enthusiastic theatregoers and non-theatre audiences. From encountering people from different backgrounds and taking risks with developing work, we highlight the importance of transnational collaborations to connect, inspire and challenge each other. 

By broadening our audiences at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, we aim to create workshops, festivals and tour new environments, acting as an intercultural exchange for performance. 

 

Costs

This Crowd Funding campaign is to cover expenses that we wont be able to cover with our ticket sales:

 

Accommodation: 1000€

Travel from Berlin and Spain to Edinburgh: 400€ 

Marketing: 150€ for printing flyers and posters.

Costume: 120€, we need 2 copies of the costume because Matteo sweats A LOT. 

Fringe registration cost: 350€ 

Whisky (not for party purposes, but for obvious reasons): As much as possible.

 

Total: 2,020€, but we just won 20€ on a scratch card so the budget is 2000€.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Do you really want to help, but cant afford it right now? Don’t worry. Every type of contribution is appreciated. Share our event and campaign on social media, tell all your friends, put a tooth underneath a pillow for us and dance naked under the moonlight on our behalf. 

 

We hope to see you at one of our shows!
story_txt: Gut Buddies is an award winning, absurdist physical comedy about a parasitic worm and a white blood cell that are fighting over their habitat in the intestines. After a three-month national tour of India, and it’s Brighton Fringe debut where it won the Best of Brighton Fringe IYAF award, Gut Buddies set sail for the Edinburgh Fringe Festival.  The Piece and Aesthetic Karl is a parasitic worm. Like all of us he’s been trying to find his own home. He has found it in a shiny corner of the intestines, where he survived undisturbed, until today. Brian is a white blood cell and on his first day of work. He is a curious warm-hearted creature with a high sense of duty to the Brain who bosses him around. In a world that is threatened by the problems of coexistence is it still possible to be “Gut Buddies”?The piece blends cartoon imagery, with strong characters saturated in luminous colours and a space-age backdrop. These lovable, eccentric characters may be magnetic in empathy, but are a problematic pair. They are forced together in a highly institutionalized world riddled with a fear for liberty. The tone of the piece is gentle and easily accessible. Amongst the people that appreciated our work are: -Groups of friends with a beer in hand who don’t normally go to the theatre-Molecular biologists-Glamorous older women,-Children that have tried eating soil before-Parents that have tried eating soil before-Muscular men with sunglasses-People that love the Mighty Boosh, Chuckle Brothers and Waiting For Godot. -Those that weren’t happy with the end of ‘Lost’-Clown lovers                                                                                  Source We explore the paradox between what it means to be human by looking at non-human things.Gut Buddies is inspired by Jamie Lorimar’s Environmental Humanities study that looks at humans as multispecies made up of organisms such as cells, bacteria, fungi, archaea, and animals invisible to the naked eye. He looks at the ‘diplomatic dialogue’ between a hookworm and the immune system in order to negotiate the conditions for co-existence. Caught by this idea we explore the transposition of this relationship to human actions in communities.  The Company We are interested in creating visceral, thought-provoking and easily accessible productions that combine theatrical territories and conventions from the world of clown, the absurd, and tragic storytelling. Influenced by the work of Jaques Lecoq, Odin Theatre, Thom Monckton, Thomas Ostermier, La Re-sentida, Patrice Thibaud and the whole cast of Friends, especially Marcel the monkey.We met three years ago during our Masters at LISPA (now Arthaus.Berlin) in collaboration with Rose Bruford College London. Why We Are Going To Edinburgh Besides the joys of haggis and scotch for breakfast, we hope the international audiences at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival will give us invaluable connections, and feedback on our work. We look for potential touring opportunities by showcasing to international industry professionals. Moreover we look forward to spending an intense month side-by-side with like-minded artists that will inspire and challenge our growing artistic practice. We recently returned from a three-month national tour of India, where we created a festival of short performances including ‘Gut Buddies’ and only one of us got Delhi belly! We covered the expenses of the tour by giving workshops to enthusiastic theatregoers and non-theatre audiences. From encountering people from different backgrounds and taking risks with developing work, we highlight the importance of transnational collaborations to connect, inspire and challenge each other. By broadening our audiences at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, we aim to create workshops, festivals and tour new environments, acting as an intercultural exchange for performance.  CostsThis Crowd Funding campaign is to cover expenses that we wont be able to cover with our ticket sales: Accommodation: 1000€Travel from Berlin and Spain to Edinburgh: 400€ Marketing: 150€ for printing flyers and posters.Costume: 120€, we need 2 copies of the costume because Matteo sweats A LOT. Fringe registration cost: 350€ Whisky (not for party purposes, but for obvious reasons): As much as possible. Total: 2,020€, but we just won 20€ on a scratch card so the budget is 2000€. Other Ways You Can HelpDo you really want to help, but cant afford it right now? Don’t worry. Every type of contribution is appreciated. Share our event and campaign on social media, tell all your friends, put a tooth underneath a pillow for us and dance naked under the moonlight on our behalf.  We hope to see you at one of our shows!

story:
Short Summary

Rabid Bat Theatricals is a Chicago-based theatre troop that crafts free performance events in order to form community.  We are committed to the mission of eliminating the many barriers that keep swaths of people away from most theatrical events, and are proud to present our first ever season of two shows: our original open-air folk tale, The Princess, the Minstrel, and the Rabid Bat, and our immersive, spooky mystery, Dog Night.

What We Need

We are hoping to raise $3000 to divide between our Summer and Fall shows, to compensate our artists for their hard work, to supply technical elements (PMRB's traveling set, costumes, wooden swords; Dog Night's atmospheric design and audience masks), and to create marketing materials to extend our reach - all without ever having to charge for a single ticket.

The Impact

In our three previous summers we have witnessed free theatre's ability to transform public spaces, gather diverse crowds, incite wonder in viewers of all ages, and form bonds of community.  This is our particular way of making the city a closer, warmer place - one audience at a time - and we tremendously appreciate support with that goal.

Risks & Challenges

Not everyone is immediately receptive to the unfamiliar, and we have had to strive to bring reticent or unfriendly members of the community into the conversation in a healthy way, even knowing what a challenge that can be.  We try to prepare for the unpredictability associated with our brand of theatre, seeking solutions for bad weather, willful interruptions, and the occasional over-eager dog off its leash.  These challenges come with the territory and we get better every year at countering them.

Other Ways You Can Help

We deeply appreciate financial support but what we need above all else is an audience.  We would love for you to join us at one (or several) of our performances, details on which can be found at www.rabidbats.squarespace.com 

Beyond that, spreading the word about our goals and our show times can connect us with the wide audiences we hope to gather.  Thank you for your help!

story:
Lindsay Gonzales has been performing theatre, stand-up and improv for many years, but what she wants more than anything is to perform in national and international comedy festivals.

 She has performed in 10 countries so far:  The USA, England, Ireland, Scotland, Wales, Canada, Spain, France, Chile and Puerto Rico and at such festivals as The Women in Comedy Festival, The Boston Improv Festival, Geek Week, Impro Mundial Chile and The Portland Improv Festival. Lindsay Gonzales debuted her original one-woman show "M.P.H." in 2006 and the show is a mixture of stand-up, performance art, public education and song & dance.  Her show is a whimsical collage of stand-up, improv, sketch - “M.P.H.: It’s never the same show twice. It’s never the same show once.”

 Lindsay:

I've made a lot of progress...I've had tremendous setbacks and losses, and many people in my position would have given up- but I refuse to. I know I can put every ounce of energy I have into finding what Joy I can in this life and making it through in the best way I know how: by making strangers laugh. That’s all I ever want to do.  I know life is short and I know I have not accomplished as much as I set out to do, but I just really want to get out there and do my best and reclaim the life I want to lead…and most importantly, make ‘em laugh.

story:
Short Summary

A 30 min. sketch show, Victims of Circumstance explores unfortunate situations that you will be glad you have never had before. A very patient 411 Operator, one really committed Annie, a gay son who has a mother unlike any other, and many more victims ask the question, "What did I do to deserve this?" Sometimes you can't control the present, but you can laugh about the past.

This is the first time this show has been brought to a stage here in New York. This show will also be taped and submitted to local comedy theaters in NY in hopes for a run in front of larger audiences.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are not asking for a lot, only just enough to cover the cost of the theater rental space, because to do this properly, we want to put the show up in the proper space. This is not cheap. The money raised will also go towards the rehearsal spaces that we have used for the cast. It will also go towards any props, wardobe, transportation, food, and any other additional variables that pop up when producing a project such as this.

You will get all of the perks. From the smallest donation to the biggest, you can earn a digital copy of the taped show to as much as a sponsor credit that will be presented in all of our PR for the show. If you help us, we want to help you! We will be promoting this show all over the internet, in restaurants around the theater, and through the theater's promotional website.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

So you may not be able to give, but you can still help!

Come see the show! It's only $10.00 (with a purchase fee online) Here is the link to purchase tickets!

http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/435475

Here is the Facebook event page to see pictures and more!

https://www.facebook.com/events/516829185062543/?context=create

Can't see the show? All we ask is that you share this Indie GOGO link to your friends, families, and anyone you think will be interested in supporting small artistic endeavors.

If you are on Facebook make sure you share our event page, which will have links to this indie gogo site and links to where others can purchase tickets.

story:
About Our Festival:

The Hawaii Sketch Comedy Festival will be held on March 28th & 29th 2015 at The Honolulu Museum of Art's Doris Duke Theater! We will have two fun filled days of some MAJOR LOLs featuring live shows, screenings, panels, workshops and more! We wanna help revive the golden comedic days of "Raps Hawaii" and "Booga Booga" and to showcase the creative entrepreneurs of the world: Writers, Actors, Comedians, Directors, Videographers and more! Our festival will:

  • Provide opportunities for local artists to showcase their original work
  • Feature master workshops led by industry professionals to further educate artists in their craft
  • Hold panels to help empower artists and their businesses
  • Open up the sketch comedy world to another set of eyes and audience

What We Need & What You Get

We wanna start our first year off with a BANG!  Here's what we need the moola for:

  • Space Rental for workshops and panels
  • Travel and lodging expenses for master instructors
  • Festival bits and pieces like: badges, shirts, stickers, marketing material, etc
  • Speaking of fun things like shirts and stickers...perks include all that awesomeness and a bag of chips. Well...not like chip chips.  You know what we mean.  Anyone else out there grow up in the 90s? Just me? Oh...
  • Sponsorships!  We appreciate your support and in turn wanna promote your awesome business!  Choose one of our sponsorship packages and be all up in our festival!
  • TITLE SPONSORSHIP!  Click on this perk and the festival is essentially named after YOU! "YOUR NAME/BUSINESS HERE" presents The Hawaii Sketch Comedy Festival. You're so special...
  • And guess what? IT'S ALL FOR CHARITY!  Our festival is produced by StoryU Arts which is a division of the award winning Hawaii non-profit: The BizGym Foundation! BGF focuses on empowering entrepreneurs of all ages! Supporting our festival also means you're supporting programs like: Lemonade Alley (A kids business competition) and Camp BizGym (a business media camp for kids)...HOW COOL IS THAT?!

Holidays got you low on dough? No worries!

We value your time and effort.  If you're unable to donate cash, please consider doing one of these fun things:

  • SHARING IS CARING: Share this campaign with your friends, neighbors, family and whoever you think likes to laugh and have a good time! Actually...share it with the ones that don't like to laugh too...they should TOTALLY be at this festival!
  • LET'S TALK ABOUT SKETCH, BABY: Chat our campaign up! Spread the word! Safely climb to the top of your nearest coconut tree and yell, "MY PEOPLE! YOU MUST VISIT HISKETCHFEST.COM!"

Mahalo for your support!  We can't WAIT to see you in March!! YEEHAW!

story:
The Big, Fat Low Down

THE FOOD CHAIN

Even almost 20 years after its acclaimed first Off-Broadway run in 1995 at the Wooly Mammoth Theater, The Food Chain's sharp commentary on self-image, acceptance, and the desperation that follows from a lack of both rings true with present-day audiences. Silver's philosophy of mixing his message with a heavy dose of absurd character-based humor makes for a heavy-hitting comedy that sheds light on the darker side of our insecurities and coping mechanisms.

But don't take our word for it!

"In The Food Chain, Nicky Silver's toxic, fractured tale of sex, loneliness and the importance of being thin, the pursuit of love is an even more convoluted process than usual. It's hard, after all, to forge a relationship when all you can really hear is the sound of your own voice. For the poisonously funny, image-obsessed Manhattanites in the play, all the world's a mirror. It's no accident that much of this breathless comedy of neuroses [...] is made up of monologues, even though there are nearly always at least two people onstage." - New York Times

SPOON PRODUCTIONS NYC

Spoon Productions is a new collaborative group of artists from varying backgrounds and talents with a common interest/concentration in writing, improvisation, film, and live theatre. Current members consist of Jordan Stovall, Kyra Bromberg, Britta Whittenberg, Shane O’Neill, Joey Pelletier, and Dan Poppy. We met during the completion of the sketch curriculum at the Upright Citizens Brigade Training Center, and continued to meet independently to create and workshop new sketch comedy as the team We Spoon.

The Food Chain will be our second production after our successful debut of AfterSpoon Delight, a sketch comedy show written, produced, directed, publicized, and acted by the members of Spoon in December 2014. This was our first successful venture to produce a full-length production as a company.

In other words, we love doing this stuff, we're trained to do this stuff, we want to do the stuff, and we'd love to have you seeing us do the stuff. Stuff, stuff, stuff.

WHY CONTRIBUTE?

As a budding production collaborative with virtually no budget, all expenses will otherwise come out of the pockets of those involved, making new theatre difficult to realize. In order to bring The Food Chain back to life, we are asking for help from others, especially those that are similarly interested in live theatre and comedy, to help make our vision a reality.

The (Financial) Skinny

OUR FUNDING GOAL

We are seeking to raise $3,000 in 30 days to get this production on its feet. This budget will fund:

  • Rights to produce the play
  • Renting out the Treehouse Theatre for a 4-week, 8-show run of the production
  • Sets, lighting, sound, costuming, and other technical requirements
  • Rehearsal space
  • A small marketing budget to increase public interest
We seek to be as transparent as possible about all financial matters in this campaign, and assure you every penny will go to producing the best work possible.

PERKS OF CONTRIBUTION

We want to make sure everyone who contributes to our campaign knows how much we sincerely appreciate their support for helping us produce this play! Check out the column to the right to see rewards for each level of support.

IF WE EXCEED OUR GOAL?

Well good golly gee, you guys are the best! If we exceed our goal, all proceeds will go directly to improving production quality, to publicity and exposure for the production, and to helping Spoon Productions NYC create new work in the future!

Other Ways You Can Help

We are no strangers to being tight on cash. Any project like this is a HUGE group effort, and by just spreading this page by sharing in any capacity possible and spreading the word to your family and friends, you are helping us vastly achieve our campaign goal!

THANK YOU FOR CHECKING US OUT & BEING A PART OF NEW THEATRE!

story:
Hello, I’m Elizabeth. I am an experimental performer and dance maker, both learning the rules of dance and investigating how to break them.

On August 26th, I will be on my way to be an artist in residence at Ponderosa, a farm-turned-dance-center nestled in the German countryside about an hour outside of Berlin. I will spend six focused weeks in this idyllic setting making my favorite kind of work.

The residency, called Con|VERGE, is comprised of a curated group of interdisciplinary performers from around the world. The Con|VERGE artists will collaborate to make dances, conduct research, and lead workshops and panels. We will interact with the local rural community and also bring our work to Berlin.

You can read more about Ponderosa HERE and HERE.

You can read more about the Con|VERGE residency HERE.

My dance practice is a synthesis of movement, curation, photography, writing, design, dramaturgy, research, and community organizing. My plan to attend the Con|VERGE residency is based in a desire to continue to expand the definitions of dance by including these other forms in a newly intentional way.

Having ample time, space and resources will allow me to joyfully create a few projects during Con|VERGE to share with my backers and my community at large.

One project will be a culminating dance piece that I will bring back to show and workshop and hone and teach and show again. Another will be a DIY publication of my photographs and select writings about dance. Though I will be involved in myriad projects at Cov|VERGE, it is these two that I am the most excited about.

It is my intention to share these two projects with my backers in exchange for helping me out in such an important way. My dance-making always plays with the relationship between audience and performer and this campaign is no different. I see you all as more than donors; you are also my collaborators. Your contributions will provide me with the necessary constraints to generate content -- images, language, ideas and movement. I want to make something with and for each of you!

This campaign is FIXED FUNDING -- I get it all by August 26th or I get nothing!

$1,200 will offset the costs of attending the Con|VERGE residency at Ponderosa. I am really asking a humble sum for all of the planes, trains, materials, printing, gear, processing, workshops, productions, sustenance, labor and time. I feel confident that I can make my goal of $1,200  just in time for me to hop on my flight.

Please take a look at my perks  --------->

Thank you for reading all of this and for helping me out!

backers in exchange for helping me out in such an important way. My dance-making always plays with the relationship
between audience and performer and this campaign is no different. I see you all as more than donors; you are also my collaborators. Your contributions will provide me with the necessary constraints to generate content -- images, language, ideas and movement. I want to make something with and for each of you!This campaign is FIXED FUNDING -- I get it all by August 26th or I get nothing! 
$1,200 will offset the costs of attending the Con|VERGE residency at Ponderosa. I am really asking a humble sum for all
of the planes, trains, materials, printing, gear, processing, workshops, productions, sustenance, labor and time. I feel confident that I can make my goal of $1,200  just in time for me to hop on my flight.Please take a look at my perks  --------->Thank you for reading all of this and for helping me out!

story:
Short Summary

Sperm is a project of mine that I started in college. After moving to New York and having the script sitting in the drawer for a few years, I dusted it off, revamped it and sent it out. Thankfully the wonderful people at the Strawberry One Act Festival happened to think it wasn't too bad and put it in their excellent run of shows. It's been a long standing dream of mine to have something I did up on a New York stage, let alone in the amazing St. Clements Theatre. 
Sperm is a one act play about a man facing challenges when he is unable to have a child with his wife due to his ineffective sperm. This problem causes both marital and mental strife as he questions what it means to be a man in a journey that takes him down a dark path of struggling pregnancy expectations. 

What We Need

My funding goal is 1,000 dollars. This will go towards:

Reimbursing the stage rental

Rehearsal space

Lighting designs

Costumes and Props

and Printing Promotional Posters and Cards

Even if the goal is not reached, anything would be beneficial, as most funding will go to rehearsal space costs first.

Other Ways You Can Help

Contributing is not the only way you can help! Please feel free to spread this campaign and the dates of my show to anyone you'd like to share with.

story:
Our Story

My name is Éowyn, I am a choreographer based out of Portland, Oregon. My dance company Éowyn Emerald and Dancers, took on its name last summer but really began taking shape in 2012. We currently operate as a small project-based dance company.

Last year I decided to take my work to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, better known as The Fringe! It is the largest arts festival in the world, with 23,000 performers from 43 countries taking part in 45,000 performances every August in Edinburgh Scotland.

Performing at The Fringe was something I have always wanted to do. We performed for one week at the festival and funded the tour almost entirely on our own, with some help from family and friends.  

This year we know how it works and we want to improve on what we did last summer. That means a new show, a better time slot, twice as many performances, a more aggressive approach to marketing and getting more people in those seats. And we know that's attainable based on the incredibly enthusiastic response to our show last year which included a 4-star review.  Read the review!

  Returning to The Fringe this summer also means getting the help we need to make this happen. And that means you. We are a small company and we need help with what it takes financially to get there. There are numerous costs from airline, to lodging, to costumes, you name it....but most of all the dancers and our technician, James. They give up so much time and energy to make these dreams come true and they deserve to be compensated for what they pour into this company.  

Please help me not only make going back to the fringe a possibility but help me give those dancers and technician what they deserve.


What We Need

The festival is a completely self-produced project. Everyone presenting their work at the Fringe is doing it all at their own risk. Financially and artistically. For us this means first finding a venue that likes what we are and will rent the space to us, and then all the costs that come with producing a show. Next there is the incredibly large feat of traveling internationally as a company of 5. And obviously the creation of work takes time, energy, money, and the dedication of the dancers.

We are hoping to raise $15,000 with this indigogo campaign. This would help us cover more than half of the cost. Here is what your donation would help to cover:

  • More than half of that goes to our travel expenses. The airfare alone costs almost $8,000.
  • Lodging: $4533
  • Venue rental at Greenside: $3,900
  • Festival fee: $493
  • Music licensing fees: $425
  • Insurance fee: $205
  • Tech equipment rental: $285
  • Marketing: $715
  • Costumes: $200
  • Studio rental for warming up in Edinburgh: $90
  • Per diem for the cast: $3,710
  • Artist Honorarium: $4,000
  • Miscellaneous travel fees: $100

Total: $26,656

On the plus side! We retain all of the revenue from out tickets sales while we are there. Last year our tickets sales brought in $1,000. 


Impact

The Fringe is attended by press, promoters, presenters, audiences and artists from all over the world. It is an exceptional opportunity to network, build relationships and for my work to be seen in an international venue by these important individuals. Financially it is a big risk taking our work to The Fringe. Even if we sell every ticket to every show, the revenue won't come close to covering the cost of the venture. However, as an independent artist, it is very difficult to cultivate this level of exposure and it could prove invaluable to my future as a choreographer, and the futures of my dancers. 


Personally this festival means the world to me because of where it is and what it is. Scotland holds a special place in my heart and the festival and all its history speak to me about what it means to be a performing artist.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about both this campaign and our performances in Edinburgh. You can use the Indiegogo share tools to help share the campaign. 

You can find information about our performances in Edinburgh and a link to buy tickets here:  https://www.edfringe.com/whats-on/dance-physical-theatre-and-circus/eowyn-emerald-and-dancers 



Who We Are

Éowyn Emerald Barrett - Choreographer, Director & Dancer
Holly Shaw - Cultivating Manager & Dancer
Jonathan Krebs - Marketing & Social Media Manager & Dancer
Josh Murry - Outreach Manager & Dancer
James Mapes - Voice of Reason, Lighting Designer & Technical Director

story:
What is the NCCAF?

The North Carolina Comedy Arts Festival (http://www.nccomedyarts.com/) was founded in Chapel Hill, NC, in 2001 as an improv showcase and workshop opportunity. It's grown into one of the largest improv festivals in the southeast, and it attracts performers and instructors from all over the country.
CRAB&LOBSTER (Ian Custar and Kris Purushothaman, gentlemen-at-large) applied to the festival back in September 2015, and we got accepted! Somewhere on this page, you can view our video submission and see why.

What Does This All Mean?

CRAB&LOBSTER is everyone's favorite crustacean-titled longform improv comedy duo. Ian and Kris (omnipotent child-emperors) got accepted to perform in the North Carolina Comedy Arts Festival in Chapel Hill, February 11th-14th, and we need your help paying for the trip. Here's what your funding with your donation:

  • Registration fees, hotel room, workshops at the festival, fancy show tickets, gas (Atlanta to Chapel Hill and back!), food, bear mace, disguises, and definitely not bail money.

But What's In It For Me?

TWO-FOLD ANSWER. A) You get the warm, fuzzy feeling knowing you helped support two Atlanta improvisers hone their craft and spread their brand of weird joy. B) Prizes. Wizard-themed prizes.

  • We've got a bunch of perks for different donation amounts.
  • These perks are all wizard-centric.
  • To be clear, our two-man show is not about wizards necessarily; we just really like doing wizard impressions, and we want to share that joy with you.

story:
Dear Musical Theater Lover:

Manhattan at the turn of the Millennium—it’s the red-hot center of the exploding new phenomenon of the Internet. Brash young Web pioneers vie to stake their claim. With the sudden new wealth and lavish launch parties, it’s the Great Gatsby on steroids.

That’s the setting of our new musical comedy Cyberbabies, to be presented at The Theater for a New City this spring. You might think of it as a La La Land for New York. It’s got great characters, vivacious original songs and blazing choreography. Most of the cast will be made up of, appropriately, Millennials, so the whole project has a youthful, Spring Awakening  zing. Its highly hummable numbers include “Manhattanite In The Manhattan Night,” “Virtual Virgins” and “Eaten By the Internet.”

We think this musical could go places. It’s certainly the culmination of an exciting journey for us. We’re hoping you can become part of the adventure and assist in getting Cyberbabies produced.

Your contribution would go toward rehearsal space, props, lighting and sound design, music (including the band) and to pay the actors. And there are lots of wonderful perks for you if you donate.

About Us

Craig Silver (book, music and lyrics)

Craig Silver’s theater credits include his play The Oven, presented at the 13th Street Repertory, and his one-man show, God In A Box, at NYC’s Dream Up Festival. A singer-songwriter besides playright, Silver’s topical songs have appeared on NPR, CNN, WBAI, WFUV and other stations across the country. Billboard magazine said Silver performs “in the best Phil Ochs tradition.”

Lissa Moira (director)

Lissa Moira is co-creator of the musical Who Murdered Love?, presented at the New York Fringe Festival, and she directed a musical adaptation of Nicholas Nickleby with a cast of 35 at the Theater for a New City. Most recently she directed the critically acclaimed Holocaust-survivor opera Lady of the Castle at the Edwin Booth Theater Off Broadway. Bloomberg Radio declared that Moira’s directing is “beautiful, fresh and fine.”

Nevada Lozano (music director)

Music directing credits include: The Fourth Messenger, The Gold (NYMF); Calamity Jane (Musicals Tonight); The Lady of the Castle (Theater for the New City); Godspell, Company, Next to Normal, Avenue Q, Little Shop of Horrors (MJR Theatricals); Little Women.

story:
Hi!

I'm Meg Wolfe. I'm a choreographer based in Los Angeles, and director of Show Box LA. I am excited to announce I will be opening a new creative space/rehearsal studio in the Jefferson Park neighborhood of Los Angeles, called we live in space. We open in June 2016.

While the opportunity to sign this lease came up rather suddenly, I have been looking for a suitable and affordable space for some time. I'm excited about this one, and felt I could not let it go by. It's a ground-floor storefront space, about 20' x 45', with no columns, suitable for rehearsals and with enough depth for small showings and other events. It has two bay windows to  let in the light and curious passers-by; but I'll also put in some curtains for complete privacy when needed.

I am reaching out now for your support to get we live in space  up and running. There is some work to do, and I hope you can help out!
Primarily, I am seeking to raise funds to install a sprung dance floor in the studio; and to cover costs for a small amount of renovation work. 

This studio will be a home base for Meg Wolfe Dance; for events and residencies; and will also support the broader community through low-cost rentals for rehearsals. we live in space will provide a place for choreographers to explore and refine their work; and a place for artists and audiences to connect.


What We Need & What You Get

I am asking for your support with these costs:

- lumber & other materials for the floor
- paint, plaster, rollers, etc
- mops, buckets, brooms, cleaning supplies
- replacing an old toilet & floor linoleum
- removing old flourescent lighting, rewiring for new lights
- replacing a broken window
- replacing broken doorknobs & locks


While I am a fan of keeping it simple, the reality is that we may come across unexpected costs beyond the ones outlined above. Your tax-deductible donation will make sure that we are ready to cover any overruns related to getting the space ready for dancing feet.


For you:  here are some perks!

Ticket giveaways from REDCAT*!

Ticket giveaways from Center for the Art of Performance at UCLA*!

Social media and art business consultations with Dr. Anna B Scott!

Rehearsal time in the studio**!

Admission to we live in space events!

An invite to our opening!



The Impact

On the most basic level, your contribution will help sustain dancers in their work. Dancing on a sprung dance floor minimizes the wear and tear on our bodies that can occur working on hard floors with no give.

Being able to keep rental rates low nourishes and encourages a community of choreographers working in Los Angeles.

Beyond that, the impact of having a home base, to be part of the fabric of a neighborhood, to find new intersections of ideas, dreams, and dancing, is huge.


Risks

This is something I have been thinking about and working towards for a many years. I have been involved in projects in many spaces all over town: in warehouses, bars, basements, theaters, lofts, galleries, social clubs. While I have enjoyed these experiences, it's time for a home base.  There are always risks that come with any new venture, but I feel prepared and ready to take this on.

My partner, Lorrie Snyder, will be leading and doing much of the work on renovating the space and putting in the floor. She knows how to get things done. For those who don't know Lorrie, she specializes in the design and equipping of new performance spaces. She was the founding resident Technical Director for REDCAT (The Roy and Edna Disney/CalArts Theater); and acted as a technical consultant to the project during construction; she is currently the Venue Manager of Royce Hall, at UCLA’s Center for the Art of Performance.

Together, we can do it!

Please help if you can, and spread the word about this campaign.

Thank you, as always, for your support!



* All ticket offers are on an as-available basis; if performances are sold out, tickets of equal value, but for other events will be arranged.

**All studio rehearsal hours will be scheduled by mutual agreement, on a space available basis. Use them yourself, or donate to a local choreographer.

story:
Calling All Parties wants to bring our special brand of interactive art to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival…again. We have a venue booked, Bourbon Bar, from August 14-20, 2016, but we need your help to get to Scotland and produce our brand new show, The Life of the Party.

In The Life of the Party, we will lead festival goers on a journey across time from mod to rave to disco in a vivacious interactive theatrical and film experience in which audience members are invited to participate as party guests. Created, produced, and performed by Debra Keneally, Mahayana (Yana) Landowne, and Heather Alexa Woodfield, The Life of the Party, will immerse audience members in a series of parties supported by film projected on bespoke costumes.  

We estimate it will cost $9,500 to produce The Life of the Party, which includes transportation overseas, housing in the lovely city of Edinburgh, and production costs - projection, props, costumes, flyers, etc. We are pitching in nearly 50% of the hard costs and hundred of hours of in-kind labor. We are looking to you our friends, supporters, admirers, and innovative art lovers to donate the other half - $5,000.  Every contribution, not matter how small, will help make our vision a reality.

Your Contributions will go towards:

  • Travel Expenses - round trip airfare to Scotland
  • Accommodations - two weeks of budget lodging
  • Registration - for the Edinburgh Fringe Festival official program
  • Marketing - flyers and posters to promote our show
  • Equipment - to make our projections come to life
  • Production Costs - for low-budget/high style filmed elements
  • Creation of Costumes & Props - to achieve peak fabulousity

The Impact

Through The Life of the Party, we aim to advance the medium of interactive art by bringing it to the world stage at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival and grow as international artists in the process. As always, we hope to spread much laughter, joy, and empowerment by helping participants tap into their creativity.

Other ways you can help:

We're disco-phoning in our favors on this one, so PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD! Reach out your friends and ask them to support The Life of The Party via email, text, telegram, etc. and of course on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram...

Thank You!

Calling All Parties is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Calling All Parties must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Equipment - to make our projections come to life


Production Costs - for low-budget/high style filmed elements


Creation of Costumes & Props - to achieve peak fabulousity

The Impact
Through The Life of the Party, we aim to advance the medium of interactive art by bringing it to the world stage at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival and grow as international artists in the process. As always, we hope to spread much laughter, joy, and empowerment by helping participants tap into their creativity.Other ways you can help:
We're disco-phoning in our favors on this one, so PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD! Reach out your friends and ask them to support The Life of The Party via email, text, telegram, etc. and of course on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram...
Thank You!Calling All Parties is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Calling All Parties must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
MEET THE BRAINS BEHIND IMAGINARY FRIENDS!

Hi everybody! We’re the Cupcake Ladies, and we’re coming to you because we’re doing a production in this year’s Planet Connections Theater Festivity called Imaginary Friends, a multimedia production that focuses on the sounds, real or imagined, we sometimes hear coming from the stuff between our ears. And we need your help!

But who are we, like, specifically? Glad you asked! See that photo up there, where a video would usually go? Right. So, from left to right, starting at the bottom left of the picture above, we are Xavier Rodney (actor, multimedia), Rich Wisneski (actor, playwright), Laura Mae Baker (actor, director, costumes), Paul J. DeSena (playwright, actor), Melissa Meli (actor), Melissa Farinelli (actor, director, technical director), Michael Rehse (actor, director).

WHERE DOES MY HELP GO?

Glad you asked. Here's where your support goes:

  • REHEARSAL SPACE (oy, is this stuff expensive)
  • Projector (we are a multimedia production, after all)
  • Costumes (believe it or not, fabric costs money)
  • A Robot (you heard it here first, folks)

ALRIGHT, YOU SEEM TO BE ON THE UP-AND-UP, BUT WHAT DO I GET IF I DONATE? 

Fair question. You see over there, on the right panel? No, above the ads for the “Celebrity Photos That Will Totally Blow Your Mind” and that “One Weird Spice That Totally Slays Diabetes.” See that there? Our perks. Our 100% Organic, Free-Range, No GMO Perks (perks may have some GMOs). Pick what you’d like, donate, and sit back and bask in the glow of your perk (perks do not glow).

And guess what? These donations are tax-deductible (minus the cost of those sweet, sweet perks). Cupcake Lady Productions is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Cupcake Lady Productions must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

ALTERNATIVE SUPPORT

Alright! I get it! Fine! You’re a bit short right now. No worries! Still want to support us? Great! Here’s how: 

  • Buy tickets! Come and listen to the voices in your head!
  • Share this page! The more people find out about us, the less we’ll annoy you.
  • Like and share our Facebook page!
  • Do you have a rehearsal studio space?  A coupon for Kinko’s? A kidney sale you’d like us to broker? Reach out to us here and let us know. 

See you at the show!

Sincerely,

Cupcake Lady Productions

story:
About Monica Hogan Danceworks

MHDW is a project based contemporary dance company based in NYC. We have been creating and performing in a mixed-bill format since 2013, as well as offering workshops, residencies, master classes, and more.

Now, we are thrilled to have the opportunity to present our own full-length theater production at GK ArtsCenter in DUMBO, Brooklyn, NYC.

This marks an incredible milestone for the company, offering the ability to develop more long-format work. The show in May will mark the premiere of our first large-scale choreographic project, Resilient Paradise.

With a fiercely driven all-female cast, MHDW has been working tirelessly since August of 2018 developing this show. 

Support Our Artists

We've been putting the hours in at the studio. 

Now we need your support! Please consider making a donation to support the development of this show and, more specifically, compensation for our amazing artists who have dedicated a huge number of hours to rehearsing and preparing for this debut performance.

Meet the Creative Team

Here are the incredible artists your contributions will support: 

  • Dancers:
    • Arzu Salman 
    • Audrey Wells
    • Ellen Brown
    • Tyra Els
    • Emily Hogan
    • Sydney Keir
    • Sarah Lapinsky
    • Louisa Pancoast
    • Chisato Yanagisawa
  • Lighting Design: Craig Stelzenmuller
  • Stage Manager: Liz Hepp
  • Photography (promotional): Mike Esperanza / Esp.
  • Makeup Artist: Sunny Young
  • Photography (show): Justin Chao

Every Bit Counts

Whether it's giving $5 or $500, every contribution truly counts and we appreciate your support! If financially backing the campaign isn't feasible for you, here are some other ways you can help:

  • Spread the word -- let others know about our campaign!
  • Come see the show in May
  • Like, share, and engage with our content on social media

Thank you for your help!

story:
About Machinal

A young woman follows the path that society deems fit for her, despite feeling resistance. She marries her boss (a man she doesn't love), has a child with him, and then has an affair with a younger man. Revitalized by this experience, her moral conflict grows until she retaliates.

  • Based on the true story of Ruth Snyder
  • Explores the themes of gender stereotypes, relationships, socioeconomic status, and the psychiatric phenomenon of derealization
  • A new adaption written and directed by Artistic Director - Elaine Rava

What We Need & What You Get

  • Rehearsal Space - the average studio charges $40/hr in NYC
  • Performance Space - as much as $500 per performance
  • Raw materials for design - set pieces, rentals, equipments, etc. $500 +
  • Props - $250
  • Marketing materials (Facebook ads, posters, programs, and more) - $100
  • Artist support - $50 per actor

We need your help! Claim one of our perks to get social media shoutouts, exclusive Shellscrape merchandise, tickets to the show, complimentary drinks, and so much more.

The Impact

Shellscrape Theatre Co. follows the non-profit business model - meaning all of the money we raise goes directly towards our theatrical productions. And if we happen to make money? It goes towards our next artistic endeavor! With your help you are:

  • Supporting a community of emerging and early career artists
  • Investing in the growth and development of the arts
  • Helping to make thought provoking theatre accessible and inclusive
  • Sponsoring the production of new works

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're unable to donate at the moment, please consider

  • Spreading the word! Share our campaign on your social media platforms to show your support.
  • Follow us on social media to stay updated on future campaigns.

We appreciate any amount you are able to give - there is no donation too small.

story:
Undertale – Musikaali toiveista ja unelmista on harrastajapohjainen musikaalituotanto, joka perustuu käsikirjoitukseltaan Toby Foxin vuonna 2015 julkaistuun peliin Undertale. Musikaalimme on täysin vapaaehtoisvoimin tuotettu, emmekä tavoittele minkäänlaista voittoa: esityksissämme ei ole erillistä pääsymaksua emmekä pyydä minkäänlaista korvausta esiintyessämme maksullisessa tapahtumassa. Tästä syystä tarvitsemme teidän apuanne!

 

Keitä me olemme?

Olemme n. 30 hengen pääkaupunkiseudulla harjoitteleva joukkio, jonka tavoitteena on tuoda lavalle Toby Foxin pelin upea tunnelma. Musikaalin harjoituskausi on alkanut vuoden 2018 elokuussa, ja ensi-ilta häämöttää jo vuonna 2020.

 

Mihin lahjoitukset käytetään?

  • Puvustukseen, lavastukseen ja tarpeistoon: visuaalinen ilme on tärkeä osa teatteria, ja haluamme luoda unohtumattoman elämyksen. Lisäksi on tärkeää tehdä kaikesta laadukasta ja kestävää, jotta puvut, lavasteet ja tarpeisto kestävät koko esityskauden!
  • Tekniikkakuluihin: haluamme varmistaa, että esityksemme on jokaisessa esityspaikassamme tasalaatuinen, ja pienellä pesämunalla pidämme huolen siitä, että käytettävissämme on aina suhteellisen samanlainen tekniikkavarustelu niin äänitekniikan kuin valojenkin puolesta.
  • Logistiikkaan: pyrimme tuomaan esityksemme useammalle paikkakunnalle, mikä tarkoittaa, että niin koko joukkiomme kuin lavasteemme ja pukumme täytyy kuljettaa esityspaikalle. Tämä tarkoittaa esim. pakettiautojen vuokraamista sekä tietysti bensakuluja.

 

Vastikkeet

Olemme erittäin kiitollisia jokaisesta lahjoituksesta, joten jokainen tukijoistamme pääsee nimellään tai nimimerkillään kunniapaikalle nettisivujemme Tukijat-osioon. Tarjolla on myös erilaisia tuotteita, kuten pinssejä ja T-paitoja.

 

Vaikket itse kykenisi lahjoittamaan, voit silti olla avuksi! Pistä kampanjamme jakoon ja kerro kavereillekin, arvostamme sitä kovasti <3

 

Nettisivut: https://www.undertalemusikaali.fi/

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/undertale.musikaali/

Youtube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCK212Waw39JvDS...

Twitter: https://twitter.com/utmusikaali

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/undertale_musikaali/

Tumblr: https://undertalemusikaali.tumblr.com/

 

In English:

Undertale - A Musical About Hopes and Dreams is an amateur musical production based on Toby Fox's 2015 game Undertale. Our musical is completely non-profit: we don't sell tickets to our shows and don't get any provision if we perform at a convention. That is why we need your help!

 

Who are we?

We're a group of approx. 30 people mostly based in Helsinki, who have an ambition of bringing Toby Fox's game's astounding atmosphere on stage. The musical's rehearsals begun in August 2018, and our premiere will be in 2020.

 

Where does the money go?

  • In to making our costumes and props: the visual side of theater is really important, and we want to provide an unforgettable experience. It's also important for everything to be of quality and durable, so our costumes and props will last us for our whole tour!
  • In to sound engineering and lights: we want to make sure our performance is homogeneous no matter where we perform, and with a little bit of money reserved we can make sure that we'll always have quite a similar set of lights and sound gear at our use.
  • In to logistics: we plan on performing in a number of cities, which means our whole crew and our costumes and props have to be transported to our performance locations. This means f.ex. renting vans and gas expences.

Perks

We're very thankful for every penny we get, so each one of our backers gets their name or nickname on our website's page dedicated for backers. We also offer some physical perks, such as pins and T-shirts.

 

Even if you yourself can't donate, you can still help! Share our campaign and tell your friends; we appreciate that <3

 

Website: https://www.undertalemusikaali.fi/

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/undertale.musikaali/

Youtube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCK212Waw39JvDS...

Twitter: https://twitter.com/utmusikaali

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/undertale_musikaali/

Tumblr: https://undertalemusikaali.tumblr.com/

story:
"Six Months of Winter" is a new original comedy by Cody Sanders about a young, queer couple and the first six months of them living together. They struggle through different hurdles and they have some less than helpful sources of advice: their meddling friends, self-involved family members and even the local god-like radio DJ. It is a tumultuous six months, but they learn at the end that spring always comes after winter. 

We at CodAko Entertainment are producing this play as our first entry into the Capital Fringe Festival in July 2019. It is our largest and most ambitious project yet, with the opportunity to reach a wider audience than we've ever had. We will be performing in Capital Fringe's Plum Theatre in the Arena Stage building in SW DC.

Performance dates:

  • July 12th  @ 7:30pm
  • July 14th @ 8:00pm
  • July 21st @ 12:30pm
  • July 25th @ 5:30pm
  • July 28th @ 12:30pm

To put on a full production we are buying/building all set pieces, props and costumes. And with gods as characters we have some elaborate plans for these, therefore our budget is much bigger than usual. Also being a part of the Capital Fringe Festival comes with its own fees. We are hoping to raise about $2500 to cover these costs.

But we also want to give back and have several perks for those who donate:

  • Those who donate $5 or more will have their names printed in the program 
  • Donate $10 or more and you'll get a shout-out on social media to any personal or professional page
  • If you donate $25 or more you'll get invited to a special preview event with food and drink
  • For $50 you will get a ticket to the show

We are very excited about this play and our premier in the Capital Fringe Festival. Since founding CodAko Entertainment we have been passionate about creating and showcasing important queer art. "Six Months of Winter" is a new kind of queer art: queer art that affirms identity while showcasing toxic behaviors within the community. We've been working on this story for years and are ready to bring it to a mainstream audience.

If you are not able to donate but still want to help out, there are plenty of ways you can participate. First, you can share this campaign to friends and family. You can also follow us on social media: CodAko Entertainment on Facebook and @codako_dc on Twitter and Instagram. You can also just come and see the show and enjoy it. We welcome all your support and are so appreciative of all donations we receive.
