story:
Hawthorne

In Portland, Oregon - city of sodden dreams - a private investigator wrestles with her past's attempts to become her present. Whether she's diving down the rabbit hole or climbing up the chain of command, she can't stop until she finds the truth. And we all know how well that usually goes...
Hawthorne, running May 12th through June 4th at Action/Adventure Theatre, is an original play by A/A company members Aubrey Jessen and Greta West, written through collaboration with a brilliant team of actor/devisors.  By using the structures and tropes familiar to film noir and pulp detective novels, Hawthorne explores what it means to navigate a world that is filled with traps we built ourselves - the unsafe, unsettled feeling of generalized anxiety that so heavily influences both film noir and an awful lot of people's lives.
Photo Credits: Pat Moran

Action/Adventure Theatre

Action/Adventure Theatre is so excited to bring you Hawthorne as our last show of the 2015-2016 season. Action/Adventure is a Portland, Oregon based non-profit theatre. Since 2007, we've been focusing on bringing accessible, entertaining work to new audiences. We're best known for our "theatre for TV people" serialized shows - a new episode of an ongoing story each weekend, bringing together the best parts of scripted work and improvisation (a story with a definite beginning, middle and end, AND exciting, in-the-moment dialogue). Hawthorne is Action/Adventure's second original, fully-scripted play - after last year's beautiful and successful How to Stop Dying by company member Noah Dunham, we were inspired to keep exploring the possibilities of applying our creative team's energy to a more traditional scripted play format. The results have been overwhelming, and we can't wait to share them with you. Our team of astonishing collaborators includes the cast: Zoe Rudman, Jade Hobbs, Ellery Jessen, Cassie Skauge, Beth Summers, Jake Simonds, Michael Zimmer, and Andrew Haftkowycz; the design team: Lucas Welsh, Richard Moore, Dan Minzer, Tyler Buswell, and Jade Harris; Stage Manager Kelsie Johnson; and our devising team: Stephanie Cordell, Brian Kuwabara, Justine Davis, Katie Watkins, and Jed Arkley.

What We Need & What You Get

Action/Adventure is in the extremely rare position of having spent most of our years almost entirely funded by ticket sales. This is a pretty glowing testament to our relationship with our audience, but it also puts an inherent ceiling on the scope of our shows. Without asking too much of our audience by raising ticket prices, it limits our ability to compensate our collaborators in a way that reflects the magnitude of their talents and time. We are asking for $5,000 - your help will take the cost burden off of ticket sales and let us go deeper and bigger with our design elements. Our tremendously talented team is working to create a multi-media immersive world for our characters (seriously - sound, lights, projections, set, costumes - all so amazing). Every contribution will go directly toward production costs like equipment rentals, material purchases, and - most critically - artist stipends. Any amount is helpful toward this end, and it will all go to offset costs and pay artists even if we fall short of our $5,000 goal. By helping, you become an invaluable part of this team, and teammates get gifts! 

For $10 "Hawthorne" signed post card: The cast of "Hawthorne" is charming and attractive and talented, and they will send YOU a postcard with all of their signatures on it. It's like having 8 of the best pen-pals in the world. For $20  "Hawthorne" signed photo: Postcards are cool, but you may really be craving a stunning 8x10 image from the show. For $50 "Hawthorne" VIP Experience: If you're going to come to the show (and we so hope you are!), why not come to the show in a manner that lets everyone know how great you are? This is a package that includes a ticket to the performance of your choice, beverages, a reserved seat, and a signed 8x10 photo from the show. For $100 "Hawthorne" VIP Opening Night: Come celebrate the launch of this exciting project! This package includes a ticket to opening night (May 12th), beverages, a reserved seat, a signed photo from the show, and an invitation to our opening night toast/meet and greet. Take pictures with excited actors! Pose on the set and pretend to be a detective - or a villain if you prefer - while loved ones post your photo on Facebook! A guaranteed good time. For $150 Writer/Director Spa Day: "Hawthorne" wasn't written in a day, and it wasn't written without the help of massage chairs and pedicures. Collaborators (and human women who need to do something nice for themselves once in awhile for heaven's sake) Aubrey and Greta will treat you to one of the most important pieces of the creative process - pedicures with friends. Will you get the inside scoop about the creation of the show? It seems very likely, talking being an important part of the experience. Treat yourself! For $200 Personalized Detective Theme: "Hawthorne" composer/sound designer and frequent Action/Adventure superstar and associate artist Richard Moore will compose you your very own theme music, Looking for something to capture your tragic yet noble hero's journey? Maybe a tune to express your inherent sensuality (a gift AND a weapon!)? Richard will write you a score for the ages. For $200 A Song for You: Action/Adventure Associate Artist (A/A/A/A) Cristina Cano is a renowned singer/songwriter with a presence in multiple (very cool) bands - including, but not limited to Albatross and Siren and the Sea - and has a way with the personal and specific in her lyrics. She will make you a song! A murder ballad? Sure! A pop jam? You bet! She is so talented, and we are so lucky to have her! For $350 Noir-styled Photo Shoot: "Hawthorne" costumer and Action/Adventure Associate Artist Jade Harris has the most impeccable eye for detail, and an aesthetic that can't be described, but comes close with "Wes Anderson Vacationing in Twin Peaks in the Early 90s." She will apply these prodigious talents to styling and shooting your very own noir-themed photo session. For $500 Movie Night with the Cast: "Hawthorne" is the direct product of the team's love of film noir. Join the cast and crew for a screening of one of our favorites (that you get to choose from our curated list!). Snack, beverages, and opinions all part of the package!

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign! Come to the show! Follow us on Facebook! And, most importantly (if you're in Portland or Portland-adjacent), COME SEE THE SHOW! 

Hawthorne

Thursdays through Saturdays at 8:00

May 12th through June 4th at Action/Adventure Theatre 

1050 SE Clinton St Portland, OR

Tickets: http://www.merctickets.com/Browse#venue=7388308-actionadventure-theater
story_txt:
Hawthorne

In Portland, Oregon - city of sodden dreams - a private investigator wrestles with her past's attempts to become her present. Whether she's diving down the rabbit hole or climbing up the chain of command, she can't stop until she finds the truth. And we all know how well that usually goes...

Hawthorne, running May 12th through June 4th at Action/Adventure Theatre, is an original play by A/A company members Aubrey Jessen and Greta West, written through collaboration with a brilliant team of actor/devisors.  By using the structures and tropes familiar to film noir and pulp detective novels, Hawthorne explores what it means to navigate a world that is filled with traps we built ourselves - the unsafe, unsettled feeling of generalized anxiety that so heavily influences both film noir and an awful lot of people's lives.
Photo Credits: Pat Moran

story:
Hi!

We are the Uphill Theatre Company! Our original play, 'All the In-Between', will make its world premiere at the 2020 Hollywood Fringe Festival, and we need your help!

Toeing the line between farcical absurdity and heartbreaking realism, 'All the In-Between' explores the complexities of saying goodbye. It is a whimsical memory play, where two individuals are trying to see eye-to-eye...of course, it doesn't help that there's a talking bird who only seems to make things worse.

'All the In-Between' will make its debut at the Flight Theatre @ The Complex Hollywood
Thursday, June 4 @ 8PM
Friday, June 12 @ 10PM
Sunday, June 14 @ 3PM
Saturday, June 20 @ 7PM
Sunday, June 21 @ 1PM
Saturday, June 27 @ 5PM

We hope to see you there!

 

Who Are We?

The Uphill Theatre Company was founded in Los Angeles by two former east-coasters who are passionate about original stories. In a world of reboots and sequels, we are committed to producing new content penned by a wide spectrum of voices. 

 

How Can You Help?

Theatre is expensive, man! Our goal of $5,500 will enable us to properly compensate the wonderful theatre artists embarking on this journey with us, and to ensure that we can bring the best possible production to the Hollywood Fringe. Additionally, it will enable us to price our tickets as low as possible, making new theatre accessible to audiences of all backgrounds.

 

Our Mission:

The Uphill Theatre Company is dedicated to creating original works that speak to a larger purpose. We are determined to bring universal truths spoken with diverse voices to the forefront. We believe everyone has a story to tell. 

 

Want to help but can't donate?

We get it, sometimes life gets in the way. Even if you can't donate, just letting people know about our show and helping us get the word out would be so appreciated!

story:
The GRIEF GIRLS are a multidimensional crew of artists whose diverse identities and artistic practices inform the work. We approach our intersectional narratives with vulnerability and rigor. 

In our first ever evening-length work, we are using performance to step into the chasm that divides all of us and invite witnesses to meet us there. Through dismantling assumptions of otherness we aim to restore humanity in both performance and process. 

During our week-long residency at Base: Experimental Arts & Space leading up to our culminating evening-length show, we will offer interactive performance/conversation series free of charge. We’ll host a dialogue about the social underpinnings of CHASM, drawing from James Baldwin’s play “Blues for Mister Charlie,” which largely inspired the work. 

CHASM features:                                                                                                                                               

Direction by Laura Aschoff                                                                                                      

Performance by the GRIEF GIRLS: Markeith Wiley, Chelsey Weber-Smith, Julia Sloane, Lillian Orrey, Erin McCarthy, Hanna Hofmann and Matt Aguayo.                                                         

Lighting design by Meg Fox                                                                                                                 

Technical direction by Elby Brosch                                                                                                   

Sound design by Markeith Wiley in collaboration with performers

Funding Covers:

Artist Compensation (10 collaborators), Performance Venue ,Rehearsal Space ,Production Expenses (props, costumes)

story:
Short Summary

The Collective We strives to produce musical theatre that makes people want to take action, revamping yesterday’s shows for today’s voices. We rework pre-existing shows to add a modern twist, and present new works that are fresh and fulfilling. 

 

  • Theatre should be inclusive, immersive, and intuitive
  • All theatre should be accessible to all ages and abilities 
  • Theatre should be a diverse, safe space

 

Storytelling deserves the time it preserves. Where would you be without stories?

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

We're applying for grants and funding from the city, but theatre isn't cheap. Seattle is a big city and there are a lot of fees when it comes to art.

 

  • It costs a lot to rent spaces, to pay artists fair wages, and to get rights to shows. We want to be able to do all of this, and we can't do it without your help. 
  • With every donation there is reward! They range anywhere from a sticker to a personalized thank you to a ticket to an opening night show and afterparty!
  • If we aren't able to reach our goal, it isn't the end of the world. The money will still go toward the project and we'll just have to be extra creative to raise more funds. 

 

The Impact

Your contribution will make a difference, no matter how big or how small. Even if it's just sharing the fundraiser with your friends and family, it means so much to us.

 

  • This project is for the people. We want to create art for the Seattle Theatre Artists who don't feel seen, we want to create it WITH the artists that don't feel appreciated and heard.
  • With a young team, we have a lot of drive. We want to make this happen and will work hard to get it done.
  • You are helping change the world. 

 

Risks & Challenges

There are plenty of risks with this project. People might not care, the starving artist trope is alive and well, and Seattle is becoming less and less of an artists city every day. Hopefully we still make enough noise to make enough of a difference.

We didn't reach our last fundraising goal! That didn't stop us!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Money can be tight! We get it! You can still help us if you're interested in the project!

 

  • Join our email subscription to stay up to date on our projects!

  • Share the project online. Make lots of noise about this.

 

And that's all there is to it.

Thank you so much for your help. We couldn't do this without you.

story:
Everyone knows that books are the purest form of magic, but some tales are more powerful than others. The Library of Broken Books takes in powerful tales that have gone wrong, those that need fixing before their errors start leaking out into our reality. We present an experience that is a hybrid of escape games, immersive theatre and game shows.

Brief Concept Clip

From the moment you enter the Library, we will be transporting you to an incredibly immersive world. Your team of 2-4 players will be guided by a Librarian through the different genres of the library.

 Unlike a traditional escape game, you do not choose a single game to play, instead, you experience multiple adventures in selected genres. Within these dynamic experiences, your goal is to collect as many keys as possible. We are launching with Adventure and Fantasy zones first.

This will help the Librarians lock down any chaotic magic threatening the tale. This collection of keys makes for an arcade-like experience, where once collected they can be noted down, recording your achievements, and ensuring that if you would like to play again you can attempt to collect them all! There will be a variety of different challenges inside each book, ranging from physical, logical, skill-based and multi-person puzzles, meaning that there will be something for everyone.

Along the way you will journey through exciting locations, facing magical surprises, meeting memorable characters and solving the mysteries of the Library.

Back Us on Indiegogo

Support us by buying early bird tickets! It will enable us to make the library as amazing as it can be. This also allows you to join us as we share updates on each of the stages from design to build and launch.

Risks and challenges

We have the perfect venue in mind in Central Leeds and are in the later stages of acquiring it. Once this is complete… We have big dreams for the Library, all of which take substantial planning, money and time to create. Due to this, we will be splitting the project into multiple phases. We already have funding for stage one: creating the library, the first two genres (Adventures and Fantasy), and a number of unique adventures within the genres.

Your support on Indiegogo will allow us to bring this vision to life at its full potential (think amazing props and tech), with all the care and detail it (and you!) deserve, and help spread the word! It would also help us get Phase Two moving along. This will see the introduction of our next two genres (Horror and Magic), a free-roam immersive art experience in collaboration with other creators, a bar, meeting space, and the constant development of new stories to play.

story:
A little background 

Hello! For those who don't know me my name is Kat Wellman and I've recently graduated with a Bachelors in Technical Theatre. Theatre is something that I'm passionate about and have been lucky enough to pursue. Although I was born in Alaska, I grew up in Germany, and then moved to England to pursue my passion for backstage work. 

Now I need to save up enough to apply for a new visa to stay in the UK to continue pursuing my dreams and working toward my goals. It's a lot for a student and with the impact of Covid, funds are always tight. 

Contributing to this would help me achieve the goals that I've been working towards for three years and help me to start off on this truly amazing career path. Anything at all would be immensely helpful to me and I would forever be grateful.  

What do I need?

The downside of being an international in the UK is that staying is incredibly difficult...especially when funds are low. The application fee for a graduate route visa (Which will allow me to work in any capacity of Theatre for two whole years!) is £700 alone. Additionally theres a Healthcare Surcharge for both years of the visa which comes to £1.248. All of that together plus postage and additional documents comes out to about £2.000. 

This is why I've decided to ask for help, it's a lot of money to try to save by myself at the moment and any little bit that can be spared would be amazing. Wether you're my family and would like to give a small graduation present or anyone who can spare a small bit, it all adds up. If I don't reach my entire goal then that's perfectly okay, I'm still going to use whatever money I do raise to fund at least part of the application process

Why do I need this?

Technical Theatre is not only something I'm passionate about but something that I excel at. Being able to pursue my dream and kick off my career would not only mean the world to me, but also change the entire course of my future. 

This is a huge opportunity for me and I would appreciate any help at all to make my dreams a reality.

 

If you can't donate anything that's completely fine. I know times are tough and I don't want to ask anything of anyone who isn't in a place to help. But if you could share and tell people who are in that position it would mean a lot. Thank you so much for reading and helping!

Thank you for reading!
story_txt:
A little background 
Hello! For those who don't know me my name is Kat Wellman and I've recently graduated with a Bachelors in Technical Theatre. Theatre is something that I'm passionate about and have been lucky enough to pursue. Although I was born in Alaska, I grew up in Germany, and then moved to England to pursue my passion for backstage work. 
Now I need to save up enough to apply for a new visa to stay in the UK to continue pursuing my dreams and working toward my goals. It's a lot for a student and with the impact of Covid, funds are always tight. 
Contributing to this would help me achieve the goals that I've been working towards for three years and help me to start off on this truly amazing career path. Anything at all would be immensely helpful to me and I would forever be grateful.  

What do I need?
The downside of being an international in the UK is that staying is incredibly difficult...especially when funds are low. The application fee for a graduate route visa (Which will allow me to work in any capacity of Theatre for two whole years!) is £700 alone. Additionally theres a Healthcare Surcharge for both years of the visa which comes to £1.248. All of that together plus postage and additional documents comes out to about £2.000. 
This is why I've decided to ask for help, it's a lot of money to try to save by myself at the moment and any little bit that can be spared would be amazing. Wether you're my family and would like to give a small graduation present or anyone who can spare a small bit, it all adds up. If I don't reach my entire goal then that's perfectly okay, I'm still going to use whatever money I do raise to fund at least part of the application process

Why do I need this?
Technical Theatre is not only something I'm passionate about but something that I excel at. Being able to pursue my dream and kick off my career would not only mean the world to me, but also change the entire course of my future. 
This is a huge opportunity for me and I would appreciate any help at all to make my dreams a reality.

 
If you can't donate anything that's completely fine. I know times are tough and I don't want to ask anything of anyone who isn't in a place to help. But if you could share and tell people who are in that position it would mean a lot. Thank you so much for reading and helping!
Thank you for reading!

story:
99 Women | 99 Stories | 1 Stage

99 Women is a unique and ambitious theater project where 99 Women with 99 Stories will be performing on 1 Stage in the month of July, 2016 in Pune, India. 

Originally conceptualized by Genevieve Flaven – a French national, the project has had its first successful run at Shanghai in China in October 2015.

The next destination is Pune, India for which the script has been adapted to the Indian Context.

The volunteer actors in the play comprise of 99 women from Pune, from different walks of life, different cultures and from different social situations. These actors are being mentored by an experienced panel of experts – theatre professionals, choreographers, voice and speech experts through highly interactive immersion workshops into the field of Performing Arts.

A Social Initiative

The benefits of the play will be given to the women empowerment project –‘SWAWLAMBAN' (English: Self-Supporting) led by Chaitanya Mahila Mandal of Pune. Their Vision is, 'Upliftment of Society through Women and Children' and their Mission is 'Integral development of women in achieving their due status in a secure environment'. 

 Please visit http://www.cmmpune.org for more information.

Why Pune?

Pune, located 150 kms from Mumbai, India has been looked upon as a Rational & Progressive city with a focus on women empowerment and social well-being. Modern day Pune boasts of a supportive culture and a springboard of opportunities for women from all over the country and abroad.

Current Status of the Project

Over 90 enthusiastic participants have registered for the performance and are regularly undergoing preparatory and advanced theater workshops. We are self-funding this initiative and have managed to pool in a contribution to the tune of $5000, that have gone into getting rehearsal spaces and arranging theater workshops. But the funds collected so far are not enough to take the performance to the audience.

This initiative needs your help.

We urge you to help us spread the word about this Indian initiative, which is one of its kind. By contributing to this initiative you will be helping us to create an uninhibited experience for the audience as well as the performers.

Our total budget for the production is approx. $ 14000 out of which we have been able to raise $ 5000 successfully through self-funding and by the support of our well-wishers like you.

So please take the time to look at our campaign video. You may also visit our website www.99women.org for further details. 

What We Need and What You Get

Your contribution will help us in achieving to a large extent, the following:

  • Costumes
  • Props
  • Set Dressing
  • Print and promotion
  • Lights and Sound
  • Travel
  • Other Production Costs

As a humble gesture of gratitude for your wishes and contribution, we are offering some exciting perks. Apart from that you will also be an integral part of something very exciting which has never been tried in India at this level and of this scale. 

So please contribute for a cause, contribute for arts, contribute for the stories to unfold. 

Risk & Challenges

The most obvious risk and challenge is the flow of funds through this journey of a theatre production. We have some of the most talented and enthusiastic women in our troupe and we can see that the learning journey till now has been both liberating and therapeutic for most of them. These women are working very hard to push their limits and put up a grand show.

We are confident that with your kind support we will surely achieve our goal and set a bench mark by making this performance a huge success.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The Team

Genevieve Flaven (Author)

 

Genevieve Flaven is a French woman, born in Paris in 1969. Genevieve is an entrepreneur when she’s not busy writing. In France, she studied Economics and Business and founded a design agency in 2001. In 2010, she landed in China to expand her business. Genevieve is a writer ever since she resolved herself to put on paper millions of stories and thoughts coming tumbling out her mind. Living in Shanghai reinforced her dedication to literature and led her to publication.

Sonali Kothari (Producer, Project Director)

Sonali Kothari,is the founder director of Innishari, an initiative focused on human renaissance through various initiatives like wall narratives, workshops and theater. In the past, their work has touched the lives of less privileged children, school students, teachers, parents, housewives, corporate professionals and city authorities. Earlier, Sonali has worked with The Akanksha Foundation, an NGO in the field of education of the less privileged children. She has over 8 years of experience working with children, teachers, college students and corporates as a trainer on topics ranging from child behavior, teaching strategies, creative thinking and conflict resolution. She holds a Masters in Zoology from Calcutta University. You can reach her at sonali@innishari.com

Neeti Pherwani (Art Director)

 

Neeti Pherwani, has been involved with theatre ever since she can remember, and recently she co-headed Moonbeam Factory Theatre in its trial trajectory.  She is currently working in marketing, sales and branding at a social enterprise, Coppre, in Pune, promoting handcrafting traditions in metalware. Apart from being a theatre professional, she has explored various dance forms, instruments and experiments with mixed media art forms. Neeti holds a Masters in English Literature from Pune University. You can reach her at neeti.pherwani@gmail.com

Shaberi Ray (Choreographer)

 

Shaberi Ray, our choreographer, is a homeopathy doctor. Her compelling passion in music and dance led her to get training from Prayag Sangeet Samiti and Shiamak Davar and also choreograph events for 15 years and counting. Currently, she runs a music and dance school by the name Tan Tarangam, whose short journey of 10 years has already created 200 beautiful dancers and musicians.

Vartika Gupta (Production Manager)

 

Vartika Gupta,  is a Psychologist and an Arts Based Therapy Practitioner. She works with children and grown-ups alike through various art forms like drawing, painting, music, dance, drama, stories, drum circles and subtle energy work. She is a Project coordinator at Aark Foundation, a de-addiction and a rehabilitation center, working with the chemically afflicted.   She is the founder of Protsahan India Foundation Pune chapter. She completed her Masters in Psychological counseling from Christ University Bangalore and Certificate course in Arts Based Therapy from World Center for Creative Learning Foundation (WCCLF). She has recently founded Machhli, a center of experimental arts. You can reach her at gupta.vartika8@gmail.com 

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Other Ways You Can Help

Doesn't matter if you are not able to contribute financially, you can also contribute by spreading the word across and help us reach contributors and well wishers like you.
Feel free to spread the word, and help us reach our goal. Please share on social media, tell your friends. Your one link, one tweet, one share can really make a difference.
Please feel free to contact us for any queries that you may have. 
Thank you.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

You may follow us on

facebook.com/99womenpune | twitter.com/99womenpune

instagram.com/99womenpune | http://99women.org

story:
Denver Immersive Opera is Denver’s newest opera company. We present English operas in unique venues, and design productions to be immersive and participatory experiences. In doing this, the company aims to attract new audiences to opera and offer exciting opportunities to local singers.

 

The company will present its first production in October 2017 with three performances of Menotti’s haunting opera “The Medium”. We will take over the basement at Syntax Physic Opera, a local bar and venue. There, audience members will experience the bedeviled lair of crooked fortune teller Madame Flora and participate in a seance, witnessing her descent into madness.

 

With a mission to engage new opera fans, the company aims to keep ticket prices low while maintaining a commitment to creating paying opportunities for local singers. Denver Immersive Opera needs your support so we can pay for the show’s performance rights and pianist!

What We Need & What You Get

Our budget:

$450 - Performance Rights

$500 - Pianist/Music Director

$550 - Sets, costumes, promotional materials and Indiegogo fees

Total = $1,500

 

Our perks are designed to enhance your experience at Syntax. Perks start at just $10 for recognition both publicly and privately; and move up to include signed promotional materials and the best seats in the house.

PERKS

$10 - TOBY - Recognition - thank you email, shout out on Facebook, website listing (unlimited)

$25 - TAROT - Thank you email, shout out on Facebook, website listing AND a personal thank-you postcard (unlimited)

$50 - MONICA - Thank you email, shout out on Facebook, website listing, a personal thank-you postcard AND a production poster signed by cast (unlimited)

$100 - GHOST - Thank you email, shout out on Facebook, website listing, a personal thank-you a postcard, a production poster signed by cast AND an invite to our dress rehearsal on 10/19 (23)

$150 - BLACK SWAN - Thank you email, shout out on Facebook, website listing, a personal thank-you a postcard, a production poster signed by cast, an invite to our dress rehearsal on 10/19 AND a ticket to a performance of your choice with a guaranteed seat next to a performer (5)

$250 - BABA - Thank you email, shout out on Facebook, website listing, a personal thank-you a postcard, a production poster signed by cast, an invite to our dress rehearsal on 10/19 AND a ticket to a performance of your choice with a seat next to Madame Flora herself (3)

 

Even if we don’t reach our goal, “The Medium” will still go on (but singers will get paid less). If we surpass our goal, singers will be paid a bonus and remaining funds will go toward the company’s next production.

 

The Impact

As our world changes, so must art evolve to the needs of contemporary life. Denver Immersive Opera is dedicated to fostering this evolution in the opera world and ensuring a future for this art form. “The Medium” is the company’s first step towards achieving this goal in the Denver metro.

 

Our staff is experienced and excited. We all are passionate about bringing opera to unique spaces and new audiences, and have 30+ collective years of performing and producing operas. Our experiences have led us to establish this company with a full understanding of the risks and the challenges that come along with it.

 

We appreciate your support! Please help us spread our mission and share this campaign with your friends and family!

story:
Lucy Riner and Michael Estanich are taking RE|dance group to several cities around the Midwest this Summer and Fall and we want to bring our gift of dance theatre LOVE to you!

We established RE|Dance Group in 2009 as a means to explore long distance collaborations and present dance theatre works that examine the many facets of human relationships.  Executive Director, Lucy Riner, is a Chicago based dance artist and teacher.  Artistic Director, Michael Estanich, lives in Stevens Point and is an associate professor of dance at the University of Wisconsin.  Our creative process embodies rich emotional content and dramatic imagery through the layering of music, text and sculpture.  We seek to establish physical memories that enrich our  dancing and the relationships created in our works. 

What does all this modern dance jargon mean?  Essentially we love making dances about people, relationships and how love and connection impacts us as human beings!!! We made "It's About Love Again This Year" two years ago and it's the dance that keeps on giving.  Audiences love it and we love performing it! 

So we are looking to our friends, family and dance supporters to help us get to 3 cities in the next 3 months! Our tour starts in Minneapolis for a five day run at the Minnesota Fringe Festival. From there, we will make our way to Detroit to present another crowd favorite, "The Mysterious Disappearance of the Second Youngest Sister" at the Detroit Dance City Festival. Then we hope to show our signature duet about desire, "Abbot & Viv" in West Virginia later this Fall. So many places to share our art but we can't do it without you!!!

Your support will go directly to paying the dancers for their talents and artistry and also getting us to all these great places in the mighty Midwest! And of course we want to provide you with perks and ways to follow our progress as we travel! Most of all, we hope that if we are in a city near you, you'll come see a show and introduce yourselves to us afterwards. Our dances are about human connections! What better way to keep that dream alive than to meet wonderful people around the country and world like you!

story:
What is this?

The Apt Show: Haunted House of Capitalism is about showcasing local indie artists with live performances and installation art. There'll be snacks, entertainment and a whole lot of fun. All funds raised will be split between the 6 artists equally, as well as paying for any decorations/tech needed so that these artists don't have to pay out of their own pocket and are reimbursed for the hours that they have spent prepping.

Why are you asking for money?

At Thumbs Up Good Work Theatre we believe that artists should be paid for their art, their hard work and their efforts. With our previous shows we have found that the artists are just barely breaking even.

What do you need $800 for?

Ideally, we would like to give each artist $100 to reimburse them for any incurred costs on tech rental, props, costumes and the time the have spent prepping and creating their pieces for the show! No matter what we raise, each artist will receive an equal share of the amount raised, and a portion will be used to cover decorations, advertising, props and items for the installation art pieces.

I can't donate, but I want to help!

Great! Thank you for believing in our project. If you can't donate money, we would also love old halloween decorations, bags of candy, or just a share and a like. You can check out our Facebook page Thumbs Up Good Work Theatre.

story:
November 22nd will mark the 50th anniversary of Lee Harvey Oswald's assassination of the 35th president, John F. Kennedy. The Purchase College Musical Theatre Club presents Stephen Sondheim's "Assassins. A thought-provoking and insightful piece, "Assassins" allows us to explore the psyches of the nine assassins who fell far from the American Dream.

"Assassins" dares to retell history, presenting us with the stories of nine individuals who changed the course of American history with their one irreversible act: assassinating or attempt to kill a president. Sondheim and John Weidman's musical educates audiences on the darker moments of American history, that way we aren't "bound to repeat it."

"Assassins" will be produced by a 100% student cast, crew, and team to the Purchase College commmunity and those in surrounding Westchester communities. Shows will take place at 8:00 pm on November 21st and 22nd.


Funding will go towards (in this order, from first to last)
-> The performance rights for Assassins with Music Theatre International
-> Materials to build the set and props
-> Costume pieces
-> Carnival games (with prizes!) for the audience to play outside the theatre before the show starts
-> Printing posters and playbills for the show

Featuring: Tony Mita, Chris Loucas, Billy Manton, Mason McDowell, John Downey, Andrew Hones, Sheila O' Neil, Alex Ferro, Laura Meltzer, Keith Weiss, Adriana Amaya, Iris Rogers, Parade Stone, Cassandra Armstrong, Sara Donnellan, Sam Stein, Sebastian Rametta and Matthew Rafanelli.

Production Team:

Director - Jesse Penber
Assistant Director - Alexandra Baldwin
Producer- Laura Meltzer
Music Director- Juno Arreglado
Pianist - Sequoia Sellinger
Set Designer - Alexander Whittenberg
Lighting Designer - Nathan Avakian
Costume Designer - Talia Sabag Film Director - Robin Richardson
Production Stage Manager- Miriam Levenson
ASMs - Taylor Barje and Justin Babbitt

Sponsored in part by the Purchase College Student Government Association

"Assassins" dares to retell history, presenting us with the stories of nine individuals who changed the course of American history with their one irreversible act: assassinating or attempt to kill a president. Sondheim and John Weidman's musical educates audiences on the darker moments of American history, that way we aren't "bound to repeat it."  
"Assassins" will be produced by a 100% student cast, crew, and team to the Purchase College commmunity and those in surrounding Westchester communities. Shows will take place at 8:00 pm on November 21st and 22nd. Funding will go towards (in this order, from first to last)-> The performance rights for Assassins with Music Theatre International-> Materials to build the set and props-> Costume pieces-> Carnival games (with prizes!) for the audience to play outside the theatre before the show starts-> Printing posters and playbills for the show
Featuring: Tony Mita, Chris Loucas, Billy Manton, Mason McDowell, John Downey, Andrew Hones, Sheila O' Neil, Alex Ferro, Laura Meltzer, Keith Weiss, Adriana Amaya, Iris Rogers, Parade Stone, Cassandra Armstrong, Sara Donnellan, Sam Stein, Sebastian Rametta and Matthew Rafanelli. 
Production Team:
Director - Jesse Penber Assistant Director - Alexandra BaldwinProducer- Laura Meltzer Music Director- Juno ArregladoPianist - Sequoia SellingerSet Designer - Alexander WhittenbergLighting Designer - Nathan AvakianCostume Designer - Talia Sabag
Film Director - Robin RichardsonProduction Stage Manager- Miriam Levenson ASMs - Taylor Barje and Justin Babbitt
Sponsored in part by the Purchase College Student Government Association

story:
About Us

We're Duke Daal Baath Shaak Raas, Duke's premier raas-garba competitive team. We were founded in 2006 and compete around the nation from California to Florida keeping the Gujarati tradition and culture alive not only on stage but also around Duke University's campus.

We have had success in past competition winning competitions such as Miami Mayhem and Aag Ki Raat and placed at several others.

We are currently a club sport, however, because of renovations around campus, we are looking for support from the community to keep our successful seasons coming. With your help, we are looking at towards our two first major goals: getting new costumes from India and winning our first competition of the the spring, Raas Mania at the University of Illinois in Urbana-Champaign. Then we are going to Dallas for Southern Methodist University's Raas Rave & Bhangra Blitz competition.

We need $2500 just for our first competition at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champlain, Raas Mania but we expect we'll need $5000 in fundraising to make our season a success and $3500 for Raas Rave. If we reach our goal of $1500, we can be sure that we will be able to go to our first competition, Raas Mania! But this is just a start and we could use all the help you can give.

We put in a ton of time a week on top of our already busy class schedules. All we need is your support so that our costumes look as good as we do and that we can get to Illinois in February.


What is Raas-Garba?

Raas-Garba is set of traditional dances from the Indian province of Gujarat performed during Navarati. These include Garba, Raas and Tran Taali. These dances started as communal dances were everyone would dance in celebration of Durga.

We have moved the dance from this setting and onto stage as we perfected and energized the dance. In America, this grew into a competition circuit, especially at the college level, where different teams compete to see who has best kept the spirit of Navaratri alive while impressing the audience.


Our Short Term Goals

As we've mentioned, right now we need to pay for competitions and costumes.

Getting to competitions is clearly our top priority, but it is also expensive. Even past paying for entering the competition itself, reaching the competition and reserving hotel rooms for twenty people can cost more than a thousand dollars per competition.

Right now, we're looking towards our next competition, but this is just one of our spring competitions. Included in our fundraising goal is the entirety of our competition costs of Raas Mania in February to ensure we can afford to compete. Although we plan on driving to Illinois, we still need to pay for hotels, dues and gas money to get there.

We estimate just this competition to cost $2000-2500, $1000-1200 to help us fly there and $1000-1200 for hotel costs with $100 set aside for competition costs and other expenses.

SMU's R2B2 competition will likely cost us $3500 with $2500 spent out of pocket for plane tickets and about $1000 on hotel accommodations.

In addition, we have had our current costumes for three years and they are beginning to become dilapidated. After use in our competitions and around campus, the detailing on these outfits are starting to go. If possible, we would like to replace these before they become unusable. However, we get our costumes custom-made from India, which causes the costs to rise. In order to get enough costumes for our team and to get them made right, we estimate the cost of replacing our costumes to be $1000-1250.

If you could help us reach half of what we need, we would be very grateful although if you can help us with this competition and costumes, it will open us to larger competitions later in the season.

Longer-Term Goals

Even this is just one of the competitions we going to over the course of the year. We plan on needing $10,000 to successfully compete in all of the competitions we want to and to get new costumes. That is, even beyond Raas Mania and costumes, there is until plenty of room for you to help. We continue going to competitions throughout the spring and then start again next year with more competitions.

Club dues cover nearly half of what we need, but it is still not enough to compete everywhere we would like. As a college organization with a still small alumni base, we need your support and the help of the community to accomplish all that we set out to this season.

We have had successful seasons in the past and with your support we can bring it even further as we go to even more competitions. In the past we've won at competitions such as Miami Mayhem, even placing third in our most recent competition, University of South Carolina's Aag Ki Raat.

Help us do what we love and keep Raas on the rise. We can't do it without you!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate, there are plenty of ways to help. Please share our page with others or with organizations that can support us. Further beyond, money if you have any means of helping us get our costumes or reach or competition, please feel free to contact us.

If you can help us with fundraising on campus, please contact us so we can find out more at dbsraasfundraising@gmail.com


Thank you for your support!

DBS Raas

Abhishek Balakrishnan, Sruti Pisharody, Pramodh Ganapathy, Anna Knight, Ashwin Kommajesula, Daiana Dai, Eshita Singh, Alekhya Sure, Deepika Potarazu, Helen Murphy, Kavya Durbha, Komal Kinger, Nicole White, Alisha Pope, Parth Chodavadia, Pooja Mehta, Priyanka Kanal, Raj Sikaria, Becky Holmes, Rhea Chitalia, Jordan Lucore, Roshni Prakash, Sagar Patel, Shreyas Bharadwaj, Swetha Iruku, TJ Ciesla, Vaishali Oza and Vandana Kumar.

story:
Following our incredibly successful production of West Side Story in 2013, Tisch New Theatre (TNT) will mount another cross-departmental, cross-school musical for a one- weekend engagement at the 860-seat Skirball Center for the Performing Arts this April, with this year’s show selection being Catch Me If You Can.

Over the next few months, we intend to bring the NYU community together in an unprecedented way by bridging the gap between the many schools and departments within the university. Developing a cross-school musical of this size will give students, regardless of their field of study, the opportunity to exercise their passion for the arts with other students they would not normally interact with. West Side Story marked a great change in the way NYU students can collaborate together on a project with the cast containing students from four of NYU's schools.

The collaboration that happens when performers of these different backgrounds come together is something truly outstanding, with every single person bringing something completely unique to the process. This year, we have taken that idea of cross-school collaboration and have attempted to maximize its full potential, with students from six of NYU’s schools being represented in our cast and on our production team.

We're thrilled to welcome students from Tisch (Drama, Film & TV), Steinhart (Vocal Performance, Drama Therapy, Applied Psychology), Gallatin (Individualized Study), The College of Arts and Sciences (Physics, Journalism), The School of Engineering (Business Technology and Management, Engineering), and The College of Nursing. The cast’s experience ranges from leads in Broadway’s Newsies and the national tour of West Side Story, to students performing in their first musical since high school. Together, these students will have the opportunity to work together and present their work to 800 spectators each night. Rarely do NYU shows exceed an audience of 100, so the possibility of performing for an 800+ member audience comprised of the NYU community is truly thrilling for all involved.

We’ve been asked, “Why Catch Me If You Can? Why NYU Skirball?” When tasked with choosing a show, there were many things about Catch Me If You Can that excited us—its thrilling story, beautiful score, and dynamic dance numbers, just to name a few.

But what excited us the most was the opportunity to work on a show that has a recognizable name, thanks to the Oscar-winning film it’s based off of, but no pre- conceived notion for what it should be. It’s not an iconic classic like West Side Story or A Chorus Line where the audience expects a certain look or style. It can be an entirely new take based on the decisions of our team, which will be showcased beautifully in the largest theater in New York City below 14th Street.

We truly want to make this the production that students can get behind and be proud of. We believe that the NYU community is ready for a project of this caliber to be a yearly tradition, and we are eager to share this with the NYU community this April.

story:
Anna is upset. Her family is at a loss; they know they should do something. Scream. Shout. Pray. Cry. Something other than just ignore it all. Drawing from gathered sources of our own experiences, those of families, friends, strangers – even audience members – this exciting new verbatim piece seeks to dramatise the everyday, big and small, funny and tragic, in the hope of stumbling upon the words Anna has lost. All to show that there is a happy side (as well).

 

To find out more about the show and the process we are currently going through, visit:  ahappyside.wordpress.com

 

We are Hammersmith Academy 6th form students trying to raise money to put on a production we have been working on at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. As this is our last year studying the performing arts course, we would love to take our individual range of skills up to Edinburgh to showcase our talent to the rest of the world, and also help put our school on the map. We are hardworking and devoted students who always try our hardest to achieve the maximum of our potential and help others do the same.

We are working in collaboration with Niall Wilson, a playwright from the Royal Court young writers programme to create a new piece of theatre. After workshops with Niall and our own independent research we hope that we have created the seed of an idea that not only communicates who we are and what we love to do but that also create a legacy of new writing and devised performance at Hammersmith Academy that will inspire students in years below us.

 

Greenside (venue 231)

2nd - 10th August

4pm

 

tickets available from the 1st may from www.edfringe.com

story:
Hey, Hey Mi Gente!

I'm Toi, a storyteller, community organizer and artivist, and I'm asking the community- the People- to support the first steps in my research for my second community play and novel (*and possibly graphic novel) entitled Resistencia: Sangre which will take you, the co-authors, deep into exploration of Afro-Boricua and Taino identity and spirituality while also exploring liberation- Puerto Rican independence and anarchy. We follow a group of radical, queer independentistas involved in Puerto Rico's underground movement and music scene  who are interested in the dismantling of the current system and the collective liberation of the island's People. The group find out that their current story is the continuation of a much older story- a history of slave revolts, indigenous resistance, and rebellion told in a parallel by their ancestors and radical predecessors.

About Me and My Work:

I'm a spoken word artist, playwright, filmmaker, journalist, blogger, author, food and health justice organizer, gender rights activist, and medicine maker/herbalist. I'm also ending a year term as an Americorps VISTA member/community health organizer where I took a vow of poverty while serving low-income communities of color on Austin's East Side.

I began my journey as a playwright while living in West Oakland and had the reading of my first play, Genderqueer Files: La Qolectiv@, in Austin this year for the Mi Casa es Su Teatro portion of our local, fringe festival- FronteraFest.  It was the highest grossing and highest attended play for this section of the festival. Genderqueer Files: La Qolectiv@ brought out people of all colors, genders, and sexualities and created much-needed dialogue in the community. Not bad for a brown, queer, play in spanglish. The play is now a community workshop.

Genderqueer Files: La Qolectiv@ is a sci-fi tale that follows a multi-racial group of queer, radical activists who find strength and guidance from their ancestors in order to dismantle a system that thrives off gender and racial exploitation. (Read the monologues: Here)

    

My plays address themes of gender, sexuality, spirituality, ancestry  heritage, accessing our inner power, autonomy, and interdependence.

 

Other work:

Blogs

Genderqueer Street Philosophactivist blog

Queering Herbalism blog

Zines

Queering Herbalism zine

Herbal Freedom School Webpage and zines.

Kwueen Shadez

Film

"Survivin'" - Queer Women of Color Film Festival in San Francisco.

Books

Notes from an Afro-Genderqueer

Notes from an Afro-Genderqueer2

Philosophactivism

Chapbooks: Saturn, Venus, Mars, Artivism

My writings are an extension of the life I live as a community organizer and activist committed to justice, equity, and freedom for all marginalized folks. Queer. Brown. Women. Genderqueer. All those who feel voiceless or invisible. My writings are a tool for healing and liberation. They are meant to open a space for cross-cultural, intergenerational dialogue that sparks collective action across difference . By examining all of who we are we are able to address multiple layers of oppression faced by the various communities that we are a part of.

These writings have helped me to heal by allowing me to work through my own oppression and re-examine and reclaim my multi-ethnic heritage and deep roots that span from the Americas, to the Caribbean, Africa, Spain and other parts of the Mediterranean and as far east as India.

About Resistencia: Sangre

In Resistencia:Sangre you'll listen to the silenced voices of Afro-Puerto Ricans, Tainos and their ancestors through the story of queer musicians, organizers and visionary community members committed to their island's liberation. While searching for their own autonomy and independence they stumble upon suppressed histories, tragedy, triumph and Truth. Experience the music and magic.

 

                            

                       

                
                                                         
 
 


                      c

 

The Characters:

An interesting mix of punk band members, organizers and activists, artists, community members and visionaries and all are about decolonization, ending "the Struggle", and their oppression and reclaiming their birthright: Freedom.

There will be scenes with their African, Taino, and even Spanish, ancestors, healers, and scenes with anarchist, feminist, and other radical and powerful predecessors. And the play will integrate the following themes...

Main themes:

 

  • Liberation
  • Independence/Interdependence
  • Autonomy/Sovereignty
  • Trans and Queer identity and injustice
  • LGBT/Queer Rights
  • Afro-Puerto Rican Identity (*in spanish, see above link for an english video)
  • Taino (indigenous) Identity
  • Land rights
  • Environmental Justice
  • Economic justice
  • Gender justice

 

 

I'm super excited about the birth of this play as all of these themes contain elements of my personal history and I know that you will be excited with the outcome, too.

 

Why Resistencia: Sangre is important

             

This play is all about reclamation and resistance. For far too long, we've been denied our histories and forced to forget our roots and expected to assimilate. Afro-Boricuas and Tainos, especially those inhabiting queer bodies, have a rich history of political and cultural radicalism that is seldom told. Weaving together the stories of characters that embody contemporary countercultures, feminist and anarchist historical figures, and African and Taino ancestry, Sangre: Resistencia will help us uncover the more hidden side of the Island's rich culture of dissent.


Reclamation is healing. Healing is resistance.

 

Who is Resistencia: Sangre for?

This isn't for broadway or fancy, inaccessible bookstores with coffeeshops in fast gentrifying areas. This is for the People. I want to bring this to queer communities of color, our families, friends and allies.

Resistencia: Sangre is meant to inspire dialogue that recognizes the significance of incorporating our spiritual roots, cultural ancestry and political heritage into our collective struggles to create a world free from exploitation.

While Resistencia: Sangre focuses on a specific group of Black and Brown Puerto Ricans, the themes addressed within are relevent to peoples of all racial/ethnic identities who are engaged in a struggle to dismantle oppressive hierarchies of power and reclaim their humanity.

Indigenous, Australian (Murri) artist and activist Lilla Watson once said:

"If you have come here to help me, you are wasting our time. But if you have come because your liberation is bound up with mine, then let us work together."

Our liberation is bound up together. And as Martin Luther King, Jr. said:

"Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere."

When we listen to each others' stories we begin to understand the complexities that have led to our oppression, our roles in the oppression of others, and what it will take as a larger community to heal from and transfrom a system based on suppression, invisibilizing, and invalidation.

Just as it took hundreds of years of careful crafting for this ridiculous system to dominate the world, it will be a slow process to dismantle it.

It starts with compassionate and transformational dialogue and blossoms into strategic action.

I know I'm sick and tired of being sick and tired...aren't you? Good! Please contribute to a liberatory play and novel by, for, and about the People!

Yes, YOU.

 
        

 

What's Needed to create Resistencia: Sangre

  • Airfare - Roundtrip Austin- San Juan=   $350
  • Lodging- $40-60 (avg $50)/nt. (hostels,paradores, etc) @ 10 days ~  $500
  • Transportation  (cheap rental car -$200/wk, bus, metro) = $300

       (to Taino villages, pueblos of predominantly folks of African descent,     University of PR campuses to speak with professors, sustainable farms and farms ran by women-"agro-mujeres" and visits to other sustainable projects, major cities: San Juan, Mayaguez, Ponce and mountain villages)

  • Gas $200
  • Food   $200
  • Emergency Funds $250
  • Fees charged by Indiegogo and Paypal- $200

 

Total: $2,000

 

What You'll Receive

As a co-creator of this work every single person who contributes will have free access the play online.

 

Here are some of the other amazing swag you will receive:

$5- Shout outs on the Afro-Genderqueer and Genderqueer Street Philosophactivist webpage plus access to online copy of the play Resistencia:Sangre. 

$10- above PLUS a shout out in the novel and play and access to online copy of novel and play. Plus 50% off novel and play.

$20- above PLUS a copy of either the novel or graphic novel and monologues from the play.

$50- above PLUS you get to name a character!

$100- all above PLUS you get to name the main characters' band or select scenes!

$250- all above PLUS a chance to contribute your art (poetry, drawings) to the novel and play

$500- All above PLUS

autographed everything
two copies of play and novel
free tickets to closest show for you and your friends/fam

$750- All above PLUS you get to help construct a scene in the play!

$1000- Everything above PLUS
invitation to special Areíto (ceremony),
invitation to pre-show
invitation to pre-release of novel.

YOU are truly an integral part of this work! Let's build this together.

The Impact

It's not easy to fund brown, queer liberatory art projects. There are few plays produced by and centered around queer people of color that are addressing similar themes with the intention of co-facilitating discussion and workshops around personal healing for collective liberation. 

I'm excited to write this play and novel about the invisibilized and those at the intersections of identity in a very real underground movement in Puerto Rico. Africanness and its importance in the very culture of Puerto Rico has been suppressed and the Tainos are said to have been decimated so they are only to be seen in pictures from the 16th century and museums that have them frozen in time even though there are many people carrying on the traditions.

Also, over 30 queer folks have been murdered on the island in the past few years. There are very few protections for the queer and LGBT in Puerto Rico. Though so many travelers guides call it one of the most "queer-friendly travel destinations". When finished with this play and novel I hope to travel with it to Puerto Rico, the states, all over the Americas and abroad to raise awareness and empower those who may feel silenced!

You can contribute to this and be a part of the R/evolution.

Every single dollar toward this work is important and I can't wait to collaborate with those of you who are interested in collectively creating this story.

 

 

 

Can't Spare the Change? Here are Some Other Ways You Can Help

 

  • Get the word out on facebook, twitter, tumblr, and even beyond social media! Please share this page with anyone and everyone!
  • If you know of any community spaces, theatres, classrooms, etc. that may be a great place for this work, please get in contact with me so we can make it happen!
  • If you'd like to be involved with production, readings, or artwork for the novels, please contact me: gqstreetpoet@gmail.com.

 

When Will We See The Fruits of Your Labor?

I'd like to have a first draft of the play done by 2014 and a draft of the novel by May 2014.

But have no fear, I'll be blogging about my time in Puerto Rico and giving monthly updates on the play and writing process between now and March and I'll be releasing scenes online for all who are interested in how Resistencia:Sangre is developing.

 


                        
 

Thank you all for your support! Let's do this!
story_txt:
Hey, Hey Mi Gente!
I'm Toi, a storyteller, community organizer and artivist, and I'm asking the community- the People- to support the first steps in my research for my second community play and novel (*and possibly graphic novel) entitled Resistencia: Sangre which will take you, the co-authors, deep into exploration of Afro-Boricua and Taino identity and spirituality while also exploring liberation- Puerto Rican independence and anarchy. We follow a group of radical, queer independentistas involved in Puerto Rico's underground movement and  music scene  who are interested in the dismantling of the current system and the collective liberation of the island's People. The group find out that their current story is the continuation of a much older story- a history of slave revolts, indigenous resistance, and rebellion told in a parallel by their ancestors and radical predecessors.
About Me and My Work:

I'm a spoken word artist, playwright, filmmaker, journalist, blogger, author, food and health justice organizer, gender rights activist, and medicine maker/herbalist. I'm also ending a year term as an Americorps VISTA member/community health organizer where I took a vow of poverty while serving low-income communities of color on Austin's East Side.
I began my journey as a playwright while living in West Oakland and had the reading of my first play, Genderqueer Files: La Qolectiv@, in Austin this year for the Mi Casa es Su Teatro portion of our local, fringe festival- FronteraFest.  It was the highest grossing and highest attended play for this section of the festival. Genderqueer Files: La Qolectiv@ brought out people of all colors, genders, and sexualities and created much-needed dialogue in the community. Not bad for a brown, queer, play in spanglish. The play is now a community workshop.
Genderqueer Files: La Qolectiv@ is a sci-fi tale that follows a multi-racial group of queer, radical activists who find strength and guidance from their ancestors in order to dismantle a system that thrives off gender and racial exploitation. (Read the monologues: Here)
     
My plays address themes of gender, sexuality, spirituality, ancestry  heritage, accessing our inner power, autonomy, and interdependence.
 
Other work:
Blogs
Genderqueer Street Philosophactivist blog
Queering Herbalism blog
Zines
Queering Herbalism zine
Herbal Freedom School Webpage and zines.
Kwueen Shadez
Film
"Survivin'" - Queer Women of Color Film Festival in San Francisco.
Books
Notes from an Afro-Genderqueer
Notes from an Afro-Genderqueer2
Philosophactivism
Chapbooks: Saturn, Venus, Mars, Artivism
My writings are an extension of the life I live as a community organizer and activist committed to justice, equity, and freedom for all marginalized folks. Queer. Brown. Women. Genderqueer. All those who feel voiceless or invisible. My writings are a tool for healing and liberation. They are meant to open a space for cross-cultural, intergenerational dialogue that sparks collective action across difference . By examining all of who we are we are able to address multiple layers of oppression faced by the various communities that we are a part of.
These writings have helped me to heal by allowing me to work through my own oppression and re-examine and reclaim my multi-ethnic heritage and deep roots that span from the Americas, to the Caribbean, Africa, Spain and other parts of the Mediterranean and as far east as India.
About Resistencia: Sangre
In Resistencia:Sangre you'll listen to the silenced voices of Afro-Puerto Ricans, Tainos and their ancestors through the story of queer musicians, organizers and visionary community members committed to their island's liberation. While searching for their own autonomy and independence they stumble upon suppressed histories, tragedy, triumph and Truth. Experience the music and magic.
 
                            
                       

                                                                         


 


 




                      c
 
The Characters:
An interesting mix of punk band members, organizers and activists, artists, community members and visionaries and all are about decolonization, ending "the Struggle", and their oppression and reclaiming their birthright: Freedom.
There will be scenes with their African, Taino, and even Spanish, ancestors, healers, and scenes with anarchist, feminist, and other radical and powerful predecessors. And the play will integrate the following themes...
Main themes:

 

Liberation
Independence/Interdependence
Autonomy/Sovereignty

Trans and Queer identity and injustice

LGBT/Queer Rights
Afro-Puerto Rican Identity (*in spanish, see above link for an english video)
Taino (indigenous) Identity
Land rights
Environmental Justice
Economic justice
Gender justice
 
 
I'm super excited about the birth of this play as all of these themes contain elements of my personal history and I know that you will be excited with the outcome, too.
 
Why Resistencia: Sangre is important
             
This play is all about reclamation and resistance. For far too long, we've been denied our histories and forced to forget our roots and expected to assimilate. Afro-Boricuas and Tainos, especially those inhabiting queer bodies, have a rich history of political and cultural radicalism that is seldom told. Weaving together the stories of characters that embody contemporary countercultures, feminist and anarchist historical figures, and African and Taino ancestry, Sangre: Resistencia will help us uncover the more hidden side of the Island's rich culture of dissent.

Reclamation is healing. Healing is resistance.
 
Who is Resistencia: Sangre for?
This isn't for broadway or fancy, inaccessible bookstores with coffeeshops in fast gentrifying areas. This is for the People. I want to bring this to queer communities of color, our families, friends and allies. 
Resistencia: Sangre is meant to inspire dialogue that recognizes the significance of incorporating our spiritual roots, cultural ancestry and political heritage into our collective struggles to create a world free from exploitation.
While Resistencia: Sangre focuses on a specific group of Black and Brown Puerto Ricans, the themes addressed within are relevent to peoples of all racial/ethnic identities who are engaged in a struggle to dismantle oppressive hierarchies of power and reclaim their humanity.
Indigenous, Australian (Murri) artist and activist Lilla Watson once said:
"If you have come here to help me, you are wasting our time. But if you have come because your liberation is bound up with mine, then let us work together."
Our liberation is bound up together. And as Martin Luther King, Jr. said:
"Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere."
When we listen to each others' stories we begin to understand the complexities that have led to our oppression, our roles in the oppression of others, and what it will take as a larger community to heal from and transfrom a system based on suppression, invisibilizing, and invalidation.
Just as it took hundreds of years of careful crafting for this ridiculous system to dominate the world, it will be a slow process to dismantle it.
It starts with compassionate and transformational dialogue and blossoms into strategic action.
I know I'm sick and tired of being sick and tired...aren't you? Good! Please contribute to a liberatory play and novel by, for, and about the People!
Yes, YOU.

         
 

What's Needed to create Resistencia: Sangre


Airfare - Roundtrip Austin- San Juan=   $350

Lodging- $40-60 (avg $50)/nt. (hostels,paradores, etc) @ 10 days ~  $500

Transportation  (cheap rental car -$200/wk, bus, metro) = $300

       (to Taino villages, pueblos of predominantly folks of African descent,     University of PR campuses to speak with professors, sustainable farms and farms ran by women-"agro-mujeres" and visits to other sustainable projects, major cities: San Juan, Mayaguez, Ponce and mountain villages)


Gas $200

Food   $200

Emergency Funds $250


Fees charged by Indiegogo and Paypal- $200

 
Total: $2,000
 
What You'll Receive
As a co-creator of this work every single person who contributes will have free access the play online.
 
Here are some of the other amazing swag you will receive:
$5- Shout outs on the Afro-Genderqueer and Genderqueer Street Philosophactivist webpage plus access to online copy of the play Resistencia:Sangre. 
$10- above PLUS a shout out in the novel and play and access to online copy of novel and play. Plus 50% off novel and play.
$20- above PLUS a copy of either the novel or graphic novel and monologues from the play.
$50- above PLUS you get to name a character!
$100- all above PLUS you get to name the main characters' band or select scenes!
$250- all above PLUS a chance to contribute your art (poetry, drawings) to the novel and play
$500- All above PLUS 
autographed everythingtwo copies of play and novelfree tickets to closest show for you and your friends/fam$750- All above PLUS you get to help construct a scene in the play!
$1000- Everything above PLUSinvitation to special Areíto (ceremony), invitation to pre-show invitation to pre-release of novel.
YOU are truly an integral part of this work! Let's build this together.
The Impact


It's not easy to fund brown, queer liberatory art projects. There are few plays produced by and centered around queer people of color that are addressing similar themes with the intention of co-facilitating discussion and workshops around personal healing for collective liberation. 
I'm excited to write this play and novel about the invisibilized and those at the intersections of identity in a very real underground movement in Puerto Rico. Africanness and its importance in the very culture of Puerto Rico has been suppressed and the Tainos are said to have been decimated so they are only to be seen in pictures from the 16th century and museums that have them frozen in time even though there are many people carrying on the traditions.Also, over 30 queer folks have been murdered on the island in the past few years. There are very few protections for the queer and LGBT in Puerto Rico. Though so many travelers guides call it one of the most "queer-friendly travel destinations". When finished with this play and novel I hope to travel with it to Puerto Rico, the states, all over the Americas and abroad to raise awareness and empower those who may feel silenced!
You can contribute to this and be a part of the R/evolution.
Every single dollar toward this work is important and I can't wait to collaborate with those of you who are interested in collectively creating this story.
 

 
 
Can't Spare the Change? Here are Some Other Ways You Can Help
 



Get the word out on facebook, twitter, tumblr, and even beyond social media! Please share this page with anyone and everyone!
If you know of any community spaces, theatres, classrooms, etc. that may be a great place for this work, please get in contact with me so we can make it happen!
If you'd like to be involved with production, readings, or artwork for the novels, please contact me: gqstreetpoet@gmail.com.

 
When Will We See The Fruits of Your Labor?

I'd like to have a first draft of the play done by 2014 and a draft of the novel by May 2014.
But have no fear, I'll be blogging about my time in Puerto Rico and giving monthly updates on the play and writing process between now and March and I'll be releasing scenes online for all who are interested in how Resistencia:Sangre is developing.
 


                         
Thank you all for your support! Let's do this!

story:
HELLO, DOLLY!

The Professional Performing Arts High School will perform HELLO, DOLLY! for its Spring musical and the talented cast needs your help!

What We Need

  • Musicians: The Jerry Herman score requires depth! Currently, we only have a budget for 3 musicians. Ideally this score requires a band of 9.  We are paying NY's finest for their time and talent.
  • Costumes: The show takes place at the turn of the 20th century and we need to create costumes for that period of time. With a cast of 30 of New York's City's most talented young performers, we need every little bit to put them in their "Sunday Clothes."

The Impact

The PTA is very generous with helping with the majority of the cost of the show, but with a production of this size, we need extra help. For the second year in a row, we're asking for additional support to be able to present a production that is up to NYC industry standards!

Other Ways You Can Help

Help out by posting the link to this page anywhere and everywhere you can (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram)

SPREAD the WORD.

story:
Pulp Productions: we are a small band of students and professionals, troubadours and tragedians, brought together by our shared vision of what theatre--its organization and its presentation--ought to be. We are committed to an open, collaborative creative process, in which all are encouraged to share their ideas and listen earnestly to others in the building of character, craft, and authentic connection. And we strive, above all, for truth. 

Our latest project is J. M. Barrie's The Boy Who Wouldn't Grow Up,  more commonly known by its colloquial title, Peter Pan. However tempting it may be, one should not confuse this work with Disney's appropriation. Barrie's Pan is a sensitive and insightful exploration of imagination, the borderlands of childhood, and what we leave behind when we grow up.

Pulp Productions is currently unsponsored and unfunded, and depends entirely on the contributions of its members, as well as the generosity of people just like you. Peter Pan is our most ambitious project yet, and carries with it a few immediate costs that must be covered if we are to get off the ground. The first are the royalty payments, coming in at a $450. Thankfully, J. M. Barrie stipulated in his will that all royalty proceeds are to be allocated to the Great Ormond Street Hospital for Children, so this will not just be lining the pockets of the Samuel French estate. Secondly, we have insurance overhead along with permit fees, at $375, for use of a performing space. 

The current planned dates for The Boy Who Wouldn't Grow Up are June 14-15, 21-22, and 28-29. 

What We Need & What You Get

The break down of $900:

  • $450 for royalties: this covers royalties for 6 performances.
  • $375 for event insurance and permit fees
  • $75 to cover Indiegogo's percentage of the funds raised

Stretch goals:

$1200:

  • the above plus:
  • $300 for us to put toward building our set, purchasing props, and printing posters

$1700+

  • the above plus:
  • stipends for the production team to cover the costs of travel, food donated for work days, etc. 
  • stipends for actors

Your donations help ensure that we can meet the costs of royalties to put on this production. We consider your donation your purchase of a ticket to the show. All who donate $5 or more will have their name added to a comp list for the show (please note that we don't have assigned seating and have had standing room only for shows in the past--so come early!)

Why should you support this production?

Pulp productions strives to offer creative, heartfelt performances to our community. We offer sliding scale tickets to ensure that anyone who wishes to attend the performance can (we don't turn people away due to lack of funds). 

We are not your average community theater. We do not have a theater and so bring you interesting performances in sometimes unexpected places. Our goal with each show is to tell a story, it may be a familiar one, with honesty and care and often a little bit of humor. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute? That's okay, you can still help!

  • Let others know about the campaign and the production.
  • If in the area, come see our show!
