story:
Short Summary

Hi!  We are 'For Love & Duty Players' a new theatre company making our inaugrual production with the Planet Connections Theatre Festivity. 

A summary of 'Interpreting Her Martyr'd Signs'

In this unique adaptation of Shakespeare’s Titus Andronicus, Tamora, Queen of Goths and Titus’ tormented daughter Lavinia are locked together in Purgatory to await judgment.  Who belongs in Heaven and who in Hell?  Martyr’d Signs explores the monster in all of us on the road to redemption or damnation. 

Please check out our video and website for bios of the cast, promo shots, and more information on the show!  www.forloveandduty.com

What We Need & What You Get

To be completely transparent, here is what we are looking at having to spend towards this production:

$250 = Festival fee

$300 = To pay our co-directors and fight choreographer

$300 = Marketing - Ad space with the festival, postcards, online ads, etc

$2, 000 = Rehearsal space.  This is always the biggest expendature for a company.  We have been fortunate enough to have some free spaces offered to us, but some of the rehearsals have had to be in studios.  A minimum a room costs $20/hr (and usually rehearsals are 3 hours) We have some big group scenes, devised work, and fight work, and really need the space for safety of our actors. 

$450 = Props and costumes.  

IF YOU DONATE - WE HAVE SOME AWESOME PERKS IN STORE FOR YOU!

We want our contributors to be part of the experience.  We are offering everything from a soundtrack, a night out with the cast (accompained by a free drink - provided you are of legal drinking age), a sneak peak showing at a rehearsal, and dinner cooked personally for you at your home with some of the cast.  

The Impact

We are laying the foundation for what we hope will be a magnificant, innovative, and supportive company.  The arts are important in this world.  By helping us achieve our financial goals for this production, you also helping raise awareness for Safe Horizons and promoting green efforts to keep our Earth healthy! 

Other Ways You Can Help

We realize that not everyone is able to donate financially.  However, you can pass this along to others and make them aware of our campaign.  We would be ever so grateful. 

House Managing

Donating to Safe Horizon.  www.safehorizon.org

Come see the show! (Of course!)  We would love to have you in our audience.  You can purchase tickets at http://planetconnections.org/interpreting-her-martyrd-signs/

Thanks for contributing to our compaign!

story:
Short Summary

THE SPOT is approaching it's 3rd year of being in business!! Day after day, we continue to grow and expand to reach more and more satisfied patrons. Our goal to offer cutting edge theater to the Central Coast is becoming a reality. We have invested blood, sweat and tears (literally) along with countless hours and lots of money into the SPOT over the past 3 years. We are so happy and grateful for your patronage. 

Currently there is a major construction process going on in the front half of the building. This construction will not directly effect the theatre, but it will improve our entryway, lobby and bathroom situation. It will also bring us a lovely new neighbor in the form Comfort Market, a rustic cafe and market http://comfortmkt.com/. The construction process is scheduled to last 7 weeks and during the construction, the entire front of the building has been boarded up making it look as if we are closed. 

With your help, we can assure that the community realizes we are still here and going STRONG!

What We Need & What You Get

  •  We are putting together a major TV campaign to advertise our upcoming production of The Authentic Life of Billy the Kid, in hopes that we can drive up sales to the show and create more awareness of THE SPOT. $1500.
  • We are purchasing a vinyl sign to hang in front of the building in front of the construction wall to assure the community that we are still in the building. $250
  • We are going to place ads on the local newspapers advertising this show and again reinforcing the fact that we are not closed. $750.
  • For your support you can get some great gifts in return. We are just starting a series of 3 month workshops titled "Put on a Show." These classes will consist of everything that goes into producing a play; acting, directing, writing, set design/construction, lighting design, costume design and more! For your contributions you can receive any combination of the following rewards: a Facebook shout-out, your name printed on a poster of recognition in our lobby, tickets to shows in our season, 1 full enrollment in our first session of classes for yourself -or- as a gift to someone else, a personalized name plate on one of our theatre seats.
  •  We will be applying the first $250 to our our vinyl sign, the next $1500 to the TV campaign and the remaining $750 to our print campaign.

story:
The Yass Hakoshima Movement Theatre 
Premiere of "ECHOES"

Yass Hakoshima is the internationally-acclaimed performer, choreographer, and artistic director of the Yass Hakoshima Movement Theatre. He has been performing throughout the world for more than 40 years and has appeared at more than 400 American colleges and universities in 49 states and has been featured at international arts festivals in North America, Europe, Asia, Australia, and Central and South America. Hakoshima has made numerous television and film appearances, including his CINE-Golden Eagle award-winning video "Dream Journey." 

A choreographer as well as a performer, he has created stage movement for many modern plays, has worked in film and television and has collaborated with musicians and sculptors to achieve a synthesis of performing arts. Hakoshima's work is a fusion of East and West, as well as a blending of music, art, and literature, combining the tradition of mime, the mystery and fatalism of Japanese theatre, and the expansiveness of modern dance. His work has been hailed widely for its innovative content and thought-provoking style.

Yass Hakoshima is also the founder and director of the New Jersey Center for Mime (NJCM), the only training program in the state devoted solely to the development of aspiring mime artists and serious students in theatre and dance.

Danmari Ltd. is the non-profit umbrella organization for the New Jersey Center for Mime and the Yass Hakoshima Movement Theatre. The Japanese word for Mime or Silence is “danmari”. Danmari Ltd. has received continued funding from the American Music Center's program "Live Music for Dance",  (now "New Music USA"), including for Hakoshima's choreography of "Duality," "Duality II,"  "Wings," "Rashomon," "Arguments," "Extremities," and "Meian." The New York Times and the Star-Ledger recognized the works with great critical reviews.

The Sirius Quartet, born and bred in the downtown scene of New York City, blends the precision of classical music with the energy of a rock band. The conservatory-trained musicians are also highly skilled improvisors. Whether playing acoustically or with electronic effects, they push beyond the conventional sonic vocabulary. From Lincoln Center and the Köln Triennale to the Knitting Factory and CBGB's, the Sirius has made itself at home in a wide range of venues and musical styles. Their appearance in Yass Haskoshima's "Meian" in 2013 brought them great critical acclaim.


What We Need & What You Get

Why we need your help?

Yass Hakoshima Movement Theatre’s 43rd anniversary season features the celebrates Yass Hakoshima with live music by members of the Sirius Quartet, Chern Hwei Fung, violin and Jeremy Harman, cello and guest artists Nicole Camacho, flute, Wenhan Anderson, piano and Vasko Dukowski, Clarinet.

A production of this caliber requires an amazing amount of support in order to bring together dancers, musicians, set designers, lighting designer, costumer, videographer, the choreographer and last but not least a suitable venue. We hope to be able to raise funds in order to reimburse all these amazing artists involved in the “Echoes” production. We want to realize the mission of Danmari Ltd. and the Yass Hakoshima Movement Theatre to further the artistic development of the art forms of ancient mime and movement through performance, and to develop a better understanding of the art form and how it can be applied to Western contemporary life. Danmari's goals are to initiate and encourage interdisciplinary artistic collaborations.

With your help we want to produce a highly artistic, unique and joined project of movement theatre and live music.

Please be advised that all donations will receive a tax receipt. Danmari Ltd. is a 501c3 non-profit organization and all contributions are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. 

This special "Echoes" project will place you online with all the enthusiastic supporters and admirers of the Yass Hakoshima Movement Theatre and ultimately with the art of Mime and Movement Theatre. Yass Hakoshima is one of the few international artists to have continued this artform of silent theatre over more than four decades, in spite of lots of financial hardship, our mission is important and strong and that's why we are asking for your thoughtful and generous contribution. To support our efforts for this collaborative project: like music, mime and movement theatre are truly universal languages.

Most importantly, we have continued to receive overwhelmingly enthusiastic receptions wherever we perform and present workshops, reaffirming the universal appeal; of mime and movement theatre.

This time, we hope to raise $5,000 through our Appeal. We ask you to continue your important support by making a tax-deductible gift to this special campaign today. Gifts both large and small make a significant impact on our ability to fulfill our mission. Through them, you directly help us continue our unique 40-year legacy, combining mime, modern dance, music and traditional Japanese theater into a universal language-one that can touch all persons regardless of race, ethnicity, age and gender.

If you cannot help us with a financial contribution, we ask you to please help to build excitement for the special "Echoes" project by getting the word out to your friends, neighbors and relatives, and remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools.

We know you have many choices regarding which nonprofit group to support. Thank you in advance for doing all you can to help us reach our current financial goal for the "Echoes" project.

We have a number of wonderful gifts lined up for you, which you don't want to miss.

Domo arigato!


The Perks!

As part of our appreciation of your contributions, the Yass Hakoshima Movement Theatre will present simple but valuable objects related to the art of mime and Japanese culture. Among these objects are:

-  Autographed Photos - Vintage Posters

-  Limited edition T-Shirts

-  DVD's limited edition

-  An authentic Japanese mask used by Yass, in his presentations (autographed)

-  An antique authentic Japanese "Kimono".
story_txt:
The Yass Hakoshima Movement Theatre Premiere of "ECHOES"Yass Hakoshima is the internationally-acclaimed performer,
choreographer, and artistic director of the Yass Hakoshima Movement Theatre. He has been performing throughout
the world for more than 40 years and has appeared at more than 400 American
colleges and universities in 49 states and has been featured at international
arts festivals in North America, Europe, Asia, Australia, and Central and South
America. Hakoshima has made numerous television and film appearances, including
his CINE-Golden Eagle award-winning video "Dream Journey."  
A choreographer as
well as a performer, he has created stage movement for many modern plays, has
worked in film and television and has collaborated with musicians and sculptors
to achieve a synthesis of performing arts. Hakoshima's work is a fusion of East
and West, as well as a blending of music, art, and literature, combining the
tradition of mime, the mystery and fatalism of Japanese theatre, and the
expansiveness of modern dance. His work has been hailed widely for its
innovative content and thought-provoking style. 
Yass Hakoshima is also the founder and director of the New
Jersey Center for Mime (NJCM), the only training program in the state devoted
solely to the development of aspiring mime artists and serious students in
theatre and dance.
Danmari Ltd. is the non-profit umbrella organization for the New Jersey Center for Mime and the Yass Hakoshima Movement Theatre.
The Japanese word for Mime or Silence is “danmari”. Danmari Ltd. has received
continued funding from the American
Music Center's program "Live Music for Dance",  (now "New Music USA"), including
for Hakoshima's choreography of "Duality," "Duality
II,"  "Wings,"
"Rashomon," "Arguments," "Extremities," and
"Meian." The New York Times and the Star-Ledger recognized the works
with great critical reviews.
The Sirius Quartet, born and bred in the downtown scene of New
York City, blends the precision of classical music with the energy of a rock
band. The conservatory-trained musicians are also highly skilled improvisors.
Whether playing acoustically or with electronic effects, they push beyond the
conventional sonic vocabulary. From Lincoln Center and the Köln Triennale to
the Knitting Factory and CBGB's, the Sirius has made itself at home in a wide
range of venues and musical styles. Their appearance in Yass Haskoshima's
"Meian" in 2013 brought them great critical acclaim.What We Need & What You GetWhy we need your help? 
Yass Hakoshima
Movement Theatre’s 43rd anniversary season features the celebrates Yass
Hakoshima with live music by members of the Sirius Quartet, Chern Hwei Fung,
violin and Jeremy Harman, cello and guest artists Nicole Camacho, flute, Wenhan
Anderson, piano and Vasko Dukowski, Clarinet.

caliber requires an amazing amount of support in order to bring together

collaborations.

to produce a highly artistic, unique and joined project of movement theatre and
live music.

all donations will receive a tax receipt. Danmari Ltd. is a 501c3 non-profit
organization and all contributions are tax-deductible to the extent permitted
by law. This special
"Echoes" project will place you online with all the enthusiastic

story:
Short Summary

Balletomane is a small company of volunteer dancers undertaking work in the community to promote literacy to children in fun and innovative ways. Our 3rd installment in the Ballet Among the Books series is Three Magic Mice, based on the fantastic book by author Katie Dale, will be performed in public libraries free of charge to children ages 5-7. During post performance workshops children will explore story-telling and literacy themes through movement and dance.

The ballet is already fully choreographed. However we are in desperate need of funds for costume, sets, props and transport, and this is how you can help!

What We Need & What You Get

We are aiming to raise £2000 through this indiegogo campaign:

  • 28 sets of costumes
  • Back cloths and sets
  • Props
  • Transport -- for the sets and costumes to and from performances

We appreciate any help we can get. As a token of thanks, we have some fantastic perks lined up, including signed pointe shoes from company members, and a chance to watch our dress rehearsal and meet and greet dancers. Please check the right for details.

About Us

Balletomane was established in 2005, dedicated to bringing free, in-house classical ballet performances to those who are elderly, disabled, with limited access to the theatre, or suffering from illness or financial hardship. We bring performances to many places in Greater London, such as elderly care homes, disabled groups, specialist schools and public libraries.


Since the founding of the company, we have performed The Nutcracker (2006 - 2008) and The Sleeping Beauty (2009 - 2012), to various libraries and schools in the Greater London area. The performances and workshops have always been free for the audience as our aim is to bring ballet to those who would not be able to access it otherwise.


The company is currently self-funded. Our members are volunteers and many have non-dance related careers. We meet every weekend to rehearse, and the company members all contribute to the hiring of weekly rehearsal space. Any surplus goes towards other costs such as costumes and props. Therefore any donations are very gratefully received.


For The Three Magic Mice, we would like to bring the highest level of performance to our audience. We are therefore setting up this campaign to raise funds so we can put on our most spectacular show ever.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute, we understand. You can still help by spreading the word and letting your friends know about us. Please use the Indiegogo share tools above, by either:

  • Liking us on Facebook
  • Share our link on twitter
  • +1 us on Google+
  • Or simply, word of mouth, telling your friends and family about us!

Thank you!

story:
Short Summary 

  • Theatre is very important to me and introducing it to children is paramount. The future of theatre starts with feeding young playgoers and I want to contribute to that love of performance and storytelling. 
  • When I found out I was going to get a staged reading of my new Theatre for Young Audiences play, Swings & Roundabouts, I was overjoyed. What I didn't know was that there was a specific school desperate to see the play but unable to afford the trip to see it.
  • The play is about an 11 year old Afghan girl who finds her identity after moving from Afghanistan to Canada; the school that wanted to see a reading of my play is comprised mainly of Afghan students new to the country.
 

What We Need 

Roseneath Theatre has been generously guiding me through the process of creating this play for over two years and will be helping facilitate this process by wrangling actors and dealing with the administration necessary to take a four person cast to a public school. 

  • Even though this is a worthy cause I don't believe in asking artists to work for free. I am looking to raise enough to pay each actor for the day. This would cover transportation, the reading and the following question and answer period that will help me refine the play. An 8 hour day for four actors on a reading is just under $450.00.
  • .If I don't raise enough through Indiegogo I will bake a lot of banana bread and sell it to the people standing in line at the PanAm Games.

The Impact

 
  • Bringing theatre, even a reading, to a school that otherwise couldn't afford it is a remarkable gift. Not only will you be contributing to a future arts consumer but you'll be allowing children into another world that they rarely get to experience.
  • I ran my first campaign on Indiegogo and raised enough money to produce the 2013 SummerWorks play Eating Pomegranates Naked. Because of that show I won the RBC Arts Professional Award and NOW rated the play one of the best ensemble plays.
  • Theatre should be for everyone. and I hope you can help me bring it to a small group of special, worthy kids.

Risks & Challenges

Arts funding is at an all time low and I recognize that the holidays are not a great time to ask for help. Anything you can offer will be deeply appreciated.

Other Ways You Can Help

Just send me love and good vibes . And if you want to talk about Swings & Roundabouts in depth I'd be happy to send you an excerpt.

story:
Due to a series of unfortunate events (I'm guessing Kenny Chesney concerts and Sunday Funday fireballs), Miles needs your help to go to TomorrowWorld! Please see reward information for this exciting opportunity!

For every $ you donate, I will match it. 

If the amount goes over the ticket amount, the remainder will go to Ozear or some other child in need.

story:
Who We Are

Ótimo is a Latin fusion dance company inspired by styles of Brazilian dance such as: Samba Reggae, Maracatu, Samba no Pé and Samba Axé. For more information on who we are, please visit www.otimodance.com.

Ótimo Dance is proud to present our 2017 calendar fundraiser! Our goal is to raise $1,000 toward the creation and maintenance of the company set of professional-grade, handcrafted Samba dance costumes.  
 

Our costumes are hand-crafted, American made! So is our passion. 
You simply can't fake an excitement like this!
 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $1,000 and every dollar will go towards purchasing bulk materials needed to create feather headdresses and costume accessory pieces for lots of #shakeyshakey! These professional-grade costumes will be worn at our biggest performance of the year, Carnaval in February 2017! For show information, visit www.otimodance.com.

The first 50 people to contribute $20 to our fundraiser get a limited-edition 2017 Calendar! The calendar will feature a gorgeous selection of full-color, professional photos by Ray Pfeiffer.

 

Our performing artists are creative, innovative and incredibly dedicated to the costume design and construction process:

$500 covers the cost of almost 800 authentic rooster coque and ostrich feathers for our headdresses for 10 dancers

$350 covers the cost of gemstones, rhinestones and sequins to add shine and sparkle with costume accessories

$150 covers the cost of other crafting supplies for belts and headdresses:  wire, fabric, thread, hooks, ​felt, foam, glue, ribbon and elastic 

We need 50 calendar backers in order to reach our goal - will you back us? 
We truly wouldn't be able to do what we do without the support of the community! Thank you so much for checking out our fundraiser and for your support!

story:
Premiering at the San Francisco Fringe Festival September 8th-17th


L.Anguage

Written & Performed by Shameka Cunningham

Directed By Levy Lee Simon

Angeles,  a monolingual African American women, wants to be multi-lingual. As she investigates the cultural boundaries and bridges that language creates; she constructs her own language of words and cartwheels. A poetic response to her love/hate relationship with English, told through multi-media and storytelling woven between moments of silence, sign language, movement and music. In the end, it is a story about the moments that are beyond words that create the language of Los Angeles. Developed through TeAda Theatre Company New Works Festival.

Complete show description and ticket info:


http://www.sffringe.org/fringe11/11plays/langua...


How/Where your money will be spent:


Your support will help offset the following:


Production Expenses

- Photography and multimedia design

- Publicity

- Projector rental

- Rehearsal space

- Travel costs and lodging 


Direct support to the production team

- Stipends for Director, Stage manager, choreographer, and videographer

- The filming and editing of promotional DVD of the performance to help book future shows.


PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD on your Twitter or Facebook Page!


About the Artists: 

Shameka Cunningham(Writer/Performer/Producer) is a solo performance artist who has had her original one act play, "I Lost My Laugh in the Revolution" performed at numerous theatre festivals around the world and in the United States. At the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, I Lost My Laugh was heralded as, "A superb play with a pertinent message, this is definitely not one to miss." (Three Weeks Edinburgh Festival Guide).
Shameka Cunningham lives in Los Angeles, CA where her work reflects the diverse communities around her, the action and inaction of politics, and the food justice movement. Ms. Cunningham's work is performed in her own unique style of prose marked by the confessional frankness of a novel and the self-confident swagger of hip-hop.
Her credits include ; For Colored Girls… by Ntozake Shange at the Village Theater in Los Angeles and Long Time Since Yesterday by P.J Gibson: L She helped launch the Arts Education program with the Robey Theatre Company. She has performed with The Urban Bush Women Summer Leadership Institute in New Orleans. L.A.nguage was part of the TeadaWorks New Performance Festival.

Malesha Jessie (music consultant/opera singer) is a native of Southern California- Los Angeles. She currently resides in Brooklyn, New York. Before arriving to New York, Malesha spent the last 10 years touring throughout Europe and the Americas as an operatic soprano during which she earned her Masters degree in Music. During her training, Malesha worked for several non-profit organizations as an instructor, consultant and/or administrator. She is the creator of Musesalon , a network of artist, visionaries, educators and life enthusiasts that believe in community. www.musesalon.ning.com



About the Director:

Director Levy Lee Simon is a modern day artist concerned and passionate about the world we live in and its history. He is an Audelco Award Winner, Lorraine Hansberry Award Winner, Eugene O’Neill Fellow, Two Time NAACP Best Playwright Nominee an Ovation Nominee and Cosby Screenwriting Fellow. As a playwright Levy Lee is the author of twenty plus plays which have been produced and read in theatres around the country. Mr. Simon was born and raised in NYC and lives in Los Angeles, he has his MFA in Playwriting from the University of Iowa.


About the Producer/Choreographer:

Born and raised in Los Angeles, California, Perris Aria McCracken began her dance training at Paul and Arlene Kennedy’s Universal Dance Designs. She then studied at Westside Academy School of Ballet under the direction of Rosemary Valaire. Ms. McCracken continued her formal training under Ballet Master Yuri Grigoriev before joining the Debbie Allen Dance Academy in 2001. Her training also includes summer programs at Alonzo King’s LINES Ballet, Dance Theatre of Harlem, and Complexions. After graduating Cum Laude from Loyola Marymount University, Ms. McCracken danced for Lula Washington and joined City Ballet of Los Angeles. She currently freelances as a Contemporary Ballerina and works as a producer for Clear Point Entertainment.  


What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $2500 to help with production costs. 

Check out our great perks folks!!!!!

  

Other Ways You Can Help

SPREAD THE WORD ABOUT L.A.NGUAGE!!!  If you know people in San Francisco tell them to come to the show!!!!!  Share this campaign on facebook/twitter/blogs.

story:
My name is Scott Dehn and I own Golden Age Cinemas, LLC which operates the McHenry Outdoor Theater.  Some of my fondest memories as a child are of attending The McHenry Outdoor Theater with my parents, my sister and my grandmother.  As a six year-old, I could hardly comprehend the concept of watching movies on such a huge screen outside under the stars.  I recall watching "Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom" while sitting on my grandmothers lap in the back of our family's station wagon.  I remember explaining to her what had happened in the last Indiana Jones adventure.  I remember the smell of the blanket she cuddled me up in.  I remember loving the dancing food items on the intermission reel.  Most of all, I remember feeling so safe and loved amongst my family in this unique setting.  It was moments like this that remain with me to this day.  I fell in love with movies and this particular theater from that day on.

Today, I find myself blessed to be in a position to help provide memories like those I experienced as a child to a whole new generation of families.  I get to see the looks of awe and excitement on the children's faces as they arrive at the theater to see their favorite cartoon character or superhero on the big screen.  I know, however, that as the years go on it will be the time and moments spent here with their family and friends that they will cherish the most.

The McHenry Outdoor Theater has been providing memories for families for the better part of 75 years.  We are entering into a critical time for the continued survival of this theater.  Movie studios are beginning to stop production of 35mm film prints and releasing their features digitally.  The McHenry Outdoor Theater MUST convert its 35mm projection equipment to digital.  The projection booth will be in need of a massive overhaul to accomodate such an upgrade.  Without this conversion, The McHenry Outdoor Theater will not be able to operate much longer.  There are less than 400 drive-in theaters left in this country.  There will be fewer and fewer left due to this neccesary transition.  As a community, we have the opportunity to stand up and make a difference.  By supporting this campaign, not only can we save this beloved landmark, but we can make it even better!

What will a digital conversion mean to you as a patron?  Well, digital projectors provide a brighter, more vibrant image than anything that has ever been shown on our screen before.  It is so bright that we will be able to start our movies earlier than normal.  The sound will be digital as well which means you will experience a clear, crisp sound over your car stereo.  Most importantly, it will be easier for us to book the movies you want to see.  Currently, due to the dwindling amount of 35mm films being produced, we cannot always get the features we try for.  By going digital, that will no longer be a problem.

Drive-In movie-going is a big part of Americana.  It harkens to a simpler and more innocent era.  There are few places in this world that provide that anymore.  Saving this theater is more than being able to continue to watch movies.  It is about saving part of our community and country's identity and past.  Those are things worth fighting for.

I hope that you can help me by contributing to this campaign.  If you cannot, please at least share this with as many people as you can.  We need as much support as we can get.  The more money we raise, the more we will be able to accomplish at this theater in terms of upgrades and beautification.  We also are accepting donations in our concession stand throughout the summer and fall if you are more comfortable contributing in that capacity.

Thank you for supporting us in whichever way you can.  I will continue to do everything in my power to save this theater.  I hope that you will join me!

-Scott M. Dehn

story:
Premiering at the Bushwick Starr in October 2013, RoosevElvis ("Rose-of-Elvis") is a duet in which TEAM actresses Kristen Sieh and Libby King tackle two American icons of masculinity: Theodore Roosevelt and Elvis Presley. 

More fever dream than biography, RoosevElvis examines gender and appetite—both literal and spiritual—through the story of Ann, a slaughterhouse worker in South Dakota who is awakening to the sense that she is not strictly male or female. The play unfolds through a quintessentially American narrative: the road trip. Performed live and through film, Ann and her lover journey from the Badlands to Graceland, surreally transitioning into Elvis and Roosevelt as they confront contemporary America - its relationship to food, to gender, and to fame. 

Why We Need Your Help

The TEAM is thrilled to be headlining the Bushwick Starr’s 2013-14 season with RoosevElvis, which will also mark our 1st-ever World Premiere on American soil! That’s kind of a big deal.

Before we can get there, however, we have to hit the road—I-29 to be exact—to film the show’s central component: a time-fuzzy, surreal road trip from the Badlands to Graceland. Armed with cameras and faux-facial hair, Libby and Kristen will drive an RV, in costume and in character, from South Dakota to Tennessee, filming all the way. Your support will go towards flights, fuel, and film equipment for this gender-bending adventure. In return, we’ll not only send you missives from the road and other goodies, you’ll be one of the first people to see the finished product, wherever in the world you are, thanks to the miracle of Vimeo.

About the TEAM

The TEAM is a Brooklyn-based ensemble dedicated to creating new work about the experience of living in America today. Once described as “Gertrude Stein meets MTV,” our work crashes American history and mythology into modern stories to illuminate the current moment. We combine aggressive athleticism with emotional performances and intellectual rigor, keeping the brain, eyes and heart of the audience constantly stimulated.

story:
“Nutter weaves an incredible tale with pitch-perfect balance, avoiding the maudlin while alternately wrenching the heart and making us smile. This show deserves to be seen across the country -- and the continent." Pat Donnelly, The Gazette

In her award-winning solo show, Johanna Nutter tells the extraordinary and true story of her brother’s pregnancy. As she tries to put aside the role of family caretaker and live her own life, her transgender sibling is preparing to bring a child into the world he is not sure that he can parent alone. With barely more than a piece of chalk to set her stage, Nutter traces a portrait of a unique family, drawing us into her fight to assert her own identity and ultimately illustrating the universal struggle of following our own dreams while being there for those we love.

“Brilliant and moving…a profoundly wonderful play.”  Karen Muir, CBC Radio

 my pregnant brother is Freestanding’s flagship production and Johanna's first play. After winning the best of the Montreal Fringe Festival in 2009 and a subsequent MECCA for best text, the show began touring Canada. Perfectly bilingual, Nutter translated her play into French and presented both versions at La Licorne Theatre in 2010 (a first for the francophone theatre), winning a COCHON D’OR award for best Independent Production in Quebec and following up with a performance at the ProPulse Festival in Belgium; the only Canadian show to be invited.

Now, the show has been invited to the Pleasance theatre for the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, followed by a week at the SOHO Theatre in London. This is wonderful news and it comes at a price. Both theatres operate on box office splits of 60/40, so there are no guarantees and no financial support prior to showtime. At the same time, an outlay of about $15 000 CND is required to properly fund this tour. Accommodations and travel are expensive, plus we have hired an award-winning communications company to ensure that we don't get lost in the sea of shows at the world's biggest theatre festival. We have applied to the Canada Council for the Arts in the hopes of obtaining some assistance, and we are here; asking for your help as well. 

Along with the personalized eco-friendly perks that Johanna has promised, a donation to our project will also mean that a young and energetic company will have the resources to make Montreal, Quebec, and Canada proud. Time and time again, my pregnant brother has won over the communities it plays for, creating relationships that we will carry with us into the future. We are working diligently to promote our special brand of simple, intimate, integral, and reciprocal theatre: our latest show, Jeremy Taylor's Big Plans was a resounding success at this past SummerWorks festival, winning awards for Taylor and for Tanner Harvey, its director. This tour will not only open up further opportunities for my pregnant brother, it will also pave the way for our upcoming productions.

If you would like to support us financially--amazing!--we greatly appreciate your contribution. If you feel like helping out but don't have the monetary means, please do share this campaign (or if you know someone with a spare bedroom in Edinburgh for the month of August, Johanna is still looking). Also, if you're in Montreal on the 10th of June, there will be a special fundraiser evening at Mainline Theatre with back-to-back performances en français at 19h00 and in English at 9pm. Tickets available through the Fringe Festival: http://montrealfringe.ca/en/show/mon-frère-est-enceinte-my-pregnant-brother

Happy summer, everyone!
